text: 12floz can, COD: 10.20.2016, $1.50 and poured into a pint glass. I got a lot of sediment from the pour and little foam. Many particles are held in suspension, and at the bottom of auburn-brown body. Aroma and palate intertwine that is simply characteristic of toffee. Its pretty good.

35,5cl-blik vanuit een swap van de BelgianBeerSwappers. U: Donkerbruin met een dunne gebroken witte schuimkraag. G: Karamel, hazelnoot, gedroogd fruit en biscuits. S: Zoet. Gedroogd fruit, hazelnoot, karamel en gedroogd fruit. M: Semi-volmondig met medium carbonatie.
Above avg appearance.. nice color, nice head. Metallic malty aroma. Taste is syrupy, malty, biscuit, molasses. Its alright.

Piana nieduża, szybko opada do firanki. Barwa mocnej herbaty, opalizująca. W zapachu karmel zahaczający o toffi, melasa, orzechy laskowe. W smaku podobnie, dość słodkie, ziołowe, pojawia się także skojarzenie z masłem orzechowym. Goryczka średnia, tytoniowa, niskie wysycenie, lekko oleiste, lekko wyklejające w odbiorze.

Bardzo przyjemny English Strong Ale, dośc klasyczny, zładnie wkomponowanym, lekko rozgrzewającym alkoholem. Wydaje się podobne do Coopers Vintage Ale, bez porównania zaś miażdży popularne Innis & Gunn Original czy Youngs Special London Ale.
Jakaś dziwna lukrecjowa nuta się plącze. Karmel, melasa, dość dużo ciała. Nieskomplikowane i całkiem przyjemne.

Can. Dark red brown. Thin beige head. Medium bitterness, light to medium sweetness. Medium body. Dry light sticky finish. Aroma and flavour is banana, bread, yeast, caramel, malt, nuts, light chocolate. Lovely!

Poured from a 12 OZ can into a pint glass at Taco Mac in Atlanta. The appearance is a reddish brown color with a small tan colored head. The aroma is almost all malt with some nuttiness. The taste is malt with some molasses and some earthy notes.
Can. Mahogny red/brown with white head. Aroma of alcohol, cookies, toffe, nuts, earthy, malts. Medium sweet, medium bitter. A bit sticky mouthfeel, a bit too much alcohol feeling

Clear mahogany color with a tan film that reduces to a ring. Aroma has dark, caramel malt, dried fruits, mostly raisins. Taste follows with the caramel malt and brown sugar, light earthy bitterness on the finish. Light body and carbonation. Overall its a decent but really simple old/english strong ale.

33 cl can. Malty Christmas dark fruit kissel type of aroma. Taste puts the smell to shame though, quite full body with nice hoppiness, taste of licorice, chocolate, also dark fruits and sweetness reminiscent of the aroma in the finish. Positive surprise.

Can from a friend. Brown color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, nuts, toffee, caramel and a bit of hops. Bitter finish with citrus, nuts, toffee, hops, a bit of earthy notes and nuts. Very nice brew.

Aroma: Sweet raisins and hazelnut. 
Appearance: Dark ruby with a thin tan head. 
Taste: Really sweet raisins, hazelnut and brown sugar. 
Palate: Low carbonation, oily mouthfeel. 
Overall: Very sweet but nice in a small glass.
At Smokin Bettys in Philadelphia.

Talán nem nagy szentségtörés egy winter ale típusú italt március közepén kortyolgatni, mentségemre szóljon, hogy egy igen zimankós estén nyúltam az Old Jubilation után. Mahagóni teste lélekmelengető hangulatú, fűszeres, magvas, pörkölt malátás illatai valóban téli karaktert kölcsönöznek a főzetnek. Akárcsak édesen malátás, ragadós szerkezetű, szinte szirupos teltségű kortyai, amelyek süteménytésztás, kenyérhéjas, kalácsos színezetűek, végül pedig krétaporosak, angol modorú zárással búcsúzók. Remek kis itóka.
Can. Pours dark amber. Aroma is sweet, spicy, boozy, nutty, bit buttery, malty. Flavor is sweet and bitter, malty, nutty, fruity. Finish is nutty and dry some alcohol. Overall: ok, bit boozy.

330ml can (thanks martjoobolut). Small size, yellow head, stays. Sweet, roast, malty, nutty in aroma. Roast, malty, caramel, alcohol, sweet in taste. Sweet, faint hops, faint raisins in aftertaste. Alcohol is there. In can feel the heat. Solid brew.

355 ml. can @ Gollem: USA Beerweek(end) #2. Canned 20 October 2016. Very dark ruby brown, tanned big head. Nose is old leaves, ditch water, malt, stale caramel, kitchen spices. Taste is herbal leaves, old bay leaf, sugar, spices, leaves, Chinese medicinal herbs, candy, old candy, cacao, bit too thin,... Body is thinner caramel & bay leaf. Less malt sweet than I hoped, bit too old kitchen spices, medicinal herbs heavy. Okay but not on par with I hoaped, some soap in the body. Bottom of the can read "If you can dodge a wrench, you can dodge a ball" :)

Aroma is raisins, dark fruit, caramel, toffee, good. Appearance is reddish brown, light tan head, clear. Taste is caramel, dark fruit, booze, malt, good. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, dark fruit bitter aftertaste. Overall, Ive had better but its a good attempt by an American brewery.

Draft. Pours nearly black with a small off-white head. Aroma is licorice, molasses, hazelnut, raisin, and toffee. Taste is mocha, molasses, hazelnut, toffee, and dark fruit. Alcohol and a little roast in the finish. Full body. Soft carbonation. Heavy, sticky mouthfeel.

12 oz Bottle from 2010. so cellared fro 6 1/2 years. wow.
appearance: pours brown/ruby with a very thin tan head that vanishes quickly. it looks murky/opaque. aromas: dark malts and dark fruits (figs in particular) with some spices. theres bit of yeasty autolysis present. its vinousy.
palate: a full bodied beer with a rich texture, light carbonation assertive astringency. taste: strong toffee, molasses and caramel malt forward sweetness combines with figs, substantial alcohol warmth and a bitterness that hits the palate hard. the finish is sweet and short other than some lingering alcohol. - just what youd expect from an aged beer of this type. I would not say its mellowed. still a strong and assertive brew for those who like them like that.

Draught @ Milk & Hops - Chelsea. Murky brown with faint reddish tint against the light, very small frothy beige head, sweetish roasted malt aroma, low carbonation, bitter caramel/roasted malt taste with alcohol undertones, somewhat thick body, long bitter caramel finish. Very interesting and smooth brew.
Snifter on draft from Pazzos. Aroma of mocha, toffee, maybe some dark fruit. Very pleasant.

Pour from a 12oz can. Clear medium brown brew with tan head, great lacing. Nutty aroma, malty and some ethanol especially as it warms. Taste is sweet nuttyness up front tranitioning to drying hops, great offset of the sweetness in the final hops flourish. Boozey from the middle to the end of the swallow though, but I guess that is part of the appeal. Really great strong ale, fine for a winter evening.

Dark mahogany color with a thin beige head. Really bright floral & light fruit aromas; some toffee and booze notes in the back, too. Flavors are malt-driven with a toffee sweetness, nuttiness, and candied fruits; of course it finishes with a big kick of alcohol (cmon, its Avery). Some yeasty notes linger in the finish as well. Tastes very much like an English strong ale with a big bump in alcohol; call it a winter warmer if you want because the heat is there! Palate is medium, dry as hell, and astringent with the booze. Overall a very good winter ale, but the alcohol smells & tastes a lot stronger than 8.3% and can be a bit distracting.

Poured from can. Pours brown/amber with a tan head. Aroma is bready malt with cherries. Flavor is roasted malt, toffee, cherries, and chocolate. Finishes with a fruity yeastiness. The perfect winter brew.

Roasted malt aroma with some toffee and chocolate. Taste is malt dominant and has a slight chocolate finish feel to it. Balanced and full flavored. Malta add almost a spice feel but does not have any fake flavors some spiced beers have. Reading it is all different malts creating the complexity makes sense in how full flavored it is. Carmelized malty, very flavorful and balanced. Alcohol masked well. Really nice winter beer with great flavors and no fake spice tastes.
(Tap) hazy, bright reddish amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of jam, spice; thick palate; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish
Can. Mahogany Im color poured with a nice tan head. Aroma is toffee with dark fruit and spice flavorings. It is a bit boozy but overall well balanced.

12 oz. can from a $2.47 6 pack, awesome! Pours mahogany color wth a tight khaki film and collar. Aroma has caramel toffee muted roast notes dried nuts and faint fig, with a hint of bitterness. Taste starts bitter with roasted flavors of caramel toffee and fig and finishes with a meld of sweetness and bitterness. Palate is medium slightly chalky and dry. Solid brew, I believe this is close to a year old.

Avery Old Jubilation Ale 8.3%

This winter want pours a deep brown with w beige head of foam. The nose is rich bready malts and enticing spices. I get a spiced fruity banana bread kind of vibe from the aroma. 

Medium to full bodied with a round mouthfeel. The taste is rich malts and delicious fruitiness complemented by mild spices. I get grape & pomegranates coupled with nspice and toffee notes. A bit boozy but mostly well balanced. Yum. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Chevy Chase Wine and Liquors. Dark red body with medium head. Nose is sweet, caramel. nutty. Taste is caramel, plums, dark berries. Nice and spicy. Creamy finish. Good stuff.
Deep reddish brown with a thin tan head. Malty, nutty, with some sweetness. A bunch of dark fruit (raisin, cherry) without a real hops in the finish.
Pours dark red with a white head. Aroma is brown sugar, dark fruit and wood. Taste follows nose
Aroma of candied fruitcake and molasses. Flavors of dark fruits, aged caramel, and biscuits. Finishes thin and boozy. Not bad but the ending is disappointing.

A decent warmer. Nice dark color, deep red brown and hazy. Scent has some cloves and grassy spice. Sweet scent, but taste didnt carry that over. Light taste for a warmer. Nice and lifting. Mouth feel is clean. Tap
Nice color and bubbles, nice earthy minty, raisin burnt sugar character, a bit much alcohol

12oz bottle into glass. Pours a rich Amber brown. Light white lacing, clings in areas, head is about 3cm. Aroma of cherry cola, dark fruits, oak, rum. Taste of berries, booze guidance, tart apple, ripe cherry. Great seasonal beer. Dark fruits linger afterwards.

Poured from 2 each very cold 12 oz. cans into an english pint glass (the remaining ale kept cold in de can in de fridge) and, my goodness, a near perfect warming ale befitting as befitting the snow beginning to fall.
A full, warm aroma of dark malts; a hardy, reddish-brown color; tastes that satisfy the wintering soul. my take: ENJOY!

Great for the style. They managed to bring out spicy/ festive notes without adding any actual spice- malts come together beautifully. Pours a pale mahogany. Super nutty. On the sweet side but spice tempers it. Not overlyl boozy for 8.3%. Better than I expected.

Pour from can in recently bought six pack so no additional aging by me. Mahogany with soft white cloud of a head. Smoother than I expected and not boozy, up front molasses, some toffee, vanilla, very clean finish. Need to retry after some aging as I suspect it will improve but this was very good as is. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a reddish brown. Thin head. Aroma of caramel malt, sweet fruit, light chocolate, slight roast. Taste is smooth, kinda rich, dry and crisp finish. Sweet caramel, light chocolate and slight roast, pepper, spice. A little citrus. Not a bad English strong ale.

Orange and honey, dark brown color, spicy flavor with toffee, cherry, cranberry, excellent winter beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a slightly hazy brown with minimal head that dissipated fairly fast. Aroma is black liquorice toffee and cinnamon dark fruits. Taste follows the aroma with a slight molasses note. Very smooth but a bit of booze coming thru.

Hazy mahogany pour with pretty big tan foamy head almost pillow like. Aroma of toffee and caramel with a sugary scent to it. Flavor of some plum and mostly caramel. Had some nutty character as well. Sweet finish good beer.

On tap at the brewery on the 2015 launch day, wearing my ugliest sweater... Deep dark brown with a thin lacing head, aromas of toffee and apple (not quite toffee-apple though!). Dry-sweet and lightly toasty. Demerara and hints of umami and cola.

355ml bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with a small head. Aroma of caramely malts, toffee, syrup and sugary sweetness. Taste is sweet, malty and syrupy with some toffee. Finish is sweet, heavy and warming with loads of syrup, toffee and caramel. Too sweet and messy.

355 ml bottle. Enjoyed at Los Angeles, CA. Pours a dark brown colour with a small beige head. Aroma of toasted malts, nuttiness and wood. Flavour of sweet maltiness, syrup, bread, mild spiciness and mild graininess. Full bodied. Alcohol warms. Sweet and spicy. No complexity.

355 ml bottle @ hotel room, Los Angeles.
Pours dark mahogany color with a small head. Woody and toffee-dominant aroma and resin. Flavor irs sweet with toffee and caramel, ripe fruits and mild spice notes. A bit sweet.
6424

35,5 cl bottle @ hotel room, Los Angeles. Aroma ihas sweet malt, nuts and toffee. Flavour has nuts, sweet malt, licorice, toffee and some hoppiness. Also sugary sweetness. Too sweet but somewhat drinkable anyway.

Notes from Churchkey Avery Cellar event. 2014 draft and 2004 bottle. Dark amber with small white head. Caramel malt, sweet candy, bread, hint of cocoa. 10 years on is much more subdued and mild, with the taste too mellowed for me. Prefer the new, and quite like it at that.

Absolutely beautiful color. Thin foam layer which leaves small islands of foam after a short time. The aroma is incredibly delicate black currant, lots of other soft fruits and some smoke and a little mocha.
The taste is almost as heavy as the aroma might indicate, but it has a nice sweetness of berries, distinct mocha and slightly nutty flavor that together with smoked malt gives the unique fullness and very different composition than expected. Hard Roasted malt is the back of the taste spectrum. It has clearly port tones.

12oz bottle from Luckys in Clintonville. Shocked I hadnt rated this. Burnt brown orange pour. Aroma of muted sweet malt, grassy. Tastes are creamy sweet caramel malt, dark fruit, brown sugar - which is usually all bad news for me - but this is well balanced and not overly sweet. Cola vibe. Easy drinking and covers the alcohol well. Good brew.
Old rating. Pretty mahogany color. Big malty, nutty flavor. Not much spice at all. A lefty sweetness with a bitter finish. All around nice unspiced winter offering.

Aroma: alcohol, roasty, bread, 
Appearance: black, clear, minimal head, 
Taste: heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate: full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2015 Reddish brown pour, slight head that fades quickly. Aroma is sweet, high mal (toffee), slight fruit. Palate is smooth with a semi dry finish. Aprreciated the absence of spices considering its a quality that is typical of the winter beers. Flavor was pretty flat with straight sweetness with a slight nuttiness towards the end. Fairly simple overall.
Poured into pint glass from bottle, dark mahogany with toffee nose and light carbonation. Medium bodied, malty with caramel finish. Great to have a winter ale not doctored up with spices.
Pours mahogany in color with a tan head. Aroma is sweet caramel. Flavor is sweet malt with a hint of nuts and caramel.

12oz bottle poured into an English pint.

Old Jubilation pours a deep mahogany to burgundy with a fairly thin creamy tan brown head that lasts a solid 30 seconds. The aroma is caramel, molasses and a bit nutty. The flavor is milk, caramel, molasses, licorice, hazelnut, spices and a bit smokey. Overall this is a solid brew.
Pours blackish brown with a tan head. Aroma is sugary malt. Flavor is sweet brandy with bitter finish. Awesome.

おーるどエー  
香りは控えめ&

Pours dark brown with a foamy thick head. Aromas of toffee, caramel, and sweet malts. Tastes sweet and nutty with toffee, and caramel. Hops are well hidden beneath the malts. Nice winter ale in the English strong ale style. High alcohol content and the big malt profile makes this one a sipper.

Look: pours a dark Amber. Tan head. Very clear.
Smell: hops. Sweet caramel. Pine. Muted Citrus fruit.
Taste: heavy roasted malt. Slight bitterness on the back. Pine and grass. 
Feel; medium carbonation. Taste more like a porter but too dry for that. 
Overall: not what I was expecting with ale in the label.
First drank: home 1/5/15
Vintage: 2014
Bottle, 1 year old. Cola. Hazelnut aroma. Toffee sweetness, toasted malt, with big nutty flavors in the taste. A very good, smooth winter brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass.

Appearance: dark reddish-brown with plenty of streaming carbonation. Pours a 1" cream colored head that falls pretty fast with some lacing left behind.

Aroma: rich aroma of toffee, dark roasted barley, earthy and citrus hops.

Mouthfeel: medium bodied, slightly astringent, with a dry finish and a lingering alcohol burn.

Flavor: complex mixture of rich roasted barley, cocoa, toffee, some tangy citrus and herbal hops and a definite alcohol presence.

Overall: a hearty and tasty brew, this definitely fits the definition of a "winter warmer". Excellent to sip on a frigid winter night.

From a bottle. Pours opaque copper brown with a fizzy off white head. Tastes very malty, like toasted bread, cereal, nutty caramel, light booze. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like toffee, nutty, toasted malt.

Bottle. Pours cola brown with creamy beige head. Aroma is cereal and toasted malts, caramel and toffee, dates, faint woody notes, and faint booze. Flavor is rich, chewy malt profile with some alcohol spice, light woody notes, light earthy hops, faint chocolate, and some dark fruit sweetness. Medium body and carbonation.

Aroma has current and sugar. Not spiced, not too sweet. Dark caramel malt, maybe some roast or chocolate in small quantities. Trailing coffee bitterness. Nicely balanced. Neutral yeast. Definitely a sipper, as the bitterness coated my palate after a few sips. Hides the alcohol well. Really nice winter brew, would try again. Curious how it would age.

12oz bottle picked up at Wilburs 
Pours clear dark brown/mahogany with a small off-white head, some lacing. Aroma or dark malts, nutty and coffee. Taste of roasted malts, ashy, coffee and molasses 
Pretty tasty, Id like to get a few and cellar them.

Excellent Christmas Ale. Dark roasted malts with a balance of hops. Definately a buy again Christmas Ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2016 Bottle. Pours a deep brown color with white head. Slight roasted and nutty aromas. Malty, cardboard, dark fruit, alcohol, caramel flavors. Really not impressed. All cardboard and malty and boozy.

Caramelized, sugary malt is the main element here. Pours dark amber with decent head and lacing. Sweet finish and thick consistency - a little syrupy. Tap at Churchkey, 2014 edition.

I also tried the 2004 bottle pour at the Churchkey event yesterday and it didnt hold up quite as nicely as the newer one.
Alcohol very present in the flavors. Surpasses a sub-par pour and vegetal aroma. Nice creamy finish.

Pours a dark reddish-brown with 1 finger just off-white head thats very resilient. Aromas - chocolate, malt, little caramel and a subtle spice. Taste - malty, chocolate, a little caramel, some spice. Really nice.

Bottle into a pint glass. Pours a rich red/brown, with a medium light brown head. Nose is malt and caramel, and the taste is the same, with notes of hazelnut. No spice, which is nice for a change. Finish is smooth. Nice.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a fluffy beige head. Malty sweet aromas of caramel, brown sugar and chocolate. Flavors are brown sugar, caramel, chocolate, with coffee, toffee and ripe stone fruit in the finish. Slightly syrupy mouthfeel. Overall, this is a big malty ale. Very, very nice.
Pours a dark red-brown. A dark fruit and sweet malt aroma. Strong dark fruit (prune), malt, and caramel taste. A medium body with a lingering malt taste.
Strong and sweet. Leaves a sticky residue on the lips. Flavor is hard to describe. Its drinkable, but I wont be seeking it out again.
Caramel and sweet, sort of a barleywine light. Gorgeous pour. Superb able for this time of year.

Poured a dark red to brown colour with a thin white head. Aroma is quite malty with dark fruits and caramel/ coffee notes. Flavor is a sweet malt mixture of nuts and dark fruits with a bit of hop bitterness. Not much of coffee in flavor, but enjoyable none the less.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2015 Dark red mahogany color leaves lacing around the glass. Has a sweet Malty/doughy boozy taste, dry with a slight sweetness. Flavor lingers on the tongue well after each sip. This ale is not half bad.

very dark buy with white head leaving moderate lacing. Aroma is sweet fruit, raisin, malty. hint of booze. Taste is moderately sweet hint of bitter. Medium bitter finish..malty. Im not sure what I dont like about this, but I just dont dig it.

This is the 2004 vintage. Red bright pour with black floating sentiment. Poured from a bottle at Delilahs Christmas tasting. Carmel biscuit and sweet aroma. Taste is crazy sweet with honey and prune notes. Wow

Pours a dark mahogany with a small off white head. The aroma is rather sweet, you pick up roasted malts, caramel, brown sugar, coffee, nutty, and slight amount of alcohol that is more prevalent as the beer warms. The taste is very similar to the aroma especially the nuttiness and caramel/toffee. This beer was much sweeter than I was expecting and the alcohol was surprisingly well hidden in my opinion. There is not much bitterness to this beer at all. This beer is well worth a try!

12 oz bottle pour. Pours a super dark burnt color with a temporary sudsy head. Mild malt aroma. Avery for me is known for their huge abv beers. Their "beasts." However, some of these littler ones are really good. Really nice smooth roasted malt flavor with a nutty, bready, and almost smokey flavor. Full body of flavor on this one, and very good. Enjoyable for sure
Full body, hint of spice, smoky but smooth. Reminiscent of the GD Hibernation, but not as strong, mellow on the palate.

Ive had this many times, but just now getting around to rating it. Lots of holiday aromas -- citrus, light wood smoke and chocolate. Really crisp, but I am drinking this one right off the store shelf. Long, clear and bright orange, lemon middle of the palate. Comforting; like the rock of a cradle.
11/24/2014. From bottle. Dark reddish brown with a tan head. Sweet malty aromas. Hints of dried fruit and caramel. Oily texture, toffee, malt and nutty flavors with a boozy finish.
A nice sticky/nutty sweet but not cloying strong ale/old ale type thing. I dont get the mocha/coffee aspect described above, but a quite nice beer regardless.
Not a bad beer. A little week in the aroma but is very flavorful. Will keep you warm on a cold snowy nov 16th

Pours an Amber brown color with tons of particulate matter floating throughout. It has a short caramel colored head.aroma is dominated by caramel. Mildly thick mouth feel. Just a bit of carbination bite in the back of the throat. Toasted and caramel malt forward.

Tap at Bulldog Lowertown. Pint glass. Very little head and plenty of darkness. Dark brown to black in color. Faint aroma with some malt presence. Serves as a prelude to the malt-centric taste. Roasted qualities are obvious with balance kind of missing. A freshness is there which is appreciated. Caramel. Not a lot of bitterness. Pretty good even though this review isn?t all that jubilant.
Tap at bulldog lowertown. Black with small head. Malty aroma. Slightly sweet and very malty and warming. Very low bitterness. Soft mouthfeel. Nice finish.
Pours mahogany brown. The flavors on the palate are mostly caramel with a coca-cola finish. Overall, would like to see more structure in this beer, but it does hide its ABV quite well.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a dark mahogany brown with a small creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and dark fruit. Upfront, their is a rich roasted maltiness with hints of cocoa, nuts and burnt caramel. Some resiny hops come through in the finish, and the rich dark malts begin to mellow a tad. A long bitter, roasty aftertaste completes this hearty, warming ale. I might set a few bottles down to see how they age.

BOD 267/14. Dark amber pour with a very deep dark ruby cast. Below average head, lacing and retention. Subtle, but nice, nose of dark fruit (plums, figs) over a biscuit like sweet base with strong caramel notes. Almost medium body with a slickness that becomes more pronounced as it warms. Above average carbonation with some effervescence in the middle and finish. The flavor profile is intense, very complex and well balanced until the finish. It begins with a smooth blend of flavors that tend to cascade to the forefront. Sweet biscuit and caramel begin, then yield to the dark fruit over a very mild toffee note. The middle is mildly bitter with a citric rind like note that fades into bitter dark chocolate. The long finish is where the alcohol comes to the forefront, but is somewhat masked by a residual sweetness. A grain alcohol like aftertaste lingers.
Great beer. Spicy flavours, and very long lasting. Thick palate to go with it.

Medium sweet malts dominate subtle earthy hops. Smoke, caramel, white chocolate, lightly roasted coffee beans. Light vanilla, with some sherry-like nuttiness. Bit of alcohol on the finish. Pretty good.

"pretty much a textbook winter warmer. pleasant flavor, good alcohol presence without being overbearing. better at 50 degrees or more. no need for spices like so many other holiday brews. malty, nutty. simple yet refined."

This stuff is awesome! Aroma is lots of toasted malt faint dark fruit note. Taste is incredible with lots of toasty malts, caramel, burnt sugar, and nutty notes. Finish a smooth sweetness thats soft on the palate. This stuff just gets better with age.
Bottle from world beers. Pours a dark amber. Scent is a malty spicey one. Taste is malty also. Some spice, cinnamon. Pretty good beer.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours dark brown with a thin beige head. Aromas of almonds, toffee, crunchie bar, cinnamon spice. Taste is sweet and nutty. Finishes sweet. Interesting.
bottle at home ... deep brown ... thin tan lacing ... dark sweet toffee malts ... soft sweet toffee malt ... that caramel tofe malt im not fond of ... soft tofffee malts ... dull malt... not me
Bottle at home. Pours dark brown, nose is sweet, nutty, pumpkin? toffee, taste is sweet, dry toffee, light spice, rich, fruity.

12 ounce bottle, a friend gave a bottle of this to me a month or so ago so I assume its from this past winters batch. Served in a DFH Signature glass, the beer pours a murky brown color with about an inch off-white head. Head retention and lacing are both decent enough. Aroma is nice and malty, the brew smells like caramel, toffee, nuts, and some chocolate. I think the taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but theres also some dark fruit, brown sugar and dark bread flavors noticeable. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit coating and smooth with moderate carbonation. I liked this, its good on a summer day and would probably be good on a winters day too!

Transfer from BA review on 5-24-12- 
Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

Appearance- Poured a deep mahogany-brown color with a small off white head. The head faded fast with very little lacing left behind.

Smell  Sweet aromas of dried fruit and molasses mixed with a very light slightly roasty aroma of malt.

Taste  Up front there is a malty flavor with a good dose of sweet sugary flavor . These flavors form a base for the rest of the flavors to end and leave from. Right after the initial flavor a slightly nutty flavor comes to the tongue. This leaves soon after it arrives, allowing for roasty notes to come to the tongue. Toward the end the malty roast and sweet flavors mix with some light spice flavors and an ever so light bitterness. While they are slightly bitter they by no means tame the sweeter flavors of the tongue.

Mouthfeel  The body is on the above average creamy side with the carbonation on the lower side. Good for the sugary and roasty flavors and higher abv of the beer.

Overall  It has some nice flavors and a good blend of sweet and roastiness. A good and drinkable brew but nothing too fantastic.

Bottle at home from notes. Pours a dark hazy amber color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have caramel, plums, figs, dates, brown sugar, spices and chocolate. Medium-bodied. This is a nice one to sip on cooler evenings.

Really good come winter, this ale is nice and warming. Pours a nice dark amber color with off-white head. Spice, roasted nuts, and some caramel/toffee notes on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with a sweet toffee note.
Poured a clear brown with a cream top. Taste of toffee, malty and nutty. Medium carbonation, medium body.

At 6.99/six pack at Total Wine this may be the best value beer I have ever tried. Bold hoppy upfront and throughout but well balanced with malt flavors of toasted toffee that linger for ever on the tongue, remarkable. Ill be buying by the case from now on.

aroma is sweet malty with some resiny hop presence to balance..thin off white head,sparse lacing deep brown clear liquid with some cloudiness..sweet in a fruity caramel sort of way but not overdoing it theres tingly hops to balance..med-full bodied,tingly and plentiful carbonation..overall I tried this just as a nite cap as a single bottle ill be picking up the 4 or 6 pack before winter ends well done
Draft sampler at The BeerHive in Pittsburgh. A nutty taste throughout with hints of spice. A nice winter warmer.

Pour is deep ruby red, transparent, with a tan head and fair bit of lacing. Nose is salty and meaty. A bit of berry and malt sweetness, slightly oxidized in back. Taste is more sweet, tinge of alcohol, faint herbal hop. Seems a hint sugary with some brown sugar and caramel lingering. Medium body, soft carbonation, a hint slick.
Great winter seasonal beer. Rare find in NJ. Pour from 12 ounce bottle to a pint. Pour very dark amber with thin white head. Malty and boozy but in a good way. Enjoy if Troeg Mad Elf is out of stock

P: Pours a ruby cola appearance with a vast community of floating specks. A small short lives bone colored head that fizzles down to a lizard skin cap. 

S: Right away cherry NyQuil floods the nose. Dark fruits create a sweet sticky aroma, holiday fig pudding, dank grains, clove, hints of star anise and cola. 

T/M: Lots of spice up front, roasted grains, astringent cherry booze, slight oxidation, dark fruit and bitter pears show up toward the finish. I also get some bubblegum, pomegranate, white grapes and under ripe persimmons that create that buttering chalky bite. Body is medium and a tad on the thin side with velvety carbonation. Once warmed the finish is similar to a box of crayons. 

O: A great old ale in a six pack. I love that this isnt a pricey bomber and its well executed. Tons of figgy goodness with cherries, booze and spice. A nice holiday treat.

Serving type: bottle
Bottle. Ugly dark amber with sediment. Toffee and candy notes. Tastes like a barley wine.-- rated with beerbasher
Bottle. Garnet with tons of white floaties. Caramel and wet wood aromas. Sweet, candi and berries.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 11/8/2013. Pours moderately cloudy deep ruby red color with a 1-2 finger dense light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big caramel, raisin, plum, brown sugar, toast, biscuit, brown bread, pepper, herbal, floral, light chocolate, light roast, and herbal earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of big caramel, toast, biscuit, raisin, plum, brown sugar, brown bread, pepper, herbal, floral, light chocolate, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Fair amount of earthy herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toast, biscuit, brown bread, brown sugar, raisin, plum, pepper, herbal, floral, light chocolate, and herbal earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and earthy/spicy hop flavors; with a good malt/bitterness balance and no cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a fairly slick, bready, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very nice old ale style. Good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and herbal/spicy hop flavors; and very smooth to sip on. A very enjoyable offering.

Aroma of Christmas pudding and cereal, some dark fruit, brown sugar, taste is pretty similar, nice but like Anchors Our Special Ale, can only have one or two at a sitting, not made to be a session ale.

2013 bottle. Cola looking pour, yeast Pleasant malt driven aromas and flavors. Dark fruit, raisin, cola, roasted nuts, coffee, clove and spices. Mouthfeel is lighter then I expected.. Watery, medium body.. with soft, creamy carbonation. Nice lingering finish of the above mentioned flavors. Very Belgian Dubbel-esque. A good go-to value winter beer.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...
Draft at Beveridge Place in West Seattle. Darkest ruddy brown, good foam. Alc soaked grapes and raisins. Smooth, soft. Alc is well hidden. nice
I keep this beer stocked all winter. It exhibits tons of wonderful dark roasty flavors with some sweetness and alcohol. Great winter warmer.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with quite a bit of floating sediment and a thin light brown head that lasts. Taste is of dark roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, toffee, coffee, smoke, wood, fruit and some hops. Has a similar aroma. Has a nice chewy body with a moderately bitter and dry finish. Though there are a lot of flavors, each one is pronounced and feels as it should be there. An excellent brew.

First in the style. Pours murky brownish purple with a half finger of creamy off white head. Aroma is chocolate, figs, molasses, sweet malt, prunes. Flavor is big dark fruit notes with plums and figs, molasses, just a hint of chocolate, some brown sugar, black cherry. Mouthfeel is medium heavy with medium carbonation and light bitterness on the finish. Overall a nice malt bomb that would be warming on a cold winter day. Good stuff.

Draft at Hot and Soul in Ft. Lauderdale. Snifter. Nice dark brown, glassy pour with a thick eggshell head. Some lacing. Serious warming aroma with toffee, caramel, sweet dark fruits, dark sugars, and mocha. Also spices galore. The taste was sweet at first but diminishes to more of a dark fruit and warm booze finish. You get the dark fruits, the dark sugars, toffee and spices (although I guess the spices are from the malts.) Full body, creamy mouth feel. Low carbonation. I had just before dessert and that worked. If I had it with my main entrees it would have been too sweet I think.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown with a quickly dissipating tan head. Aroma is sweet and fruity, almost like fruit roll ups. Taste is dark fruit, nutty, slight apple hints, roasty on the finish with a moderate alcohol punch. Medium sticky palate with little carb. Pretty good but could use something to cut the sweetness.
Delicious winter time brew with plenty of complex flavor, without too heavy of an aftertaste, or lingering alcohol overpowering.
Bottle from Winestyles. Pours a dark amber with very slight off white head. Aroma of dark fruit and malts. Taste of wood and raisins with a slight alcohol burn.
On tap at Bangers & Lace. Thin, a little spicy, somewhat malty, but not too much flavor here. Disappointing.

pours mahogany. thin white head quickly dissipates. aroma is got some basement funk going on. wet socks left on the floor. flavor is malt and spice. ive never been a big fan of winter ales so I know im being extra critical on this. huge fan of avery so I thought I would give this a chance. not doing it for me. aroma and flavors are not pleasant for me. this isnt a drain pour by any stretch but I think im done with winter beers.
Dark brown with a thin tan head. aroma is roasty malts and spice. Flavor is roasty malts, with hints of dark fruit, burnt caramel, and spice. Medium carbonation.

Pours a nice mahogany color with a small tan head that fades to some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, nutty, dark fruit and bit of caramel in the background. Taste of roasted malt, nuts, bit of chocolate and caramel for a subtle sweetness. Mild bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body, smooth and creamy. Nicely balanced. No trace of the 8.3% ABV. Enjoyable beer very fitting for the holidays,
a great winter warmer from avery. Nice malt sweetness up front with a load of complexity on the back end. A great big beer from one of our best breweries.
Kind of a dong beer, its sweet and dark... yo make up your mind and be a Christmas beer or a winter beer, dont try and be both
Assume winter seasonal brew with nice mouth feel. There are slight hints of whisky on the back end.

2011 Edition

A: dark pecan ale with some orange hues. a finger of off-tan foam falls to a sheet of the same. Excellent clarity. Spot lace.
S: Sweet, slightly molasses malts are nice. No real hop presence here for me. 
T: The alcohol is evident here initially (off-putting for me). Some pecan flavors. Some licorice (so faint).
M: thin with moderate carb and semi dry finish. 
O: Decent beer. I like it as the third or fourth for the night, a little unrefined for the premier drink.

Serving type: bottle

11-21-2011
Hmmm, have not rated this one yet! Poured a mahogany color with an off white head. Dark fruits, caramel, some nutiness, and some spices.

Bottle. Pours as describes- rich dark red. Aroma is hard to pick up- getting some yeast spiciness and dried cherry, but nothing too pronounced. The mouthfeel is creamy, with quad-like spice and ginger notes. Finish is a touch metallic. I didnt wait to cellar this, but maybe that would add some additional depth. Finishes surprisingly thin, with a little bit of sticky pine needles lingering.

Bottle to pint. Deep red pour with a touch of off white head. Big nose of roasted nuts and dark fruit. Taste is similar with some nice body. Alcohol is well-hidden. Captures the idea of a winter seasonal perfectly.

First Avery offering that I tasted this past spring..found 6 pk at small bottle shop in queens..poured into pint glass..nice chestnut color..2 finger head with a little lace..clears quickly..great fruity, nutty aroma..and hits the tongue really well..stays in the palate but not in an overbearing way..an excellent winter ale that made me go and try a number of other Avery quaffs..highly recommended.
Draft to taster. Looks good; a transparent copperish brown with light beige head. Smells malty with otes of sweetness and winter spices. Tastes like it smells with a solid mouthfeel. Enjoyable.
This is a great tasting Christmas ale. Bottle days can cellar for three years, I would for at least one maybe two years.
Tap- Pour is brown with a thin off white head..Nose is toffee, spice, sweetness, dusty chocolate, caramel...Taste is nice caramel, toffee, spices, cherry, alcohol is hidden.

Pours a deep cola colored brown with a slight head. Aroma is sweet maltiness, healthy mouthfeel, and a taste of sweet black coffee, slight chocolate.....spiced and bittered notes in the back end. A well built winter warmer.
bottle. brown with small head. rich malty body. the hint of hazelnut is nice. good winter ale.

This is a great example if a winter ale. The hazelnut in it is spot on. Very complex beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pour. Another classic brew from Avery. My first English Classic Ale and Im loving it. A good mix of hops and malty sweetness. I love the toffee tones in this one.

Pours mahagony brown with very little head. What's there is off-white and mainly a rim. Aroma is pure maltsville - toasted nuts, yeast and sweet roasted grains. Maybe a touch of prune. Taste is full of complex malt flavors with more nuts, toffee and booze closing to a slightly bitter linger. No spice, but very warming and seasonal for winter. Quite bright up front with some carbonation. Dry on the palate. A nice beer that will appeal to malt heads, though I must say I enjoyed it less as it warmed. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hints of licorice and toffee. A nice, different twist for the holidays. Almost a brNdy-like taste note and relatively high ABV. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark, fruity, spicy, and strong enough to put some color in your cheeks. Great winter warmer with noted of cherry, ginger with a solid malt backbone.
Pours black with thin tan head. Rich, spicy aroma. Notes of plum and anise. Taste has notes of anise, rhubarb, blackberry but with a bitter backbone. Finish is warming.
This is great winter warmer. Spicy, but not overwhelming. Flavors of dark fruits, chocolate, and toffee.

Bottled September 7, 2013 (2.5 months old).
Appearance: The body is a beautiful garnet hue with fine sediment in suspension of the, otherwise, clear body. The head is short and short lived, settling into a thin/sparse coating with a foamy and uneven ring. The color here is worth a 5 alone though, its a brilliant deep garnet that looks almost majestic.
Aroma: The aroma is big with dark and slightly syrupy fruits, a hint of medicinal quality as well. I get an non-descript malt sweetness as well. The aroma could use some more strength, but it smells very nice.
Taste: The intro is of brown sugar and dark fruits, this leads to a mid-taste that is nutty and a bit dry, which continues through the finish with a slight medicinal cherry flavor. The finish is dry and lingers of medicinal cherry, its mild though.
Palate: Full-bodied with mild carbonation.
Overall: This is an enjoyable beer, but I find that it doesnt have the complexity I expected from reading the description. I would have liked a strong toffee flavor along with what else is going on here, that would have made this nearly perfect.

Somewhat mild aroma with nuts, bread, and a little coffee. Flavor, however, is rich and chocolatey, with some toffee and a fig/date flavor. A little coffee-like bitterness and some alcohol in the finish. I tend to think Avery is a little overrated, but this is outstanding.

Bottle at Craftsman Ale House. Dark chocolate color. No head. Slight spice aroma. Full bodied but slightly bitter start. Smooth finish. Drinkable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Hazy dark brown with a foamy off-white head. Smells of malts, yeast, banana, coffee, and light chocolate. Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, light coffee, nut, and chocolate notes. Medium bodied.

Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is toasted coffee with berry. Taste is berry mixed with a subtle coffee bitterness. The finish is more raspberry and very clean. You can taste and feel the ABV from the start to the finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark brown with an off white head. Lots of caramel and malt. Clove and spices are present. Somewhat bitter which I don't usually like in malty beers. Medium to full bodied. Sweet finish.

The appearance combines a medium off-white head on top of a gorgeous hazy chestnut color, and the aroma blends caramel malts, toasty malts, nuts, and a hint of booze. The taste is mildly sour, slight umami, and slightly sour, but the palate isnt as good of a mixture as the taste; the medium body, slightly boozy finish, slick texture, and average carbonation dont really match the subtle robustness coming from everything else in the beer.
Bottle. Pours a deep brown color with a head that fades. Deep malty chocolate taste with a nutty brown. Not bad. Abv does not appear anywhere
Dark red pour from draft, three fingers of taupe foam. Seasonal spice aroma, slight caramel flavor, slight roast finish. A must try.
12oz bottle poured. Nice dark color and rich aroma. Hints of coffee and a smooth finish.
Poured at Avery. Pours a clear light golden brown color. Has nice amount of head. Has coffee and nuttiness to the flavor. Full flavor in the mouth. Definitely enjoy this beer,

Pours a dark cola brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is smooth heavy malts and prunes. Taste is a well balanced blend of dark roasted, almost chocolatey, malts, prunes, molasses, and a faintly bitter finish. Nice.

Bottle poured a clear dark brown hue w/ a small fully diminishing head and some lacing. Moderate to big roasted malt aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish. Tastes are medium roasted malt, vanilla, rum, and orange citrus. Full bodied and boozy finish.

Bottle pour. Hazy reddish brown color with a light tan head. Aroma is quite yeasty, malty, and light notes of toffee. Taste is diverse; mocha, hazelnut, overall spicy. The finish is very woody and malty. Overall pretty full bodied, a good beer. Hides the 8.3%abv well.

On tap at Avery. Poured a clear chesnut brown with a thin white head. The aroma is rich malt yeast and varnish. The flavour is medium to strong bitter with a big liqourice hop palate. The finish was not the most pleasant bitterness but it was good to taste.
On draft at the Avery tap house. Pours a hazy brown with an off white head. Malty nose. Flavors of caramel, a bit of candi sugar, and toffee. Lingering bitter finish.

Draft sampled at the brewpub. Pours hazy reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma of yeast, dried fruits, apricot, caramel, toffee, raisins, prunes and malt. Flavour is over moderate sweet and bitter. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

On cask at Avery. Pours a hazy brown with very fine, off-white head. Good retention, rings of lace. Aroma is sweet and malty, some spice. Flavor is sweet, fruity, peach, apricot, spice, with a nutty, sweet malt finish, mild toffee. Soft carbonation, medium-light body, very smooth texture. Alcohol is essentially undetectable. Really like the smoothness of the hand drawn version. Tasty, smooth, and strong.

From a 12oz bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy reddish brown with a thin white head. Smells of Carmel, toffee, and maple. Taste is somewhat confused. It has a moderate hop-like bitterness that is a little off and which is retained from the start to the finish and lingers Dow a while thereafter. It tastes a little like cloves and the original formula Listerine, not not I a good way. The alcohol heat is very apparent and doesn't add to the experience. Not a very good example of the style.

Ehhhhhh it's okay, probably not going to get again. It's a little plain, not a very crisp flavor. Good color though.

The Derricks 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark, tastes like molasses and brown sugar. Thin head. Hot from the alcohol. Toffee.

Bottle @ DØE tasting. Pours hazy dark amber with a small offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, nuts, oak, oxidation, little winelike. Flavor is malt, oak, oxidation, coconuts, chocolate, fruits. Medium body, soft carbonation, light warming alcohol. 170713

Bottle @ døe øl smagning, 17 / 7 2013. Dark brown, small white head, some lacing. Aroma, sweet malty, dark fruits, toffee, bread, hay. Taste, malty, toffee, bread, slight alcohol, . Leaves sweet dry toffee aftertaste.

Bottle @ DØE meeting. Clear dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dark fruit and oxidized. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 170713

Pours reddish-brown with soft white head.  Aroma of stone fruit, sweet malt and boozy alcohol.  Taste fruity sweet but dry leaving your tongue with a light oak bitterness.  Overall a complex beer that is good to sip and marvel all of the great flavors.
Tried a bottle of this while visiting Denver.  2012 vintage.  Good nutty winter ale that has some complexity.

Poured into a snifter. 2007 vintage, so somewhere in the 5-6 year old range.

3.5 A: Deep brown borderline black color. Just a short frothy head formed and fell quickly. No lacing. In any case, Im happy about the carbonation level at this point.

4.5 S: Seems that this has aged quite nicely. Still quite potent, but also with smooth, well integrated aromas. Big toastiness, dry caramel, light tobacco, and a pleasant spiciness. Dry overall, but balanced. Not a ton of complexity, but that tends to happen when a beer is aged so long. Despite this, it smells amazing.

4.5 T: Like the nose, its hard to find any problem in the taste. Lots of toastiness, caramel, and dry graininess. No hints of booze at all. Fairly dry, but again, balanced.

4.25 M: Medium body. A little undercarbonated compared to what Id expect fresh, but easily enough for a beer this age. Goes down super easy, but a bit more body and creaminess would be nice.

4.5 D: This drinks like a session beer. So easy to drink. Im furious that I dont have another. Tons of flavor, great balance, and no problems.

Serving type: bottle

04-26-2013 01:29:38

My Bottom Line:
Toasted, caramelized malt flavors are inherently spiced by a rye-like character, while potent wooden hops contribute as much flavor as bitterness in this complex, compelling sipper.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A creamy head of foam covers the cloudy mahogany.
-The spicy character seems to come from grain bill and hops. It even develops a marzipan-like personality at times.
-Fruit cake allusions also appear.
-The rich body is rounded out by alcohol warmth.
-The flavor profile is harmonious throughout.
-The finish is balanced.

Bottle.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours reddish brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of malt, fruit, caramel, and nuts.  Taste is malt, dark fruits, caramel, and molasses.  Nice stuff.

Pours a brown color with a red hue and tan head that leaves good lacing. Smells of caramel, toffee and hazelnut, roasted malt and hazelnut. Tastes of all the same things with molasses and chocolate added. Mouthfeel is heavy and creamy with good carbonation. Overall this was great tasting winter seasonal. Cant wait to see what some ageing does to it.
Reddish brown pour with beige head. Aroma is fruit and caramel. Flavors is fruit, caramel, but, and malt. Finish is clean and bitter.
Aroma is nutty malts, caramel and a hint of fruit/sweetness.  The flavor is caramel, complex malts, a hint of vinous notes and a mildly tart/alcoholic finish.

It poured a dark red/brown color with a tan head. The aroma was heavy on the toffee with hints of molasses, caramel and some pine hops. The taste was of roasted nuts, caramel and some burnt sugar. Not bad.
Pours a stunning dark amber. Muddled nose thats not very fragrant. Flavor is pretty malt forward then after about half of the beer gone the hops spring forward and round out nicely. Very good.
Pours brown with tan bubbles, not much of a head. Smell is toasty. Taste toasty and slightly sweet, some hazelnut and toast. Super smooth, low carbonation, med bodied. Pleasant lasting after taste.

Somewhat mild aroma with nuts, bread, and a little coffee.  Flavor, however, is rich and chocolatey, with some toffee and a fig/date flavor.  A little coffee-like bitterness and some alcohol in the finish.  I tend to think Avery is a little overrated, but this is outstanding.

12 oz bottle cellared for a year (or has it been two? Maybe they should put a vintage on the label, or I should date my beers when I cellar them...). Pours very bright and clear with color of amber resin and beige plush  half-inch head that leaves lacing. Aroma is bready and doughy with a rich portion of molasses, as well as a clove note. Theres rich dark fruit on nose,  followed by toffee and sweetbread flavors (reminiscent of British yeast contributions plus specialty malts like Victory) as well as flour (from oxidation?) ; alcohol presents itself mid-palate, which then melds with hefty balance note of bittering hop finish with some drying. Like a lean old ale, reminds me a of a leaner and much meaner London Pride).

Appearance: Served from a growler via a Unibroue snifter, it has a dark chestnut brown body with some deep red mahogany.  Clear, with a small tan head (no penalty for lack of a decent head given serving type). 

Aroma: Malty with a surprisingly clear hop note.  Very good dark fruit tones with a slight bit of booziness and hints of smoke and hazelnuts.  

Taste: Rich and complex  flavor of mix malts becomes increasingly hoppy into and after the finish.  Hints of figs, dates and raisins. Finishes with a  light bitterness, and a bit too much earthiness for my taste (but suitable for style).

Mouthfeel: Good, albeit rather light, carbonation; smooth; the 8.3% alcohol barely comes through. 

O:  A fine Strong Ale and Winter Warmer.

Aroma is nutty, mocha, toffee, plum. Dark brown, almost nonexistent tan head. Malty sweetness, tootsie roll, lingering fruitcake aftertaste. Very little bitterness. Soft carb, medium body. Overall: this combo of fruity chocolate doesn't really do it for me. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Old Chicago. Pour is toffee in appearance with a tan head and great lacing. Caramel, coffee, toffee, vanilla, grass, graham crackers and spice in the aroma. Taste is vanilla, toffee, dark fruits, light roast, somewhat grassy, raisins, and biscuit with a bitter finish. Somewhat thin mouthfeel with medium carbonation. No alcohol present and quite a lot going on. Not bad.

Pours an amber that is more dark and quite carbonated with a medium beige head.  Aroma offers a holiday feeling.  It has cinnamon, ginger, caramel, and bread.  The taste is somewhat different than the initial impression from the nose.  It is malty and very nutty, if not mostly nutty, with some caramel notes.  There is some slight spiciness here to go along with a bit of yeast.  Medium in body, a chewy texture, with some soft carbonation.  I like this.  It is one of the better Christmas beers that Ive had this year.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2013 2012 Vintage. Pours ruby with a large beige head. Smells nutty and a bit of toffee. Taste is a bit of mocha with some solid toffee and hazelnutty notes. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Avery Old Jubilation finishes with a bittersweet chocolate note.

Pours semitransparent deep copper brown with a small off white head.  Nose is brown sugar, raisins, plums, banana, cloves and vanilla.  Taste is sweet mostly but comes in with some nice bitterness at the end.  Mouthfeel is crisp and clean, the body is medium to heavy and the finish is long.  Very nice.

Tasted from brown bottle into a snifter. Poured a dark reddish brown colour with beige foam, lasting with lace. A very nice big brown holiday beer. Characteristically English malt and hops: sweet grains, brown bread, toast, caramel, toffee, nuts, biscuits, faint coffee and chocolate, some grain bitterness, earthy, tangy citrus zest, apricot-y ale yeast esters. Medium body and carbonation, lingering bittersweet aftertaste. Mild oxidation in a good way, reminiscent of a fine English Old Ale. Somehow sweet and dry, mellow but memorable. Very tasty.
2011 12 oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a small off white head.  Aromas of toffee, burnt sugar, light hazelnut.   Full bodied, smooth, nice

Maybe I wanted more from this. It smelled like roasted honey peanuts and peanut brittle - but the taste was just some light toffee malts and stale hops. Overall pretty good, perhaps a fresher bottle would be better though.
Malty, complex, sweet, and citrusy. Very smooth drinking strong ale. You can tell it is a holiday ale- sweet, brown sugar flavors with a hint of spice, but not too spiced like most tend to be.

Dark mahogony color..bottle pour into snifter..1 finger head..dissipates..aroma is not as noticeable as one might think with this burly winter offering..malt dominant..toffee.mocha..chocolate and roasted nuts..leaves very nice lacing..some coffee notes on finish..very good winter warmer that is a change of pace since it isnt spiced up like most winter offerings..worth seeking out and interested to see what a few years does to this..

Thanks, Harold, for this one. Nose is light caramel and some roast with a light nuttiness to the aroma. Pour is brown with a light tan head. Flavors tended to be full of caramel and toffee with a hint of nuts. Tannic in nature, this one is actually pretty nice.
Tap. Rating #1056. Nice looking brew, dark red. Mild caramel and toffee flavor. Good stuff. (2593)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle. Pours deep mahogany amber with a large tan head that dissipates with decent lacing. Aroma is strong caramel malt. Flavor about the same, lightly sweet, medium kind of unpleasant bitter finish, almost zesty, light tobacco. Medium body. Warming finish.
On tap at Whole Foods. Pours dark reddish brown with tan head. Aroma of leather, chocolate, toffee, nuts, citrus. Moderately bitter and sweet. Full, smooth body. Meh.
Dark amber pour with a tan head. Easy drinking great winter beer. Not as much flavor or spice aroma. Smooth Carmel malt taste.
Tasting alcohol, deep syrup, something burnt, distant smoke & hops. dry finish. Smells like brown bread and brandy. perfect khaki head on dark reddish brown. hope and smoke flavors increase as i sip,

How many ways can you you say dark brown?  Not many.  So we will just refer to this as light black.  Strong roasted aroma of je ne sais quoi.  Target pretense level met.  Enjoyable coffee notes with a stronger than expected nose.  I would encourage friends to give this enjoyable brew a try.  I might order again if I see it on a menu.

Draft - Trapeze Pub - Athens, Georgia
Draft from Ridgeline.  Its and interesting beer.  Its better than it could have been because most spice christmas beers are ruined with to much spice.  Not worth chasing but it was nice for a friday.

On tap at New Bohemia, has a nice fluffy head. Aroma and taste are of artificial hazelnut, it's alright.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A nice warming beer.  Not a whole lot in the nose - maybe a hint of caramel.  Strong malty backbone. I know they say there's no spice in there, but there's just a slight bite of something at the end....something....holiday-ish.

Malty aroma has fruity and subtle woody and nutty notes. Pours a clear chocolate brown with a fairly thick light cinnamon-tan head that doesnt stick around too long but leaves some good lacing. Flavor has a malty core and nutty, caramel and woody hops notes plus a hint of sweet chocolate. Smooth texture has good body and fizz, quite lively. Start the party!
Bottle at craft ale house. Pours clear reddish copper with a small off white head. The aroma malty and nutty. The taste is hazelnut, some chocolate, and some dry nuttiness.

12oz to snifter.  Throw in on a trade from...?  Very dark beautiful ruby brown.  The malts are the star here.  Little bit of hazelnut.  Some bitter hop afterbite. Creamy palate.  Love the absence of spices.  Great beer.

Very tasty stronger ale, but not too bitter. Not a lot of aroma. Had it in a snifter glass, great appearance. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Malty, nutty aroma. Pours medium brown in color, light head. Malty, caramel notes to start with a strong nutty finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A great winter warmer.  Its heavily malted and hopped to get you through the winter.  Great malty taste. American strong ale flavored intermingled with holiday flavors. I havent cellared any of these be cuz they all get drunk before I can get to the cellar.

Bottle. Pours a deep amber with a slight head that dissipated quickly (could be the glass though). Nose  is malty, nutty and toffee. Mouth is full and creamy, malt forward, with some caramelly notes and breadiness, and a quick fade. Considering that this one has virtually no flavoring gimmicks, Im going to say this was an impressive holiday beer. Stacks up well against comparable Xmas ales such as Great Lakes.
Pours a dark reddish amber with a half inch head and good lacing. A nice looking beer. Spicy and slightly nutty. Dry hops and lingering bitterness. Light bodied and thin. Lively carbonation.

Forgoes the spice overload Ive come to expect with holiday ales for a rich, malty, hoppy, full bodied flavor that I loved.  The color is a murky brown, the head fades quickly and leaves very little lacing.  The aroma is warm and rich, and the flavor is big and hearty.  Theres plenty of malt, its bready and slightly sweet, and closes with some punchy hops.  Id buy this year round.
Not what I expect of a winter beer.  Hoppy and no malty flavor.  Wont be purchasing in the future.
Nice ruby appearance with off-white head. Good but generic malty aroma. Decently strong, malty taste, with a lot of english hop flavor. Decent mouthfeel.
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a moderate off-white head. Tiny bit of roasting in the nose, but a strong malty smell. Taste is a tad sweet and a little harsh. Meh.

Dark brown, toasted grain aroma, hazelnuts, hint of coffee, choco. Smooth, more coffee flavor, some hazelnut, slightly boozy aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2013 Pours a mahogany color with a thin lacing of head.  Smells malty and a little of chocolate.  Tastes like it smells.  Medium-bodied and a little sticky mouthfeel.  Sweet and nutty after taste.  An enjoyable strong winter ale.

12oz bottle - pours amber with thin tan head and decent lacing. Nose is cardboard. Flavor adds chocolate, caramel, light smoke and a general malt character that my nose could not detect. Honestly, I was worried until the brew hit my lips. Light to moderate sweetness. Wonderful nutty aftertaste. Hides the 8.3% quite well. Sticky mouthfeel.

Tap at the Stags head.  Pours deep mahogany with thin soapy head.  Nose of dark fruits, caramel, and malt.  You can taste burnt toffee, spruce, leather, earth, plums, brandy, and cough syrup.  lingering on palate
Draft at Farmers Cabinet. Clear dark red pour with a pillowy white head. Bitter sweet chocolate. Raisin pie. Plum pudding. Nice full body. Dark and sweet. Well blended. Full flavors.

Pours clear and brown with a couple fingers of tan and frothy head. Aroma is yeasty with some smoky malts. There are also hints of the mocha and toffee. Taste is even more of the malts without much of the yeast ester overtones. The hazelnut flavor seems to shine through at the beginning and then gives rise to a nice warming alcohol sensation.

One year bottle pours clear reddish dark copper with a little beige suds. The smell is simple malty goodness with a toasted nutty nature. The flavor is rich toffee and a sweet near creamy malt kick. It is slightly grainy but smooth and easy to take large drinks. The hops have mellowed and add a great balance without a lot of flavor, tho some grassy herbal tones come through. Easy medium body with soft carbonation leave a malty drying feel. Towards the end I caught some nice sweet vine fruits too. A nice seemingly simple full flavored brew done well.
Draft. Deep copper red with a short-lived small head. Great winter warmer style beer with a good balance of sweet and bitter and finishes exactly how the style should  great warming feel.

Pours a deep garnet color with a beige head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is subtle. Rummy berries and some wood and caramel malts with a mild alcohol hint. Taste has some cocoa and nuts and dark fruits like plum before a big onrush of toasty grass and alcohol. Nose is highlight. Pretty good.

Draught at the brewery, on October 15, 2012Clear copper color, tan head. Sweet, malty, roasted, hints of pop-corn, light fruity taste. Dry, bitter, grainy aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness. Sweet, malty, roasted scent.

Bottle on a cold, damp night. Pour is chestnut brown with thick off white head and lacing. Scent was coffee, roasted malts, chocolate bar, and grains. Alittle off in aroma. Taste is mocha, burnt toffee, hops and malts. Lightly carbd with a medium to fuller body. Reminded me more of a brown ale then a english style. Just ok.

A-- Poured a dark reddish brown color. One finger head, good lacing and it died quick.

S-- Sweet roasted malts and some carmel.

T-- Bitter at first and then a warming sensation. Nice combination I think.

M-- A little carbonation, a bit heavy. The hops are a bit big but good and you get a little bit of sweet also. Finishes well. 

D-- ABV is there in the warming but a very nice winter warmer on a cold night in front of a fire. A little bigger at 8% but a good beer.

12 oz bottle: Pours a ruby red with a thick tan/white head. Aroma of nutty malts, floral hops and earthy yeast. Taste is smooth, dark brown ale flavor and has mellowed since purchase 6 months ago. Very smooth and easy to drink, would buy again but age first in the future. I still have one and will let it age another 6 months before tasting.
Thanks again to cheap for this gem.  A definite winter beer.  Yuo can taste the 8%abv., gives you a warming feeling.  Good balance and complexity.

This was probably the 2010 version. There is nothing on the bottle to indicate the year though. The label is a little different than the picture here; has the brewery logo at the bottom on the label.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Nice dark brown color, almost opaque. An inch head formed but quickly faded.

Smell: Overall a very light scent. Some malty smell...

Taste: Theres a great balance between the malt and hops here. Neither really come out ahead, but they complement each other well. A short sweet finish. This is one of the few winter seasonals that I have had that does not have an array of the "Christmas spices" in its flavor. I like it.

Palate: Medium going toward heavy body. Almost no carbonation. A good weight for a winter warmer.

A good beer. I am enjoying sipping it on this (finally) cold night. I will probably have one more from the 6-pack and save the others for the next few years. Avery says that they can be cellared for a couple years so we will see if anything changes with time.

Coffee-like roast aroma.  Brown complexion.  Incredible chocolate meets brown ale flavors and excellent bitter hop finish.

Notes: Brewery visit during 09 GABF

On tap at RNH. Pour is dark red/brown with an averaged sized tan head. Aroma is heavy on the toffee with hints of molasses, caramel, and pine hops. Flavor is of roasted nuts, caramel, and burnt sugar. Pretty good, some bitterness to balance out the massive malt.

From notes: Poured deep chestnut brown, with a 1-finger bone-colored head.  Aroma was roasty, mixed with caramel sweetness.  Medium-thick with a mild depth but a fairly long finish.  Flavor was caramelly sweet, with spicy and roasty notes inthe finish.

Shifter from bottle. A: ginger, cinnamon, brown sugar, dark carmel. App: amber-brown, one finger, quickly dispersing head. T: very malty, dark, brown malts, slightly sweet, and a toffee and coffee/espresso flavor rolling through the back. P: smooth, smooth, with a chocolate-espresso aftertaste.

aged two years, brown color, aroma of chocolate, toffee, caramel, flavors of chocolate, coffee, caramel, marshmallows, med to full body, creamy and smooth, really enjoyed this one, much better with age

Forgot how good this was, got one out of the cellar, about a year and a half of age on it. Very roasty malt aroma and flavor, hints of marshmellow and nutty, slighty sweet finish. Thats is all, have a good night.

Bottle; Dark Brown, Amber hue, with a modest fine bubbled khaki head in this glass. Decent retention, and some nice lacing here. The nose is nice; caramel, toffee, nuttiness here. There is a bitterness out of the gate; fruit esters, cream,  nuttiness, caramel, toffee notes. This is a nice one overall ; its not the most refined brew ive ever had, but its a nice one.

Bottle pours brown with an off white head. Aromas of caramel and molasses and brown sugar. Tastes similar. A touch of sweetness. No hoppiness to speak of. Lasting impressions of brown sugar. A decent beer

Pours a dark reddish brown with a short head. Spotty lacing.  Smell is dry, alcoholic, and with stone fruit and apples. Taste is very dry, and a little sharp with alcohol. Hops are quite strong and bitter. Light mouthfeel.

aroam, nutty, and deep malts open into nose some toffee, color, deep reddish hue, white head, taste, was really surprised, very malty, the brew takes on a coffee, toffee, type taste very rich with a mild semi sweet chocolate aftertaste, overall, neat brew really warms you up!
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: On tap at HopCat, Grand Rapids, MI.  We have a winner!  Of the 9 beers I sampled at HopCat, this was the favourite.  Deep brown with a perfect creamy head.  Creamy and malty aroma.  Taste is sweet toasted marshmallows, with a dry bitter finish, and a hint of alcohol.  Smooth full body.  Great stuff.
Very oxidized. And its off a keg. Oxidation of the nose and on the tongue. Not a good beer. Some sweet caramel, which is its only redeeming quality.
Pours deep and dark with slight head that laces the glass.  The site calls it English old ale but reminds me more of a spiced christmas ale, or even the taste of a porter although it is an ale.
Lush, dark fruit-driven aroma, raisins & figs, holiday spice, coffee, cola. Bit creamy, weighty, bittersweet, bit sharp on the finish, warming, decent holiday beer.

12 oz single from "Lifesource" S.Salem. $1.99
I havent rated the beers I have had from Avery very highly maybe this will change as it is one of my favourite styles.
Tawny red ale with a small light tan head and plenty lace.
Aroma of milky bar chocolate and some caramel, some nuts,,hazelnuts,
Smooth taste of coffee and cream, hazelnuts,white chocolate,figs and some whisky fudge.
Mouthfeel is pretty nice, gives the impression of fullness but its actually very drinkable
I liked it but again its not as good as i wanted it t be.
Maybe the bottles just dont travel to Oregon very well
UPDATED: JAN 10, 2012 On Tap @ Hopcat. Dark semi clear red frothy off white head. Caramel,light coffee notes, light nose. Thick, woody, coffee, almost a stout. Great beer.

(bottle).  Nice chestnut complexion and mild nutty malt aroma   Flavor has similar characteristics.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Pours mahogany with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is sweet with notes of dark fruit, roasted malts and some flowery hops.  Slightly sweet flavor with dark fruits, caramel and roasted malts.  Hints of toffee and chocolate.  Slightly hoppy finish.
medium sweetness, lightly bitter, red, brown, clear, medium body, soft carbonation,

12 oz bottle.  Rating #1000 for this!  Deep, clear orange brown with off-white suds.  Nose is caramel, raisin, dates and brown bread, a bit musty.  Almost full body, sticky, kind of cloying with a tang.  Taste is raisin, grape jelly, fortified scotch whiskey and bitter almond.
Nice looking medium brown hue with small head. Not fruity. The varied hops and malts do provide an interesting flavor though.

12oz bottle. Clear copper color, minimal cream-colored head. Webby on the surface. Decent lace. Very drinkable, light carbonation. Gets substantially better after sitting a bit. Typical christmas spices. A decent christmas that improves after it warms. Nothing particularly outstanding or unique, however.
Rich brown in color, with a medium-sized head. Both hoppy and malty. Some caramel and toffee notes.

Aromas of rich, roasted malt and raisins rises off a crystal clear medium/dark copper body with a slight ruby tinge topped by a light tan head.  The raisins follow the aroma into the taste along with a wooden dryness and light sourness.   Theres a good earthy bitterness to counter the sweetness.  Finishes with the wood flavor and light sourness along with caramel.  Great winter brew!
Dark color with a medium sized head. Smell of figs and dark fruits. Taste is smooth with roasted fruits like prunes and figs. Also some licorice. Nice finish.

Arome of toffee, coffee, vanilla, malty.  Dark brown color tan head  .   Flavor of roasted malt, bitter chocolate, coffee, sweet malt.  Creamy palate, low cabination.  Overall great holiday beer   reminds me of arm wrestling matches and knife fights in siberia
Love this beer...great for the holidays! Bread aroma and taste. Malty flavor with a dark amber color. Nice lacing and alcohol is hidden well. Next six pack I am going to cellar.
Dark caramel-colored pour. Very smooth, slight dark chocolate bitterness and no spice. Caramel malty finish with hint of alcohol, minimal carbonation. Very good seasonal.

Poured a copper brown color, medium head.  Aroma of caramel and cocoa, hazelnut and some sweet candy.  Med bitter, med light sweet.  Soft carbonation, medium body.  Creamy texture.  Yum, this is one of the better xmas beers Ive had.  Smooth but packs a mouthful of flavor and alcohol.  Would get again.

Pours dark brown with thin tan head, spicy and nutty aroma, some fruits. Taste is nice, some toffee malt notes and hints of dark fruits and cinnamon, it also has a nice kind of sprucey hop bite too. Cellaring 2 other bottles, will update later
Bottle. Light tan head, murky dark brown. Lots of ginger and cinnamon, and dark fruits. Dark fruit plum and light spice in flavor. Medium to heavier body.
Bottle. Brownish colour with white head. Nutty spicy aroma. Taste is like a brown ale with a bit of spice. Not bad.

On tap at Petrol Station. Pours a clear amber brown with a deep gray head that dissipates to the edges and laces nicely. Aroma has notes of caramel and sweet grain with a hint of backing toffee. Flavor begins with a hint of bread and grains and finishes with sweet grains, a bit of hops and toffee.

8 Dec 2011, bottle. medium nut brown color, clear, no bubbles, thin frothy head nutty bread up front with a blue cheese aroma that comes through a bit. Wow. lots in the mouth. tree bark, coffee, faint blue cheese, some raisins. alcohol isnt real noticeable in nose or mouth. pretty good.

"Its the most wonderful... kind of a beer." I think this is last years vintage, no date on the bottle. Full and enticing aromas of prunes, burnt toffee, sherry, and wood smoke. On the tongue, its full and brown and prune and toffee. After a year(?) the hops are quite subdued but still noticable in a piney sorta way. One of my favorite examples of one of my favorite styles.
Dark fruit, chocolate and toffee notes with a boat load of malts.  Light floral hops.  No spices.  Plenty of dark robust flavors, but not overpowering and a pleasure to drink.
The aroma is earthy, caramel.  The appearance is deep amber, white head.  The flavor is like the aroma.  The finish is pine and citrus hops./  Medium to medium/thick in body.  Quite good.
Draft courtesy of the Churchkey crew, thank you gentlemen!  Very dark maroon color, medium beige head.  Aroma of caramel.  Taste is sweet and peppery.  OK.

Bottle into Chimay glass.

Pours a dark mahogany with very minimal head. 

Can detect faint hints of cherry in the aroma. Mostly fruit. 

Rich, full flavor. Malty backbone. Almost nutty flavor. 

Very smooth and drinkable. 

Overall, a very good winter ale.

Very nice. Like a Scottish Wee Heavy. Very malty sweet with a thick feel. The pour is clear reddish amber with a small head. Bread and yeast along with roast malts dominate the aroma and the flavor is similar. Nice warming finish. A winter beer for sure.

Tap at Churchkey thanks to Travlr. Pours a deep red/mahogany with ridiculous lacing all over the place. Red fruit and Twizzler nose...what is up with these Avery beers? Sticky, starchy, artificial red candies. Taste is quite bland, lots of stickiness, mild alcohol heat. Not sure what is going on...but it seems to be a miracle that Avery was able to make a beer as good as Meph Addict with all these underattenuated sugar bombs on deck.
Si je peux ajouter des éléments à la description faite par Avery, ce serait au niveau du profil très fruité, pomme rouge, pruneau. Jaime beaucoup lagencement sucré assez étoffé.

Theres a light brown color in the pour and a full, dull (in a good way), flavor that would probably go extraordinarily well with tobacco.  I really liked that it was a  flavor-packed holiday brew without those pesky spice elements.

Medium reddish-amber with an impressive head and lacing.  Looks good.  Roasted caramel malt with a curious bitter edge, moves into a semi-sweet chocolate with a hint of spice.  I expected a much bigger mouth full.  Good for a repeat, but not great.
Toffee malty aroma... Mahogany in color... Flavor is sweet and caramel toffee initially with oak and scotch on the finish... Very nice

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2011 Very lively beer though I suspect it is nearing two years since bottling. Big tan head tops the color of malaise era brown Detroit iron. Woody, grainy aroma. Brewers description of hazelnut and toffee flavors is spot on. Chocolate finish, probably a factor of age. Thick, heavy bodied. Great for a cold night.

Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, malt and just a hint of pine.  Pours deep dark red with a medium sticky head.  Taste is wild.  Roasted hazelnuts, some pine, and butterscotch round this out yet it is deifinitely on the bitter side.  Very complex and unique.  I like it!
Bottle.  Mahogany pour with a red tint.  Aroma is of strong malts.  Taste is of strong burnt caramel malts and some bitterness.  Medium to heavy body.  Medium carbonation.

Pour is dark with a fair sized head. Nose is of caramel and malts mostly. Taste is of a bitter finish, with some deep malty flavors up to caramel in the taste with a slight hint of a booze in the finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours root beer brown with a small beige head that falls into a skiff of foam fairly quick; leaves some lace. Aroma is all bready malts, not much else; some roasty nuttiness and dark fruit come through as it warms up. Taste is a little sweet, a little bitter, a little tart; nice and roasted woody flavor. Hands down one of the best winter warmers Ive ever had.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2012 Pours dark, with moderate head and aroma. Aroma is mostly malt, nutty and roast notes. Flavor is a balance of hops and malt, with some distinct roasted and carmel flavor. Finishes balanced. Nothing particularly stands out here, its all about balance. When cellared, it loses the roasted flavor, and the malt comes through more. A good winter ales, but maybe a little busy. Still a solid favorite that I need to revisit annually.

Pours a light, almost clear black with a fair tn head and some lace.  Aroma is of malts, nuts, bread and a little caramel.  Interesting flavor, some carb, roasted malts, a little chocolate, caramel and a tiny bit of alcohol in the finish.  Overall pretty good, definitely save some for Christmas.
12oz bottle. Poured a dark ruby color with a small white head. Aroma is caramel notes, bready, malt heavy. Flavor has notes of chocolate, sweet fruity malts. Enjoyed this one.

Beautiful dark red mahogany color with a thick crown of tan foam. Nose is caramel and malt. Very creamy mouthfeel. Flavor profile is a rich nectar of carmelized malts, molasses, toffee and just a hint of hops at the finish to prevent cloying. An excellent ale - one worth a lot of jubilation. Can be enjoyed alone or with roasted nuts. Nice job, Avery!
