pours mahogany with a light head.  rich smell of toffee and a bit of chocolate.  excellent blend of roasted malts.  a tad sweet with some alcohol warming.  excellent winter beer.  i need to stock up on this one.
Pours a dark copper-red. Very strong and flavorful, sweet, malty, and spicey with a strong taste of alcohol.

Draft. Pours deep mahogany brown with a beige head. light toasted malty aroma with some bready notes. The flavor has toasted malts, very light roast, bread crust, cocoa powder, and light earthy notes. Pretty good.

12 oz. bottle from SoHo Organic Market.  Dark brown pour with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of hazelnut and light chocolate.  The taste is really nice; rich mocha and roasted coffee with a nutty and toffee-like finish.  Not quite a brown ale yet also not quite a porter, this one is really unique.  As a side note my bottle says this is cellarable for 3+ years rather than 2 years that the commercial description states on this site at the time of my review.  I have tried previously a 1 year old bottle that I thought was horrible.  I may have to reconsider given my good fortune with this bottle.
12oz bottle pours a dark amber with a thin off-white head. Aroma of toffee, hazelnut, and caramel malts. Nice hop bitterness surrounded by nutty and caramel flavors. Clean and refreshing. Nice!

On tap last night at RnH with James and Streets. Going from my notes, my main complaint with this one was that it was somewhat watery and lacked a real backbone or substance. Chocolate was the predominant flavor.
Draft at rattle with Brendan streets and baron. Pours a deep amber with white placing. Aroma is spicy fruit. Mouthfeel is thin to medium with notes of sweet malts.

Bottle. Pours a crimson-hued dark brown color with solid tan head. The aroma blends caramel and bready malts with brown sugar and walnut liqueur. The taste is toasted malt, toffee and butterscotch at the start with raisins and figs in the middle and some caramel and alcohol at the end. Mouthfeel is mildly creamy with soft carbonation and a roasted malt finish with some rum in the aftertaste. Overall, a respectable Winter Warmer with plenty of malt flavors to savor.

On tap at J Clyde. Pours a dark brown with a small head and good lacing. Nose in hoppy with a little sweetness. Taste is the same, complex...bitterness is well balanced with sweetness. Medium mouthfeel, medium carbonation. No alcohol burn, I wish there was more. That would really take this "winter warmer" over the top for me.

Pours clear and chestnut with a thin white head and thready lace.  nose is heavy with hazelnut and raisin.  Distinct notes on the tongue with firery alcohol, allspice, toast, and fruit cake.  Well balanced and wintery.

Draft at Avery Taphouse. Pours light brown with a half inch of off-white foam. Not much on the nose. A bit of nutty roastedness on the tongue. English Strong Ale is not exactly my favorite style and this isnt doing much to persuade me.

Pours clear dark brown. Medium aroma of caramel & a little coffee. Lots of roasted coffee on medium-bodied palate that is very well balanced. Lingering finish is slightly bitter but with a good malt presence.

Bottle from 2010. Pours deep reddish brown with very creamy tan head, aroma is full of raisin, toffee, figs, some spice, touch of cocoa, very complex and layered. Taste is just as delicious with notes of bitter aged hops, some toffee, dark fruit and spice notes intermingle and lead into slight chocolate, finished with lots of deep toffee, molasses, and bitter.

Holy smokes what an awesome tasting ale and the more it warms up the better it gets!! Hold your horses boys as this one is a sipper. The flavors are very complex and very fulfilling. The texture is very full and very rich. Although it is brewed for the winter season it can be enjoyed all year long; even in this Texas heat! If I had to choose a brew to have as a night-cap, this would be the one!

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Dark amber with thin tan head and light lacing lines.

Aroma: Big English malt smell: semi-sweet caramel and dark fruit predominately, with a slight touch of English hops.

Taste: Very malty and slightly sweet upfront with caramel and dark fruit evident. The English hop bitterness builds and lets its presence known long after each sip. Some alcohol becomes noticeable as it warms.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium somewhat creamy body, with a very dry English finish.

Overall: A big, full flavored beer that is a showcase for both English malts and English hops.
Malt caramel and dark malts, dark fruits are all over the flavor profile. There is a good amount of bittering from hops that is needed, actually adds an interesting depth to the beer. I like it.

Deep reddish copper pour with bubbly, thin cream-colored head. Clean malt aromas with nuts and toffee. Flavor is hoppy and bright, with toffee, citrus and ripe plum notes. Very clean beer, with a good hop bitter finish.

Served in a Bruery tulip.

The color is a moderate brown with a crimson hue. Pours with a single-finger off-white head as well as some light lacing and a bit of bubbly lacing around the edges of the glass. The nose brings some light caramel, toffee, and citrus plus a bit of spicing.

The flavor brings some mild hops with a bit of earth and citrus as well as some caramel. There some slight spicing and a bit of booze in there as well. The body is nice with a bit of booze and is a bit thinner than expected, but has a good amount of carbonation to carry the flavors. Drinkability is decent. This is a well-made brew, but just doesnt really stand out in any direction.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-28-2010

Draft served in a tulip at The Stable. Pours a deep, cloudy amber color with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel malts, plums, figs, dates, brown sugar, and spices. Flavor of caramel malts, brown sugar, the same fruits as in the nose, and chocolate. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a malty, fruity mouthfeel. A lot like a barleywine. Good balance, nice sipper.

2009 keg @ redlight redlight for Barley Wine Fest.  Malty aromas on the nose with molasses and spicy hops.  Pours a reddish amber with a thick white head.  Malty with a thick mouthfeel, toffee with spicy hops notes.  Very nice sipper.

On tap.

This one is rich and creamy with a HUGE wallop of dark fruits that just punches you int he face. This is along with some mild toasty bitterness and some thick caramel and sugary flavors.

12oz bottle.
Reddish brown color with a decent amount of white head.  Smells of caramel, dark fruit, and some spice - slightly sweet with some chocolate and toffee flavors.
Best winter seasonal ale Ive had in a very long time. The aroma and finish are are memorable and very pleasing

On tap at the Meddlesome Moth, Dallas. It pours a deep ruby-brown colour with small foamy beige head. The nose is fairly subtle - red berries, nuts and caramel. The taste is date, raisin, plum, leather, oak, liquorice, nuts, varnish, a little honey and some lemon sherbet with an astringent-bitter finish. The overall taste is quite dry and bit too savoury, making it quite difficult to finish.

Caramel with sweet chocolate appearing faintly on the nose.  Slight graininess.  Clear, deep ruby pour with pillowy white head that leaves nice lacing.  Caramel and breadiness blend seemlessly on the taste.  Slight alcohol warmth on the finish.  Without notice, hop bitterness dries the palate.  Medium body with mild carbonation.  Great winter beer that you would enjoy one after another in front of a fire.

12oz bottle.  Pours a very dark amber color with a light tan head that fades into a nice amount of lace.  Aromas of dark fruits and rum-soaked raisins and just a bit of molasses.  Taste starts with notes of plums and raisins and a touch of brown sugar, followed by some unsweetened chocolate. A roasted nuttiness comes through before some drying alcohol finishes the taste.  A good seasonal thats not over spiced, very well balanced.

This poured a reddish brown color with an off white head. Aroma was light nuts, tasoted malt and some caramel. Flavor was very smooth, light spices, nutty and roasted just right. An ok beer but a great offering for the style.
Tap @ Blue Nile. Nice dark mahogany pour with a pillowy off-white head. Aroma of nuts, caramel, roasty, raisin, and dark fruit. Flavor to match.
Had at Belgian with Justin. Pour is a darker thin clear caramel. Little head. Aroma is bits of chocolate and coffee. Mild nutty flavor with dark malts and spice.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a dark amber/red with an off white head and lacing through out the glass, aroma is sweet with malt, hints of dark fruit and caramel, flavor is roasty with touches of chocolate in the finish, its has a tad of a dry finish but is overall enjoyable.
Red-brown pour with a beige head. Nice malty aroma , little nutty, little hops. Great malt taste-roasted malt with a nice malt aftertaste. Very good beer> Nice lacing

Pours mahogany with small beige head.  Aroma is spices, caramel, raisin/pear and roastyness.  Taste is sweet with carmel coming through on first taste and the more acidic pear on the finish.  Very smooth and a nice warming sensation.

Tap: Brown, not clear color.  The brew has a strong bite of alcohol, furniture polish and a little wet cardboard.  Aromas are sweet, molasses, brown sugar and malts.  Bitter sweet flavors.  Very tasty.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2011 Pours a dark cola color.  Aroma is beery and malty.  Flavor is malty and of alcohol and burnt flavors as well as a hint of licorice.  Good stuff... a nice holiday brew.

On Tap at Brewforia Beer Market in Meridian, ID.  The pint glass was very full but still has a nice creamy tan head.  Nutty and malty aroma woth plenty of caramelized and pitted fruit flavors.  Molasses and woody brown sugar flavors, with a little hop IBUs to counter it.  A lightened barley Wine and a nice winter warmer. The robust ABV was apparent but not center stage or boozy.   Rather softly carbonated and a moderate to full palate. 
Nice.
One of my favorite fireplace beers. Caramel, brown sugar, dried fruit,  and coffee come to mind. Hops is just about right. Doesnt overpower the beer, but you know it is there. Big beer. Excellent.

A very nutty smell and taste with a heavy aftertaste.  The color is a nice light mahogany and the pour is nice and clean with a small head.  A good holiday brew which goes perfect with a cold winter night!

12 oz bottle. Dark mahogany brown with a small creamy beige head. Aroma of toast, chocolate, nuts and caramel. Flavor is very malt but not overly sweet, the toasty and nutty malt is dominate with a light bitterness and no alcohol flavor. Medium body with mild carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. This is a really nice beer, very rich and smooth but not overpowering. Great drink ability for an 8%er.

solid winter warmer; much aroma - malts and spices (couldnt identify) brown pour - taste was malty sweet and there were some spices but just unable to identify - hops at the end;  a little too sweet and hoppy but still a good brew for the winter...
Mahogany with lacy whitish head. Aroma of toasted and caramel malts, cinnamon and a little sugar. Taste is malty sweet, but not at all too much in any way. Nice body, nice warmer.

12 oz. bottle, pours dark amber. Aroma of English malts and sweet dried fruits. The flavour reveals much more complexity, with the aforementioned English malts and sweet dried fruits, along with prominent wood and hazelnut. A little cloying in sweetness, but this is a great winter warmer.

12 oz. bottle- Pours dark brown to red with a thin head, it also pours clear with no sediment, the aroma is old barnyard, some sort of nut, and even some tart cherry. The flavor is somewhat bitter upfront and throughout actually, with some mocha flavors. It has a malty smoothness to it but the hops do dominate, it says it can be aged, so I actually think this would be better if I could have waited until next winter to review this, but I have no willpower sometimes. The hops do mellow as it sits and warms and the alcohol gives off this warming feeling, so the beer does get a bump up in overall- was 14 and now is 15

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2014 Pours a very dark brown with a small creamy head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel malts, barley hops and maybe some brown sugar. Taste is very christmas-like with dates, prunes, nuts and some spices. Also it is a bit yeasty, and have some barley-wine stuff going on in it too.

Pours a mahogany with thin tan head.  Aroma is roasted nutty malts with hints of cocoa.  Flavor is strong roasted malts, coffee, with a nice dry bitterness on the finish.  This one is a bit heavy on the palate but has a crisp bite.  The alcohol is hidden well which makes this drinkable.  Has a slight resemblance to a scotch ale.  Very good winter seasonal.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2011 Bouteille 1 an vieillie 12-12-10: Brune foncée avec teinte cuivrée, légère effervescence, limpide et mousse éphémère. Arômes de biscuits, de céréale avec notes de chocolat et pain dépices. Légèrement sucré, avec une amertume a peine perceptible. Très maltée. Corps moyen, avec une texture asser crémeuse et riche. Saveurs de malt, de biscuits des fêtes, de chocolat, avec des notes dépices. Finale asser longue sur le theme de malt et chocolat.
27-12-11 Bouteille 2 ans vieillie: Même teinte, mousse abondante et crémeuse. Sans effervescence. Légers arômes de métal.Toujours pleine de saveurs, riche et crémeuse et très maltée. Vraiment délicieuse.
lots of chocolate malt with some charcoal undertones. leafy hops. bready yeast. theres a lot of everything, but it is balanced well.

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber/brackish color with a decent-sized tan head that lingers around for a while.  Aromas of spice and malt.  Analogous flavors w/ a bitter, roasted edge.  Medium to heavily bodied but finishes easy.  Spicy aftertaste and you can certainly feel it going down all the way to your guts.  A good brew.
This was one of the best winter seasonals i have had this year. Nice malty flavor with no spices as the label says. Enjoyable.

12 oz bottle that has been in my larder since Thanksgiving 2008. Time to drink up! I poured this into a snifter, where it seemed surprisingly carbonated. Its thin head faded quickly, but the visible carbonation reasserted itself in a surprisingly light body. Not surprisingly, the age has taken the bite out of the stronger flavors in this ale. A powerful aroma of molasses remained, but the flavor had stronger elements of nuts, carbonation, and boozy fruitcake. Both the punchy aroma and the fizzy body confirm my memory that this had sharp edges when it was new. I prefer the more mature version and judge this t be well worth the wait, especially at the price.

The beer pours a medium brown color with an off-white head. The aroma is a mix of chocolate, toffee and some nutmeg. The flavor is more complex. I get some chocolate and toffee, but I also get anise, coffee, cinnamon, roasted malt and some alcohol. Full mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice winter warmer.

Poured red/brown with a small egg-white head. Aroma: malt, hops grain. Taste was very much the same. Thinnish body. Overall: not one I would buy again. It is not a bad beer, just not for me. I can not say I picked-up on too much of what the other rates state. May have had a bad bottle or I just had a beer too many before I tried this.

Clear, dark reddish brown pour, large, loose off-white head.  Aroma is malty, nutty, with caramel and slightly roasted notes.  The flavors of this hit you sharply with more bitterness than expected: toffee, slightly charred roast with some coffee, brown bread, nuts.  Finishes with a pretty hard hit of alcohol heat.  This is a pretty good english strong, if a bit harsh.

Pours a resemblance of cherry wood, with a thin, but white lacing around the edges of the glass. Rich aromas of toffee, dark fruit, and  mocha are prevalent.  The flavor brings forth the taste of alcohol and a robust maltiness that is highly complex in nature, with a hint of astringency. All-embrassing this is a superlative winter english strong ale.
Pours brown with creamy off-white head and foamy lacing.  Notes of caramel and spruce.  Hop taste overpowers malt for a bitter finish.

Pours clear, reddish-brown with a thin, frothy, white head with light lace. Nose of plum, raisin, cedar, malt, and a hint of barnyard and sour cherry. Thin mouthfeel. Taste of bitter coffee, vanilla bean, toffee, malt, booze and smoke. This is a medium hot brew in that the alcohol is present on the finish.  Enjoyable for the style. I might enjoy more if cellared for a year.
Bottle. Clear dark brown with reddish tint and a small tan head. Malt, smoke, and alcohol aroma. Flavor of nutty roasted malt, spice, and a slight bitter finish. Medium bodied.

Pours a very dark brown with garnet highlights and tan head.  Aromas of caramel, apple, chocolate, and nutmeg.  Taste is medium sweet with flavors following aromas with additional notes of berries and earthiness.  Full body with creamy texture and soft carbonation.  Rich, delicious, balanced, and drinkable; reminiscent of some doppelbocks but with more substantial hopping.
Draught from peculier pub.  Poured dark brownish reddish with creamy head. Aroma is some cinnamon and a hint of cherry.  Mild hops finish.
UPDATED: DEC 19, 2012 Great beer.  Everything I want in a holiday ale.  Not a lot new to say that others have, except Im a fan.

Tasted on tap at the brewery in Boulder.  Dark red/orange appearance with a light head.  Sweet alcoholic aroma.  Pretty intense English Strong Ale flavor at first.  Somewhat malty body thats slick in mouthfeel like an Old Ale or a Barleywine.  Definitely alcoholic flavor.

(12oz bottle).  Pours clear mahogany with thin off-white head.  Light carbonation.  Aroma of wood, candied sugar, nuts.  Taste is semi-sweet with quite a bit of roasty bitterness.  Medium bodied with oily texture. Finish is bitter and hot.   Not a good beer, imo.

Malt and toffee aroma.  Deep copper color, a little hazy.  Medium carbonation... spices come through, but you can tell its not a spiced beer.  Good, complex flavor.... a little sweet, but complemented with bitterness.

Alright, Ive had a couple new Wisconsin beers lately, and a couple Colorados as well. Thats always a good sign. 

Old Jubilation is a tough beer, tried and true I suppose. 8% alcohol, and a horrid brown color like diarrhea. Its like the WWII veteran of beers. Tastes old and awful as well.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Light brown with dusty tan head, like crema.  Smells of caramel with a tad bit of hops and nuts, slight hazelnut flavored coffee beans.  Flavor is a uniform light caramel that comes across slightly nutty, with a moderately harsh, lingering alcohol and bitterness in the background.  Definitely on the syrupy side of things.  A watered down barley wine.  Update: 12/18/10: On draft at Shadys, the hops appeared to be much more interesting to me this time around with some berry flavors that mingled with the toffee found in the beer.  Draft version rating is a 3.8.

Toasty, slightly peppery, sweet aroma, with honey, biscuit, and doughy notes. Smooth, with toffee, nutty flavors and moderate hop bitterness. Mildly sweet, though out of the bottle it retains some of the metal from the cap. Best from a tulip.
This is the newer 8.3% batch. Poured from bottle, rich and warm brown with very little head. Wonderful aroma. Whoa, very nutty taste...I feel like I am eating peanuts. I hate peanuts.
Pours a nice dark amber with a nice head.  Nice aroma of malt, spices and a nice hop balance.  Taste is medium bodied with a good malt/hop balance.  Its a little hot, but its nice for a winter.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2011 Six pack from Dorothy Lane, deep copper with modest head  and chocked full of Malts and Hops.  Nice roasted malt aromas, and lingering sweet flavors.  Dessert flavors like vanilla and cookies in the middle.
Dec 2011 on Tap at fat Jeads and just as good with hops more noted.

Bottle.  First off, just gonna point out that I think this newest batch is slightly different from the older ones.  Theyve bumped up the abv a bit from 8% to 8.3%, and with that Im sure has come a change in the overall taste.  That out of the way, wow this is a damn fine seasonal!  Pours a ruby, amber color with a small head thats quick to leave.  The aroma is slightly sweet with hints of toffee and fruit.  Tastes of roasted malt, slight chocolate, some nuts and some toffee.  The finish is sweet with a hint of bitterness at the end.  So impressions.  Its a very solid winter seasonal, and quite a bit different from what I was expecting from Avery.  This is actually one of my new favorites from them.  The woody hints at the end, and the roasted malts go well with the slight hop bitterness and I think this beer has a great balance overall.  Glad I grabbed a couple of bottles of this instead of just one!  Ill be on the lookout for this again, and so should everyone else!  8.3% alcohol.

Not bad; strong, very complex and interesting palate, though aroma is surprisingly "standard" with some off-putting stale odors; caramel is a dominant taste, with enough hops to make it less than satisfying despite the high ABV and layered maltiness

2010 Edition.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a nonic pint glass.

Appearance: Pours dark cherry wood color with ruby highlights and a 1 finger creamy light tan head. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Sweet and earthy malts with a touch of fruit and spice. Theres also a slight bitterness that I cant quite decipher. Aroma is a bit lighter than I expected.

Taste: Sweet malt up front followed by mild dark fruits in the middle and ending with an astringent dark leafy bitterness at the finish. Aftertaste is bitter toasted malt. The flavor is not well-balanced, in my opinion.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. The alcohol warmth is missing so I wouldnt consider this a winter warmer.

Drinkability: Okay drinkability. The harsh flavor keeps me from wanting another.

Overall: Average beer overall. There are better options available in this style.

Beer poors deep amber with a ring of head that stays throughout the beer.  Aroma is of Alchol, piney, citrus, and malty.  Flavor is sweet, malty, and balanced by a mild bitterness.  Mouthfeel is excellent for style.  Not too sticky, just right for desiring more.  Overall the beer is an excellent winter warmer, look forward to more.

Didnt have much idea about what to expect on this one.... Actually thought it was going to lean more toward the golden side of things but turned out to be an English style ale.  Low carbonation, and a head that didnt last longer than a sneeze.  Nice mouthfeel, not too smooth.  Good amount of hops, kind of like an old war wound.  They just stick around.  Theres plenty of independent notes to this ale, which makes it the character deep.  The only note that didnt feel right was the copper one while it was on the tongue.  I could see how this would be excellent aged.  The score would probably go up higher then.
I though this was a fantastic beer for the winter months.  Off the tap at the brewhouse.  Nice and warm with malty tones.  Ill purchase more of this for sure.

12oz btl. The pour is a great looking clear mahoganey rust hue with a nice finger of frothy white head. Subtle sweet malty aroma. Big smooth mouthfeel flavors of toffee (for sure) and undertones of dark friut. That sweet flavor continues into a a crisp bitterness and that evens out into a nice lasting finish. Maybe Im just pumped to be drinking a Christman ale but I loved this one.

Pours a dark black color with a tiny white head and lots of lacing. Either the aromas are very muted or my nose is stuffy but I cant smell much unless I really try. All Im really getting from the nose is roasted malt. The taste is bitter burnt wood, sweet roasted malts, and a little alcohol. Good to warm you up on a cold night but I wouldnt have more than one. Not my cup of tea.

bottle.  Pours deep amber mahogany with beige, slightly tan head which persists with nice bubbles and lacing.  Aroma of pumperknickle, toffee, hazelnut.  Malty flavor exhibits notes of toffee and caramel, with a sort of dark roasted bread aspect to the finish.  Very smooth, creamy mouth feel, with the 8% completely masked.  Its hard for me to really accurately describe whats going on in this beer but it is great, one of averys finest.  As the beer warms theres almost a fruitiness, dark fruits. Very nice to sip on on a cold windy day like this.

Notes from Thursday, October 03 2010
On tap at Avery tap house.

Ar: Toffee, chocolate dominate along with some hazelnut.
Ap: Medium brown-red, little head, medium lace.
T: Lots of hazelnut with a bit of toffee.  Lightly hoppy finish.
P: Medium body, medium carbonation.

O: Highly enjoyable strong ale.

On tap @ Avery Brewery. See through dark brown like a brown ale, ivey fluffy head, great lacing. Smells of hazelnuts, toffee, and sweet malts. Taste is sweet and strong. I get lots of woody and nutty flavors combined with toffee and cocoa. Hints of holiday style spicing as well. Not bad!
Pours a dark ruby red with off-white foam, slight coffee nose. Tastes sweet with an almost pepermint aftertaste mixed with roasted nuts. Weird combination.

On tap at South Park Tavern, Dayton, OH.   Poured a nice  amber, thick color with tan head. Good full bodied beer just a bit heavy for me on a super hot October day..   Good winter offering though with nice caramel and nut flavor.
NIce winter beer that Id drink in the summer too.  A real perk is its available in 6s which most decent beers by avery only come in bombers.  This one is worth trying certainly.

[Bottle] Pours dark reddish-brown with a decent, light brown head. Aroma is brown sugar, marshmallow, honey, blackberry, light cocoa. Taste is nutty, good bitterness, toasted malt, caramel, prunes, alcohol, light citrus and blackberry again. Excellent. Good mouthfeel, smooth, with a long finish. Wow, this is a really nice beer. I definitely will be buying this again, and would like to try it with some age on it.

Dark walnut colored pour with a frothy white head. Aroma holds almond, Nutella, caramel, toffee, and peanut brittle. Classic for the style on the nose, but done well. Flavor is similar, with more caramel malt and a bit of chocolate. The nuttiness from the aroma fades away, and theres a touch of roast in there as well. Palate is light to medium bodied and quite drinkable, though not complex. Good brew.

Very dark brown with a medium off white head. The aroma holds a nice blend of caramel malt, hazelnut, other nut incarnations, and a subtle orange-grapefruit citrus presence. More caramel malt and cocoa nib lead to toffee and the slightest hint of roast. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with a dry finish.

A: snifter. pours a clear mahogany color. light tan head. moderate retention level and decent lacing.

S: pears, fig, some spices, mostly clove, and some plums.

T: big caramel notes, with some fig, plums, some cinnamon and clove. very malty brew. delicious.

M: big full bodied brew. solid carbonation level. very nice palate.

D: ABV appears to be high, noticed in the flavor. solid beer for the holiday season. wonderful brew. about two of these should warm you up.

Bottle. Pours a clear brown beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt, caramel and some burnt character. The flavor is malt, caramel and sweetness. The palate is sweet. Overall an average beer with sweetness.
Colour is light brown with a creamy top. Aroma is burnt caramel. Flavour is burnt caramel and alcohol.

Brown with a touch of haze, her khaki head clings desperately to the sides of my glass. A blanket remains while a nose of treacle, plums, red apples, and cinnamon sticks finish with green grass. A bit simple, but Christmas beers have no set parameters so to each brewer their own. While the nose didnt exactly wow, her palate on the other hand does a better job of stimulating my senses. The hops which were but a background whisper are now front-forward and prominent with green grass and pine needles crushed between fingers, their sticky resins oozing rich forestry esters. Chocolate delights flow underneath while a dry finish atop my tongue is all bark and dry forestry wood. Quaff and repeat. Overall, a bit more stimulating than her nose, resulting in a sessionable Christmas beer which neither disappoints nor inspires.


Dont get me wrong; the Old Jubilation from Avery was far from a drain-pour, but she wasnt exactly a show-stopper either. Id drink another one if offered, but I wouldnt go out of my way to buy a 6pack come next Christmas.
Pours dark copper with a beige head. Aroma is burnt caramel and fruity notes. Flavour is burnt caramel, alcohol, fruity and some bitter hop.

1yr old Bottle.  Aroma has notes of caramel malts, dried dark fruits, toffee, nutty, and roasted malts.  Deep amber hue with an average sized off-white foamy head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Taste is sweet then turns roasted bitter.  Palate is full bodied and oily soft.  Very good with at least a year on it.  Very surprised with this one, very good.  Avery still sucks though.

2007 Bottle (3 years old). Pours a nearly opaque sepia color with a large, foamy white head. Looks almost like a Belgian quad. The aroma has almonds, walnuts,  candi sugar, and toffee. The flavor is similar, fairly sweet, and has a strong alcohol finish. Soft mouthfeel foams up in the mouth. Im not sure if that has anything to do with the age. Pretty good brew, Ill have to try a fresh one to compare.

(Draught at Flying Saucer Lake beer festival) clearish deep copper, lasting tan head and excellent lacing. Nose of caramel, cream, and sweet citrus fruits. Taste of caramel, spicy hops, cinnamon, ginger, cream and honeydew. Creamy medium thickness with perfect carbonation.

12 oz bottle, pours a ruddy ruby-mahogany. Light tan head, mild retention and lacing. After a vigorous swirl, the nose is simply massive, with raisin, toffee, plum, fig, molasses, as well as slight cognac and chocolate undertones. Tastes heavily of figs, molasses, and toffee, but with a surprisingly present smoke flavor. Mouthfeel is thick without being syrupy. A very "clean" ale, if that makes any sense. Very nice.

Mahogany pour with a dense, 1-finger, off-white head.  Nutty caramel aroma with some mild dark fruit and molasses and a soft pine note and a hint of smoke.  Roasted hazelnuts, earthy caramel, smoke, molasses, some juniper and evergreen.  Creamy medium full body with soft carbonation..

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2010 Avery 
Old Jubilation Ale
Pours thick oily brown with a copper tinge and almost no head. Nearly no lacing. Sweet aroma of alcohol, cherries, barley wine, and yummy. Smells divine. Flavor is somewhat subdued in comparison to the aroma but darn nice anyway. Syrupy with a slightly bitter finish and a lasting alcohol burn. Sweet caramel malt and some dried fruits. Damn good. Avery rocks.

The color of this beer is deep dark and brownish with hints of an amber outter ring. The scent starts with hints of nuts and finishes with a trace of vanilla. This beer has a flavor a sweet coffee like start and finshes with  hints of brown sugar.

When you open the bottle you can smell the aroma instantly, maybe walnuts roasted over a fire. has a very strong taste with a hint of seasonal flavoring. Has a slight aftertaste. Not a bad beer, just not my type.
Reddish brown pour in glass. Nose and taste is nuts, toffee, some chocolates, malts and resin. Rated 2/11/03

Bottle. Pours a clear dark red/brown with a beige head. Sweet and malty aroma with a slightly tart note, and hops mucking about in the background. A tad cloying. Some wooden notes as it warms. Flavour is sweet and malty with remote notes of liquorice. Citrus hops in the background. Sweet, malty finish; mildly bitter. Lingering grassy notes. A decent beer. 03-05-10.

12 Oz.  Aged .5 years. Pours a beautiful dark amber with medium off white head that is slow to subside.  Aroma of slight funk and nut.  This beer has some seriously tasty malt charactor with not a whole of sweetness and just enough hops to hold everything up.  Finish is of slight coffee sensation.
Bottle. Clear mahogany pour with a fluffy off white head. Aroma and taste of nuts, caramel, and dark fruit. Slightly hoppy. Good.

Rich dark brown/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of malt, toffee, & some dark fruit; Flavor of slight roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, toffee, and spice; Nicely balanced; Overall, very nice ale.

A nice Winter Warmer that fits the style well but doesnt particularly excel in any category. Old Jubilation has a nice appearance, deep brown liquid with a good beige head. The aroma is predominantly light malt with a metallic tinge. Its not bad but a bit weak. The taste is somewhat boring caramel malt with good spicing and a lightly bitter finish. The spices are particularly well done with clove and cinnamon dominant and never take on the annoying artificial character of so many other beers in the style. Unfortunately, Old Jubilation just fades into the background of my winter warmer memories. Its well done but a bit boring. I would recommend it to fans of the style or those looking for a simple entry point to winter warmers (of course, the latter seems like a bizarre audience that I just invented).

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2011 Old Jubilation Ale

1998--12 oz. Bottle.  8.00% ABV.  Winter Ale.  (3.0 / 5.0)

2005--12 oz. Bottle.  8.00% ABV--30 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Winter Ale.  Arctic Liquor Beer of the Month Club Selection December 2005.  Thin lacy head.  Clear dark bronze color.  Mild roasted floral hop cinnamon malt spice front.  Dry sweet burnt crisp toffee caramel spice thin rich body.  Crisp Winter spice roasted hoppy end.  Sampled 4/18/2006.

2006--12 oz. Bottle.  8.00% ABV--30 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Winter Ale.  Mild lacy head.  No sediment.  Clear dark bronze color.  Mild hop big malt front.  Crisp tangy tart sweet toasted toffee clove nutmeg malty body.  Hot malt spice mild EtOH hop clean dry sweet end.  Big &  balanced.  Sampled 6/12/2007.

2007--12 oz. Bottle.  8.00% ABV--30 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Winter Ale.  6-Pack $8.99.  Perfect Label.  No sediment.  Rich lacy off white head.  Clear thin dark bronze color.  Toasted malt spice smoky mince meat mild hop front.  Crusty roasted burnt nutmeg toffee caramel body.  Cloying sweet smooth mild hop lingering malt spice roasted nutty end.  Sampled 10/13/2008.

2008 12 oz. Bottle.  8.00% ABV--30 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Winter Ale.  Big foamy lacy head.  Clear thin dark bronze red color.  Mild hop toasted malt spice front.  Mild coffee toffee rich malty no added spice nutty hint body.  Mild hop hot EtOH tangy malt spice boisterious malt end.  Sampled 12/10/2008.  6-Pack $9.99.
	
Avery Brewing Company--Old Jubilation Ale--Limited Release 2010 12 oz. Bottle.  8.30% ABV.  30 IBUs?  (3.75 / 5.0)  Winter Old Ale?  Lacy dense tan 1/2" head.  Clear dark ruby walnut color.  Mild hop malty toasted dark fruit front.  Creamy smooth rich doughy malty toffee raison dark mellow fruit mildly crusty sweet body.  Clean mild hop hot EtOH hint dark fruit malty end.  Too rich.  Sampled 2/21/2011.  Purchased 6-Pack for $9.99 at The Greenwood Market, Seattle on 10/27/2010.

Pours a clear dark ruby and gave a small off-white and tan head that deflated to a ring and cover, some effervescence with a few floaties in the brew when viewed in front of a light, aroma is malty, chocolate, dark roasted malt, dark sugar, some earthy and dark fruit fragrances, has a generous malt sweetness, there are chocolate fragrances that reminds me of Tootsie Rolls, flavors of strong, dark and/or burnt? caramel, treacle, chocolate, dark roasted malt, dark brown sugar, some bitterness on the palate at the finish that has a earthy flavor, mouth feel is more then medium, covers the tongue with lots of thick malt flavors, a touch of alcohol warmth on the tongue that is hardly noticed and did not take away from the enjoyment of this drink, this is prominently a malt flavored ale that covers the palate, a nice drink, I enjoyed this a lot, I recommend this on a cold Winter evening.

Well. The shelf tag @ Archer would have me believe that this is an 07 batch of Jubilation. Not quite sure. Wish I would have saved it for a night my palate was a little cleaner, but here goes. [A] Caramel. Chocolate. Toffee. Fig. Raisin. Dark fruit. Ripe. Almost wine ish. Grape or cranberry juice quality. English barleywine-esque. No hops really present, though a nice nose. Likeable in my book. [A] Shotgun blast and huge huge chunky bubbly brown head. Caramel brown to light. Active. Will not even allow a pour. Dont think this is 07. Dark ruddy brown liquid. [F] Initially dark fruit. Caramel and a very large chocolate note. Mostly fruity. Nice intricacy and balance. Licorice. Maltiness. [P] Very watery. No hops. Flat mouth. With more dark fruit and chocolate. Reminiscent of certain barleywines and foreign stouts. Not especially a bad thing for this ale. But it doesnt help. [O] I somewhat liked this after some IPA. Lord only knows if its 07. Not sure if I would buy a 6er either way. One was more than enough. Avery is one of my favorite brewers, and this receives a fair score, but I cannot totally agree with it tonight.

Bottle. Pour was deep brown with an aroma of toffee, caramel, malt, and some light spice. Flavors were more rich toffee, sweet malt, some light coffee, and a slight nuttiness along with a little woodiness in the finish. Nice brew with a good balance of flavors and complexity.
12 oz bottle.  Pours reddish amber with an off-white head.  Citrusy aroma with some caramel and eathy tones.  Flavor is nutty, earthy, and toasty with a lemony citrus.  A really nice beer.

Dark hazy brown with a small fast disappearing baige head. Aroma is full of toffe and hazelnut with a bit of overripe figs. A zip reveals quite a complex moutharoma where grassy hops set in followed by raw roasted nuts and chocolate and a quite dry and warming finish. Nice
Taste of caramel. Sweet lilke candy. A palate not unlike coffee. Pours with little to know head. Color like sap.  All in all one sweet malty experience.

Pours a dark cloudy brown, with virtually no lacing. The aroama is some caramel, butterscotch and raisin. The taste is somewhat sweet, tastes somewhat like a barleywine. The body is medium and creamy, very good.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep clear brown with a hint of ruby and a creamy pillowy off white head. Aroma is heavy on the dark fruits, some molasses and toffee, chestnut, very malty, not much hop presence, maybe a little citric. FLavor has a much more pronounced chocolate and malted milk ball character, very rich deep fruitiness, stays extremely sweet with the toffee, hazelnut, creamy and smooth, very tasty malts. Medium body and a slight crisp carbonation. Really a tasty beer, nice winter warmer, the malt (and high abv) make me feel warm all over.

Pours dark brown with a thin beige head and a treacle aroma. The slightly harsh roasted malt flavor, typical of this brewer, is evident in this brew. However, it is a good, tasty example of a strong ale, with some carbonation and a bitter finish.

Love the smell! like a Pecan Praline crusted yellowtail with mango chutney. Could smell this all day. Flavor is of malt and alcohol. Cant taste much of anything past the Alcohol sting. Palate is also long lasting. Bottle at Stop and Shop, Miami.
Reddish brown pour with 1/2 finger off white head. Nose of spice, malt, and grass. Taste is light malt with a soft bitter hop taste. Lacing is minimal. Not great.

12 oz bottle from archers. Pours a bright and clear reddish-brown colour with a little foam; aroma of caramel and hazelnut, notes of fir needles, slightly roasted; sweet and full-bodied, very tasty, late but robust bitterness before a dry caramelish, woody and malty fini

Location: 12 oz bottle from Chevy Chase, 2/6/10 


Aroma: Nose of spice, some caramel malts, nuts, wood, and a good amount of dark fruits

Appearance: Pours a clear red/dark orange color with a thin off-white head and some spotty lace

Flavor: Taste is somewhat sweet, toffee malts, wood, spice, and a solid hop presence for balance

Palate: It is a fairly smooth beer with medium-full bodied feel, and an oily, a bit sticky, mouthfeel

Overall Impression:
This is a pretty nice beer overall.  Rather complex and well-balanced.  Pretty enjoyable.  A nice winter seasonal offering from Avery.
Very nice dark brown with white head, smell of malt. Taste is smooth balanced with a tinge of spice.
buona old ale all americana.. nn strepitosa ma interessante luppolata buona presenza di note fruttate....

Dark brown with a very thick off white head.  Spicy aroma gives way to spicy taste with dark caramel notes.  Theres some sweetness and the finish is grassy, bitter, and pleasant.  The palate is even very smooth - not overly carbonated.
Like a caramely, vanilla-y, slightly chocolatey ipa. Thats how hoppy it is. Unique in its combo of flavors. Some nuttiness and woodiness come through too. It is very good for winter. Excellent.
Unique beer. Pours mahogany with a rocky head. Flavor is a mix of juniper, dark fruits and roast malt. The finish is incredibly dry with a burst of grassy hop at the end. Good beer yum.

(draft at Trinity in Colorado Springs). Dark brown color. Medium off white head, which is mostly diminishing. Sweet caramel aroma, with light hops. Light malt flavor with moderate bitterness. Smooth finish with a very light, lasting bitterness. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
12 oz bottle. Park reddish body with very small off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, dark fruit and hops.

Yuck. Dunno if this was an off keg or just not my taste. Syrupy, with a greasy skim of a head. I get the hazelnut thing, but to me this was flat, tasted lIke old coffee and old sugar. Not for me, I guess. Disgusting. But only a lot. Stale keg?
Standard bitter aroma and hoppy taste but comes with a curiously good finish, very smooth.

Mahogany with minimal tan head and some clings. Smells of roasted malt and warm chocolate. Tastes more like a porter than a strong but I guess the boundaries are blurred these days. Nutty, hazelnut, bitter coffee and chocolate all in the taste. Bitter mocha lingers.

Appearance: Pours a dark, reddish-brown with a firm, lingering tan head. Considerable lacing as the level receded.

Aroma: Nicely balanced between sweet, caramel notes and bitter hops. 

Flavor: Flavor is at first sweet and malty, then quickly turns happily bitter with some nice, piney hop flavor. On the swallow, the bitterness prevails, leaving the mouth with a pleasantly bitter, sticky aftertaste. Some notes of toffee and burnt malts, adding to the bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium to medium-big in body. Light and fine carbonation. Slightly warming going down.

Overall Impression: Overall I was very impressed. A beautifully struck balance between malt sweetness and hop bite. 

Comments: Bottle pour.
21st December 2008. Clear dark brown beer. Malty and rich with underlying fruit and some nut flavours. The richness and aromatics lift this beer from the lower levels of averageness!

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 12oz bottled Sep 23, 2009.  Pours reddish copper/brown, with a large light tan head in a wide-mouth glass.  Beautiful pour, also leaves some sticky rings of lacing.  Aroma of caramel malts, candy, some hops especially early in the glass, some toffee, and a little bit of funk.  Flavor is malty, caramel, toffee, candy sweetness, some spice, and resinous piney hops on the finish.  Mouthfeel is oily, low/medium carbonation.  Had this a couple of years ago but didnt take notes, Im enjoying this years, although the first half of the glass was much better than the second.  Fuller body, bigger flavors, especially the hops.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2011 Bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a small off-white head.  Not much lacing.  I get a bit of dark fruit, caramel, and malt in the aroma, but they definitely take second place to the hops.  The flavor is balanced and big.  The citrusy, piney hops are quite assertive but are countered by the rich maltiness.  I taste caramel, molasses, lots of nuttiness and roasty richness, and also some alcohol.  A very nice beer.

dark red brown with nice thick white head.  nose of spicy and pungent english hops with some dark malt.  mild bitterness before low crystal sweetness then some upper crystal raison flavors combined with some chocolate malt, some residual sweetness, the hops come through with spiciness and earthy notes.  the hops come through more than any other flavor, which in this style is not desirable.  i was hoping for something maltier and powerful to fit the style better

Bottle at Q-Brick. Malty fruit aroma with west coast hops and caramel. Lots of caramel, almost bock-like. Flavor also big caramel, spicy, slightly vineous, with cherries and a bit of sour as well. Rich fruits. Ok, but not all that special.

12oz bottle (2009) into a trappist glass.  Pours red/brown with a small off-white head that fades very quickly.  The aroma is malty and hints of alcohol, and the flavor is malty and a bit sweet with plenty of chocolate and coffee.  On top of this there is a solid dose of hops as well.  Very high carbonation.

Brown pour clear little off white head little lacing as well aroma of roasted malts hazelnut and toffee .... Taste of nuts roasted malts caramel toffee light bitter nutty and mocha aftertaste that lingers a little ...  a nice winter beer very warming and balanced

Aroma of mocha, toffee and bourbon. Appearance is dark brown with tan head that lingered till the end. Flavor matches the nose, with some more hops, bourbon and coffee as well. Palate is creamy. Tasty, but a bit overrated.
Pours dark brown with ruby edges and a frothy tan head. Aroma- fig, rasin, bread, vanilla. Taste is sweet caramel with a bitter hop finish. Thick body and medium carbonation.
The aroma is that musky malty sense reminding me of Belgium. It has a clear rich amber brown appearance with a small head. The flavor is clear malts with that muskiness showing but in a pleasant way.
Dark brown with amber highlights. Rich, smooth beer. If your bartender confuses your Jubilation with a Boulevard Nutcracker, your beer is the one with the delightful aroma and thick palate.

355 ml bottle. From København, Denmark.
Dark reddish brown colour with average off-white head.
Sweetish dark hoppy, roasted malty aroma with some winey elements.
Dark roasted malt, sweet hops, caramel in flavour. 
Sweet, thick and full brew.

A hazy brown pour with a large, frothy head.  The aroma is a mixture apple, grapes, and caramel malt.  The taste begins sweet and finishes with medium sourness.  It is a full body brew with a thick texture and long finish.  It leaves you with slight alcohol warmth.

poured dark amber and red around edges with thick light tan head and lots of lacing,with aromas from caramel malts,earthly hops, and peat taste of caramel,malts,earthly hops and hazel nuts a very sweet maltey smooth and creamy reminds me of a lighter version of a barley wine this is one of my favorites from this brewer

Smells of cinnamon, ginger and cherry. The malt is nutmeg.

Glassy dark red, with nice lace. Nice hue, not much body.

The taste is whiskey and bourbon. Cherry cordials and a roasted coffee. Dark chocolate malt. Big alcohol burn. A little saccharine, but the burnt flavor works well with it. Really bursting with strong flavors.

The palate is thick and creamy. Very thick. Really sticks around on the tongue. A really nice, bittersweet beer with a nice burn. A winter warmer for sure.
Bottle sampled at Grapes of Mirth Winter Beers Tasting. I like Avery. Pour was a nice amber color. Aroma of nuts and toffee. Flavor was sweet and warm.

Light filmed mahogany with a beige wavy lace making slowly fading protector.  Aroma of cereal grains, pale malt, alcohol and some sweet biscuity malt.  Taste of diacetyl, sweet malt, maple, mild roasted malt, raisons, dark fruit and alcohol.  Dry and semi boozy on the finish.

Sampled at Famous Liquors Holiday Tasting in Lombard, IL. Poured a clear, ruby brown, with some decent, light tan foam, and clingy ribbons of lacing. The aroma was toasty, nutty, and caramelly, with smooth malt and brown sugar sweetness. The flavor mimicked these notes well, while exposing a pleasant malt creaminess, moderate bitterness, and subtle but lurking alcohol. Medium bodied, and a fine, holiday treat

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a dark maroon-red with a slight layer of light brown foamy head that dissipates slowly and leaves a good amount of lacing on the glass.

The smell is a bit of sweet malts and has a bit of dark chocolate flavor as well.

The taste is surprisingly creamy at first has some sweet tones to the flavor that gives this malty beer a zing feel. There is a bit of brown sugar and is also a bit smokey but only in the slightest.

The feel of this beer is pretty pleasant, and is quite light for a winter beer that is still a bit malty. Is medium bodied and goes down pretty easy.

Moderately sweet and earthy aroma of licorice, caramel and wood. Gorgeous deep reddish brown color with a thick, rocky head that lasts beyond the final drop. Substantial lacing. Medium sweetness with hints of nuts. Substantial alcohol warmth. Full body with a hefty mouthfeel. Lively carbonation with a lasting sweet malt finish. This is a big winner. Highly recommended for those cold winter nights, or anytime, really.

12 oz. bottle, 2008. 99¢ loose bottle at Binnys. Sweet honey smell with toffee and peanut brittle notes. Deep brown but bright color, when poured, layers of the brown head fight to get past each other. Nice nut brown malt taste. Malt sweetness with a little sugar on the side. Slightly woody or peaty. Sweetness settles out leaving me to pick out more of the complex taste. No spices, as they say, but I get a suggestion of gingerbread and pecan. Slight alcohol in the nose, and a warming of the toes after drinking half the glass. Definitely in the category of a higher-alcohol winter warmer without anything excessive.

Dark redbrown, smooth light brown head.
nutty dark caramelly aroma, also some dark chocolate, some bitter hops in the background.
flavor is dark caramelly sweet, dark toffee, faint roasted malts, bitter malts, faint flowery and bitter hop flavor to balance. a beer with lots and lots of taste from malts, but never too sweet.

Bottle...  Beautifully poured a deep, dark -- almost opaque -- ruby with a thick, frothy, bubbly, khaki head that floated nicely and retained well.  Malty, cocoa and floral aroma.  Smooth, full palate with nutty tones, chocolate malts, caramel, ginger, and clean, sugary finish.

12oz bottle from Orland Park Binnys single rack. Pours dark amberish brown with 2-finger tan head. Aroma is toasted malts, caramel, toffee, bread, and some hops. Flavor is toffee, caramel, nuts, chewy malts, bread and earthy hops. Medium mouthfeel and  nice carbonation. Finishes with light bitterness and a little bit alcohol burn. Pretty solid ale overall.

12oz. Bottle from VBM in Buffalo. Pours a clear reddish copper body with a small, long lasting cream colored head. Great lacing. Aroma is spicy, slight alcohol, roasted malts, yeast and sugary notes. Flavor is nice sweet malts, nutty, a bit cloying, spiced. Full, creamy mouthfeel. There is a slight coffee aftertaste. Nice warming feeling like a good winter ale should. Very enjoyable beer.

Bottle. Poured a deep amber color with a little white head. Aroma was yeast, sweet hops, and caramel. Flavor was mild bitters, toffee, and yeast. Finish was mild bitters. Medium body. Very good winter beer.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour was deep mahogany with half an inch of off-white head.  The head retention was poor, but the lacing was quite good.  Nose is caramel, malt, toffee, and triscuits.  Taste is sweet malt and bitter hop all at once.  The toffee and triscuits then make their presence known as everything trails into a slightly dry and bitter finish that has a floral zing to it.  This is a very good offering by Avery that could quite easily sneak up on you because of the well masked, high ABV.

Pours a big 3 finger off white head. Body is a clear mahogany brown with lots of bubbles rising. Head retention is above average but the lacing is very good

Aroma  is of sweet roasted caramel malt and some herbal hops. Alcohol is also slightly detected. A bit underwhelming compared to taste

First taste reminds me of an English barleywine. Tons of malt come through ranging from flavors of brown sugar to smoked malt and even some copper. Hops are also there, slightly bitter but mostly floral and earthy. Alcohol adds a touch of warmth to the finish.

Mouth feel is good. Carbonation is sufficient. Beer is medium bodied, about average consistency for a winter beer. Wish head contributed more to body, it died down towards last quarter of glass.

Drink ability was great. Rather session able strong ale. Very complex beer, almost flawless. Winter is my favorite season for beer and this one is one of the best seasonal beers around

One of my favorite winter beers. a ton of complex maltiness with some fruit and just a tinge of alcohol and hops to keep things interesting.  Extremely drinkable and a good contrast to my other hoppier winter faves like SNCA. Averys best beer IMHO.

Good mouthfeel was about it, too malty and the alcohol in thus one came through almost sour with a hot finish, says in the description no spices used and its true. That is where I think this beer could be much better, with some spice added.

Poured clear, deep red/maogany, with a one-finger head that left a rather thick film and nice lacing. Caramel malts were strongest on the nose with a touch of spruce from the hops. Chewy bready malts on the tongue were wonderful, accompanied by caramelized sugars and supported by gentle hops bitterness. Medium body, light but lively carbonation, and a caramel malts lingered in the aftertaste. Alcohol is not evident. Great as a winter warmer.
Pours a deep brownish amber with red hues.  Aroma of molasses and nuts.  Malt is abundant and welcomed.  Slight toffee and nutty finish.  Quite good.

Liquid pours a medium copper color, with a ruby tint. One finger head of light tan foam. Retention is fairly good and lacing is decent.

Smells nice and malty. Smells of sweet vanilla caramels. Some hints of dark fruits come in and have just a tiny hint of hops with them. 

Ive never had caramel covered cherries, but that is what they would taste like. Along with a nice sweet malt base. A touch of warming spiciness. Hops are in this, but the heavy malt profile is knocking them into the background. Hints of dark fruit.

Feels very smooth and a touch creamy. Just about the body that I like a winter warmer to have.

Very drinkable. Sweet, yet not overly so. Nice, slightly dry finish. Well masked ABV.
Another solid brew from Avery. Quickly becoming my fave winter warmer. (Okay, its in a tie with Great Divide Hibernation.)

From the Bottle at TAG Restaurant, Denver 22/09/2009
Fruit and malt aroma. Amber coloured strong in alcohol and hoppy with a little roast flavour in a crisp and bitter warming chocolate malt finish.
Nice pour, brownish and lightly hazy. Has a nice nutty, hazelnut aroma and flavor. Smooth and warming to the soul.

Pours very dark brown with slight haze. Cannot see through when held to light. Thin light brown head.

Nose has a very pleasant cocoa malt profile. Very appetizing nose.

Palate is a nice blend of rich roasted malt, espresso bitterness/sharpness, alcohol warmth, pine, and a medium long finish.

Above average for a winter ale.

Draft at Brouwers.  Pours a clear dark amber brown with a decent creamy off white head.  Nose is big on sweet malt with raisin, plum, brown sugar, some grassy hops as well.  Flavor was pretty much to be expected, sweet sticky maltiness with some nut and light crispness on the end.  Solid winter brew.

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear reddish brown color with an expansive, creamy, foamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel and toffee. 
Taste is slightly roasty and nutty malt notes with caramel, toffee and spicy hops. Texture is creamy, smooth and slightly cheesy. Medium-full bodied.

12 oz. bottle. Colour... medium brown witha thick head. Nose... quite malty and slightly roasty. Palate... mildly sweet, malty, nutty, toffee-like, lightly spicy and a long finish. Currently my favourite winter ale (as far as a 12 oz. format). Doesnt seem at all like an 8% ale. This could sneak up on me, if Im not careful!

Bottle from jessup plaza. nice dark amber color with a small off white head that didnt last long. aroma is very sweet with some alcohol, and dark fruit. Taste is very sweet with notes of caramel, oak, alcohol. Light hop finish which lingers on the tongue for awhile. This is nice.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle.
Appearance: Murky amber with a creamy, light tan head.  Good head retention.
Aroma: A good bit of boozy fruit with full malt notes, caramel, and a touch of nuts.
Flavor: Dark caramel, boozy dark fruit, a very light coffee note, and a touch of nuts.  I have to agree, this one is pretty tasty and omission of the spices isnt missed.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium-rich mouthfeel and a medium finish.
Overall: Definitely one of the better strong ales Ive had.  The alcohol is present, but does a nice job of playing with others.  Great flavor, mouthfeel and appearance.

12oz bottle. This one hit me just right. Excellent looking ale that pours dark amber with a creamy head and plenty of lacing. What I liked most about this one is the fact that they dont add any spices like so many others do in this style. Without the added spice the rich malt taste was quite enjoyable and it masked the high abv completely.

Yeah, right on Old Jubilation.  One of the finest looking ales Ive seen in a glass: beautiful, rich mahogany ale produces sticky lacing along the glass.  Nice malty bite.  Good call on NOT putting any ridiculous or "exotic" spices in there Avery.  Great way to welcome in colder weather for the fall.

Note: I have often disparaged any ale from England; this beer happens to be an English style ale made in the U.S.A.  Yes, we do it better here!  Ive tried and rated the famous Fullers 1845 (rated tops in this category) and deemed it terrible.  This beer is exponentially better than Fullers.

Bottle at Trappeze.  Poured amberish brown, with a decent-sized head.  Aroma is fruit, malt, & booze.  The fruit is mostly dark and sweet.  Taste is fruity as with the aroma, malt is also present, as is a boozy finish.  Overall, a nice warmer.

Cask conditioned at Avery tap room. Amber and non-transparent. Aroma is malty and sweet. straightforward nose also with alcohol adding to a sweeter syrupy smell or caramel and pecans. Flavor is bread-like with tons of sweet caramel, more nuts, and burnt roast flavors. Leaves a unique but well defined after taste. End is lightly bitter after the wealth of sweetness throughout.
Sweet malt aroma, and taste. Red brown color. Solid body and mouth feel. Medium head

Let me start by saying I am a big fan of Winter and Old Ales, and Old Jubilation may be my favorite.

The beer pours a reddish brown with a relatively good head of foam that hold up well.

The aroma is tart cherry, currents, malt, and a wisp of alcohol. A great smelling beer.

The Cherry and Currents in the aroma take of the beginning of the taste, and remain for quite a while, then you pick up a good dose of malt, and the taste ends with a mild burn (as would be expected in a Winter Warmer), and a good dose of bittering hops. Wow

Mouthfeel and Drinkability are what you would expect from a quality brewed strong Ale.

Over all outstanding!
Avery tap room 9/22/09.  Aroma; almonds and medium caramalts.  Taste;  THIS IS A PALE PORTER... some tiny funkiness?

Clear brownish-red pour with an off-white head, good retention, sticky lacing.  Roasted malt, nutty aroma with a hint of hop bitterness.  Sweet malt, molasses and carbonation at the beginning leading to a semi-dry bitterness from the hops.  Could be more complex.  Medium body, moderate carbonation, mild alcohol warmth.  A winter warmer for sure!

A dark red beer with a small head. Aroma was like an old ale. The taste was a dark malty taste with a sweet candy finish that is roasty like a watered down stout. It also tastes like the picture- meant to be drunk on a cold snowy day.
Bottle.  The beer was hoppy, but not at all  overbearing.  Slight piny taste.
Dark mahogany with a tan head; rich aromas and flavors of malt.  Has a slight acid, slight hop taste; aromas are of caramel.  Solid, but not very complicated nor very interesting.
Pours a caramel color with a large tan head.  Mild aroma; a bit of hops and alcohol.  Flavor is very hoppy with some bitter coffee and charcoal.  Medium body and carbonation.

11/08/2007:  Avery Old Jubilation has a yeasty, dark brown sugar aroma like alcoholic fruit cake and even a bit of burn in the nostrils!  The flavor is nutty with hints of mocha and ctirus.  There is some alcohol as well, but it isnt hot and doesnt burn.  This beer is crystal clear dark brown in color with a foamy, lasting beige-colored head, a medium body, and smooth texture.  It both tastes good and feels good, but nothing really jumps out to make this beer truly unique or memorable.
12 fl. oz. bottle.  Rating #783 for this beer.

Dark in color even for a strong ale. Slight bits of red in what was otherwise darkish brown. Light creamy head. Nice aromas of dark grains, dried fruits, molasses. Flavor really shows the blended malt character. Very decent complexity. Impressive beer considering the price. Drank this side by side with Rogue Double Dead Guy. Went toe to toe with the Dead Guy, no problem. In fact I think I prefer the Jubilation. Better malt character and balance than the Rogue. Not to mention this beer is a great value.

From [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */øbenhavnske Øldage 2009. A clear, deep amber colored beer with a thin offwhite head on top. Sweetish malty, peppery, slight fruity aroma. Moderately hopped, a whiff of alcohol. Taste is fairly dry with a medium strong, nutty malt body, light sourish with ash notes. Some dark dried fruits and an well prononced hop bitterness.  Medium to light body. Feels slight watery in the mouth actually. Toasted malts and a fine, lingering bitterness in the ending. Does not stand out, but overall a nice experience

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2009 Massively underrated. Unlike most run-of-the-mill holiday offerings, this beer isnt jacked up on spice just to meet the expectations of the category. The considerable alcohol Ƙ% ABV) isnt forward, and takes a back seat...this is a lovely, malty bastard with some coffee and nuts on the follow through. Especially enjoyed it on tap at Meade Street Station, West Highlands, Denver. Drink after coming in from the snow...thats why it exists.

Pours a dark brown with some ruby red hints and a thin off white head. Aroma is kinda odd with a melding of some dark fruity notes and a fish meal/cheap tuna cat food aroma, kinda off setting.  Flavor has a very light nutty flavor, some toffee and light plum notes, lots of caramel sweetness and a light grassy hoppy note in the background. Density is great with a slightly dense sugary feel and the beer carries a modest dry ending.  Overall once you get past the somewhat offensive aroma, the flavor and mouth feel of the beer are great.
Pours a dark brownish/red wine color with a  beige head. Aroma of roasted carmel malt, dark fruit, nut, spcices, alcohol, some smoke. Taste is a similar mix. Lingering alcohol finish.

Bottle split with scottyp after work at woodys.  Pours a great clear mahogany with ruby highlights and fair tan head.  Nose of peat, tar cherry cough syrup, figs.  Very unique.  Flavor brings some light smoke, burnt malt, dark fruits, and a hop bitterness with hop flavor.  Good warming effect.

[2090-20090410] 12floz bottle. Mild smoke aroma is sweet with dark grains. Clear, dark brown mahogany with a quick creamy light tan head. Mildly smoky grains and alcohol flavour has a long heavy aftertaste. Medium body. Average.
(c/o GregClow, w/ him, jerc)

Beautiful-looking beer; deep mahogany color with a fluffy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is dominated by bread and yeast. Taste is bitter cirtus hops, caramel, smoke, toffee, and a hint of chocolate. Some heat from the alcohol, but nothing to complain about. Heavily carbonated though, too much for my taste. This is one of those beers that expands in your mouth. Very drinkable and enjoyable though.

Bottle without date. Nondescript smoky brown, amll cream head. Sweet molasses/caramel/brown sugar smells hints vaguely at cherry/blueberry, banana, peat. Tastes thick and chocolatey, cola, sappy malt, and a broad bitter spinachy backbite. Meaty palate. Overall very "brown", woody, and just plain boring.
pours brown with a tan head.  notes of chocolate, caramel, nuts, spices, toffee, brown sugar.  pretty tasty.  nice body.  liked it.
Bottle. Did not fully enjoy this beer. It did not hide the etoh taste very well, and was only average in aroma and flavor otherwise.

(06 bottle from joebrew)  Pours a dark brown with reddish tinges which settles to a medium cream-colored head with great lacing.  Aroma begins with a large spice presence, notably clove, and theres still just a faint presence of hops as well.  As this warms however, the aroma begins to change and becomes sweeter and richer.  Smells of strong caramel, cocoa, candied nuts, dough, and hints of light roasted malt at the end of sniffs.  The taste is nice and clearly malt-driven, with a lot of toffee, brown sugar, and prunes, that then switches to a nice and lingering finish of toasted nuts, toffee, and kicks of spice.  This finish just goes on, and its very pleasant.  Medium mouthfeel to this beer is borderline chewy, and the carbonation is restrained.  For a bottle of this age, this beer has held up remarkably well.  Thanks Joe!

2007 bottle consumed on 11/22/08


Fresh this is a little hot with alcohol, I find this vintage to be pouring perfectly, nice little head capping my glass, smells pof cherries, prunes and spices. And to no surprise, it tastes like it smells. Mouthfeel is perfect, perfect viscosity, sits on your tongue but not for too long.

Bottle pours a clear, dark mahogany color with a dense, foamy beige head.  Good lacing along the glass.  Roasted, malty, nutty aroma.  Flavor has some nice hop bitterness characteristics balanced with a malty sweetness.  Lots of spices, some dried fruit and toffee.  Very nice combination of flavors.  Alcohol is noticeable without being overpowering.
tastes like puke.  thats all ive got to say.              blah blah blah blah blah

12oz bottle. Pours a clear, deep red colored body with a finger-width, frothy, ight brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a good amount of lacing. Nice looking beer. Aroma is both soft and hard. The softness comes from a good amount of dark fruits and prunes, sugary berry malts, and toffee. The hardness comes from the balancing woody hops, somewhat toasted notes in the sweet toffee, some almost sharp licorice, and a nice boozey touch. The flavor is very enjoyable. Much more of a noticeable roast and toasted toffee flavor. The nuts that the brewer proclaim are distinguishable in the flavor when they were not easy to pick up in the aroma. The licorice, prunes, and berry malts from the aroma are present, but not sugary at all. There is a slight woody character to this near the finish as well. The finish is very even and somewhat dry. It leaves a very nice nut, roast, wood, and toasted toffee lingering flavor that lasts for quite awhile with just a hint of alcohol creeping in. Palate is full and flavorful. Overall, this is a very nice beer. Lots of flavor and a great balance. I really like the toasted toffees that show up in the flavor. Good stuff.

Nice dark brown in color. This beer has a red hue when the light passes through it. Nice fluffy off-white head. Great looking beer. Nice aromatic malt, sweet, and roasted aroma. Very sugary beer with a nice subtle roast taste. Fairly smooth beer. Man this beer leaves a rather powerful sweet taste in your mouth. Slight bitter finish. Overall, pretty goodbeer. Usually not a fan of the English beers, whether it came from England, or was even mentioned in passing in England, but this beer is damn good.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2009 Pours a light brown head.  Body is brown with an amber hue.  Smells like brown sugar.  Tastes like brown sugar, dark fruit, and some spice.
Dark copper pour, low head, and medium lacing. Fruity piny aroma. Fizzy with bitter dark fruits. Some caramel with a thick phlegmy mouth. Not bad, a spicy winter.

2009-04-10. Very dark brown body with a nice foamy tan head that fades. (3+) Sweet fruit aroma, mild alcoholic undertones, touch of spice? (7+) Flavour is similar, light spice, malt core is a bit mild, touch of oxidation? Light note of raisins or dark fruit in the finish. Smooth medium bodied palate. Decent. Bottle shared by GregClow

Bottle thanks to Austin. Pours a deep chestnut color with a medium light brown head. The aroma is full fruity malts, some pine and toffee. The flavor is nice; smooth and rich malts, fruity and hazelnut is just about right for the flavor. Light caramel and toffee. Very easygoing with a bit of alcohol warmth. Nice. Like an old ale almost.

Pours beatiful mahogany with a creamy, beige head and good lacings. Nose of burned malt . nuts and caramel. Flavour with malt, light coffee, caramel and notes vanilla. Medium bodied.  Slightly dry finish. Enjoyable

Pours medium brown with a 3 finger ashy light tan head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is earth, wood, cherries, herbal hops, caramel, pine and some nice spicy notes. Flavor is dark fruit, fruit cake, cherry cordial, pine sap, sweet bread, toffee, toasted nuts and a nice almost smokey wood note. Finish is nutty toasted malts. Palate is pretty thick and somewhat slick with a definite alcohol warmth.
Bottle. Very nice winter/holiday beer. Strong spicy, goes down well on a cold winter night.
Tap from Taphouse.  Pours a nice brown with hint of red, but a bit light on the head (couldve been the pour).  Very smooth and I got a nice hint of spice and a nice aftertaste.  Good balanced beer.

Dark, cooked malt flavors on a dark slightly reddish body. Body is light medium or even a tad thinner. Alcohol is apparent in the mouthfeel. No real off flavors but I wonder if this beer cellared as well as I thought it would?

Bottled.  Pours a dark cola colour with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma is sweet toffee, plus a little chocolate. Flavour is nutty, malty in the middle and some nice bitterness in the finish.  Well done.

Pours a nice clear medium ruby/mahogany with a fluffy tan head that leaves spiderweb like lacing... Aroma of sweet malts and a touch of alcohol with notes of raisin, fig, and brown sugar... Taste of sweet toffee/caramel malts with big notes of dark fruits, and a slightly dry mildly hoppy finish... Medium full body... One of my favorite winter beers...
Pours a dark reddish brown with a decent sized head.  Nice malty aroma, caramel, light nuts. Nice sweetness, alcohol isnt noticeable.
Pours hazy reddish brown with a decent sized off white head.  Aroma is sweet and malty.  Flavor is malty and sweet, with a slight roasty flavor and slight bitter finish as well.
This is a full bodied beer with a gentle bite of hops. Not an overbearing taste though.

Color is reddish brown.  Thin off-white head with good retention.  Aroma is caramel and sweet malts.  Flavor is similar, but with a good amount of hoppiness.  Moderately alcoholic and dry in the finish.  Like most Avery beers, it tends a little toward the sweet side.  But still a very nice winter brew.
This brown pour has an off white head.  It smells of sweet dark fruit.  The taste is light and smooth like a good bread with subtle sweet notes and a kick of alcohol.  One fine pour.

Bottle:  Pours a deep amber with a finger of creamy beige head.  Thick lacing.  Smells of piney hops, light citrus, and a touch bready.  Flavor is hoppy yet sweet from a source other than citrus.  A brown sugary, caramel type sweetness...  Toffee and light bready notes.  Finish is a sweet and hoppy flourish.  I found this to be extremely enjoyable and would have this again any time.

Mini growler from Half-Time.  Pours a clear red brown with a hefty light tan head.  Lots of malt, caramel, toffee, and toast on the nose.  Medium bodied and a little sweet, with hints of cereal grains.  Nice warming malt finish with just a touch of hoppy bitterness.

THOUGHTS: Nice until the finish. This will really warm you up on a cold night. A little harsh, but itll probably age well and smooth out a little. I think Ill put a couple away until next year, or at least until a freezing cold night this winter.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, very dark, brownish amber with a small, off-white head that mostly diminished and left fair lacing. There were also tiny particles in the body. The aroma was moderate to heavy nutty malt, very light molasses, raisins, toffee, alcohol, whiskey, hazelnut and when it warmed, light orange hops. The flavor started rather sweet and slightly bitter, and finished bitter, alcoholic and a little acidic with an average to long duration. There was caramel, whiskey, chocolate, coffee, some metallic hops and alcohol. The medium body was a little oily with tingly carbonation and a metallic and light to moderate alcoholic finish.
Dark amber red in color with a small beige head. Aroma is of nuts, caramel and toffee. Taste is of sweet malt, caramel, a light buttered toffee and spicy hops.

35cl bottle, no datings. Slightly flakey ruby red, firm beige head with little lacing. Good strongly nutty malty aroma, some dark dried fruits, liquorice, faint rye, nicely warming. Similar strongly caramelly flavor, herbal hops, liquorice, syrupiness. Finishes with mild warming alcohol, wood and some rust. Almost full bodied, strong lush carbonation. Whoa, just warmed me up inside out, pretty close to a BW even.
Draft 4 oz. Beer Flight at Old Chicago in Peoria, IL.  Dark amber color.  Roasty chocolate comes out as it warms.  You can really taste the alcohol here.

2007 edition on tap at Falling Rock in Denver. Pours a clear amber-red with a small, creamy head. Sharp aroma, of hops, malt, and citrus. Taste is mellow and sharp, of hops, malt, pine, and wood. Lingering slight sharpness. Decent.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Pretty sexy, boozy brew.  Almost tastes like a scotch ale, actually.  Very sweet malts, but plenty of hoppy bitterness and booze.  Alcohol showing through is not a problem.  Actually makes it pretty badass.

Sixer on sale for $5.99 at a local liquor store.  Why the hell not?  Gotta love the post holiday barn sales.  Not a whole lot to say about this one.  Its malty, nutty and a little boozy.  Its perfect for one of those 78 degree winter nights.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear translucent mahogany, with a thick, lasting cap of light tan head that leaves tremendous crusty lace.  Aroma is all deep, dark malts bounding in spicy, nutty, and woody notes with some pronounced fruit notes as it warms.  Full, rich flavor dominated by a toasty malt character but balancing toward bitter and boozy into the finish.  Complex flavor profile, but well balanced; not jumbled.  There are nuts, holiday spices (nutmeg, cinnamon), toffee and vanilla notes.  Medium bodied and smooth, with a very nice warming finish.  I forgot how good this stuff was...just a great example of a winter warmer.
Pours a dark copper color. Aroma is not overpowering of toffee and dull malts. Taste is amazing. Very smooth. Good brew,

Sampled on draught at Dexters in Madison: Pours a deep mahogany colour with a medium sized creamy beige top. Aroma is very nutty with a little burned toast mixed in. Taste is creamy with roasted malts and strong caramel notes on the finish.

Avery 10/10/08 at brewery tasting room. Firkin of dry hopped Old Jubilation. Earthy hop aroma with some alcohol. Cloudy medium brown with frothy white head. Light body and mouthfeel. Dry moderately bitter finish with some warming

12oz brown bottle. Pours a beautiful rich dark mahogany.  Huge, thick, three finger hazelnut colored head which sticks around forever and settles to a thick one finger head. Very sticky lacing.  Aroma is a homerun.  Chocolate desserts, nutmeg, cinnamon, chicory, dates and more chocolate.  Flavor is a huge letdown.  The bitterness is way over present and unwelcoming.  It smells like it will be sweet and decadent but the flavors are unbalanced, the initial flavors and finish are doing way different things.  Not enjoyable on multiple levels.  Mouth feel is fine but the flavor, bitterness and finish kill it.  Disappointing especially because the appearance and aroma were stellar.  I will have to give it another chance sometime because the appearance and aroma alone is worth it.

20oz, draft.  Thick deep brown ale.  Taste of alcohol is very prominent and not in a good way.  there is also something sweet in the brew that is not well complemented by the biting alcohol taste.  Not something I would order again.

Pours a dark cherry or deep, deep burgundy (almost black). Aroma is first of fruit (cherries, raspberries), caramel, and then of some butter. Mouthfeel is medium/heavy almost chewy. Taste is first of sweet malt, followed by some bitterness, and then a spicy finish. What a wonderful seasonal.
Very thick (like a barlywine) and a taste somewhat like a cola. Very filling with a little brandt flavor.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 080109.
Brown with off-white head. Aroma of malt and hop spices. Flavor is of dried fruit, wood, alcohol, caramel and herbs.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2009 Bottle at 52 degrees.  Mild citrus hop aroma, reddish brown color that resembles cherry wood.  Taste is roasty with alcohol, and a short burst of hop bitterness.  Im looking forward to cellaring a couple and opening them in 8 and 14 months from now.  

Updated rating on 8/6/09 (originally rated on 1/7/09):  Pour still produces a decent head.  More malt in the nose than I recall.  Slightly sweeet aroma.  Flavor has improved.  Great balance of toffee malt and pleasant hop bitterness.  Mouthfeel seems to have improved as well.  Overall I bumped this up from a 13 to a 15.  Its very good now.  I wish I could have resisted drinking the others.  Even still, its hard to imagine that too much more age will improve this, but its possible.

This to me wins for the night. Good color of reddish brown. thinnish head that laces really well. Smells strongly of chocolate, caramel, toffee and alcohol with a bit of dark fruit in there. good full flavor of toffee, burnt malt, figs, and caramel.
