Has a somewhat hidden alcohol presence, but not real hidden. Palate is somewhat smooth and a bit syrupy. Finishes with a sort of Barley wine burn. A little. Good good.
Pours a dark copper color.  Aroma is not overpowering of toffee and dull malts.  Taste is amazing. Very smooth and tastes better then the original apperance and aroma.  Good brew, not great.

Poured the beer from the bottle into a pint glass for drinking.  It had a pleasnt aroma with a strong floral hop presence, but also some citrus and pine hops.  A modest caramel malt scent and a little bit of toffee and molasses.  It was a dark, but clear copper-brown color with a big, foamy, off-white head that was quite thick with good retention and slight cling.  It had a brief sweet fruity taste, that quickly became bitter and somewhat sour in the mouth, becoming more bitter and alcoholic as the beer went.  The beer was pretty wet with some good fizz and a medium-density body.  The present of alcohol was noticeable throughout and it had a dry finish that was somewhat rough.  A pretty good beer with some good characteristics and substance.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2017 Poured with a nice large head and good lace. Brownish amber color. I claim an aroma sensory handicap due to sinus problems. With that, I cant smell a lot going on with this beer. Taste is way bigger though. Yum! Very malty, dark fruits, earth, leather, and a bit of toffee. Some booziness. Not really a session beer. Good for a cold snowy night. Pass the bottle.
Update: very similar to last time but better. Carbonation is perhaps a touch too aggressive. Otherwise its just a very nice winter ale.

’08 vintage 12oz bottle from bevmo, encinitas.  Clear darker red/mahagony with medium, long lasting, chunky, tan head.  Sweet dark red fruit with slight carmelization and yeastiness.  Flavor is nutty, yeast, cranberry, toasted malt, orange citrus, nice subtle hop bitterness, i also want to say it has a slight coffiness but it could just be the hop presence.  Medium, well carbonated body.  Very enjoyable and the alc is not even noticable.

Dark red-brown with a tan head. Aroma is delicate and fruity. I smell apples and oranges, and just a bit of yeast. Flavor is malt, yeast, grapefruit, pine. Very nice hop flavor in the finish. I almost want this to have a bigger flavor, but this is fine the way it is. A nice mild, pleasant beer. Very smooth finish. Very good.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of hops, biscuit, toasted malts, slight alcohol, light citrus, light grapefruit, slight yeast, slight pine, and some flowers.  Poured deep orange/brown/deep amber in color with a large, dense, rocky, creamy, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malts, toasting, hops, slight citrus, light chocolate, bread, slight resin, nuts, wood, and some toffee.  Medium body.  Lightly tingly, dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Semi-sweet, malty, woody finish is dry.  8%ABV is very well hidden.

Dark brown pour, nearly opaque, with a huge fluffy white head that lasts forever. Spicy aroma of mixed malts.  Flavor is very robust, malty with a touch of nut. Subtle spiciness - guessing it is not actually spice from the description - that is very warm and rich. Full bodied and delicious.
2008 Bottle - Pours mahogany with a decent off white head...aroma is toasted grain, a bit spicy...flavour is rich malt and alcohol, some dried fruit, finishes bitter...

Bottle.  Dark amber/brownish color.  Smallish white head.  Nice full malt bill on the nose with some spices, fruit and toffee.  Flavor is very nice.  Full flavor with some fruit, rich malts and some nice background hops that get you in the end.  This is well done indeed.
Tap at Pap, 2005 vintage.  Not bad at all.  Tastes like a slightly thicker raisin soda.  Doesnt have the levels of either OSA 03 or Jubelation 05.
Moderately strong malt aroma with some spicy yeast smell. Clear amber color with a medium white head. Light bitter beginning that gets sweet in the finish. Roasted end.
Aroma of toffee, some raisin and spices.  Flavor of hopes and raisins and a bit of a bite in the alcohol aftertaste.  Pretty good.

From a 12 oz bottle this beer pours a nice mahogany with a thin tan head.  Aroma of toffee, dark fruit, malts and some nuttiness.  Taste of hops, maltiness and raisin with some fruit and spice.  Nice winter beer that does not come with an real alcohol finish that some strong dark ales are known for.

Picked up a sixer of this tonight at Market of Choice. Pours a medium brown with a big tan head that leaves nice big lacing. Smells strongly of malt, brown sugar and caramel, lovely aroma. Very sweet and malty flavor with a very creamy finish and aftertaste. Mild hopping. Another tasty one from Avery.

On tap tonight, winter sampling at Acadia.  Nice rich velvety brown pour, little carbonation.  Aroma of caramel and malt.  Taste was interesting, almosty woody, maybe a little bit of bitter juniper aftertaste.  Ok, but dont know if I would drink again.

Bought this bottle off the bargain shelf at my locale homebrew shop, so don’t know what year it was brewed.  It might have been passed its prime.  I am surprised by the rating, the alcohol content and the claim of no spicing.  Very skeptical that the spiciness was made by malt and hops alone.
Medium brown with some head.  Aroma is sweet and malty like an English b-wine.  Tastes a bit hoppy up front, but quickly becomes all malt.  Sort of soapy finish.  Mediocre.

bottle.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is ugh! rotten fruit and stinky feet.  Do not care for the aroma at all.  Taste, however, was better than the smell.  Taste is of nuts, brown sugar and roast malt.  Mouthfeel is medium with some alcohol.  So-so.

12oz bottle from Total Wine (Tampa, FL). Pours a clear amber brown color with thin off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of brown sugar, nuts, some chocolate, maybe hints of ripe dark fruit. Flavor is sweet and malty as well with nuts, some slight hops, roasted malt, some herb and spice notes. Generally medium body with a malty finish.

Poured a dark red with a sturdy tan head. Aromas of brown sugar, burnt sugar and chocolate.  Flavors of bready malt, spicy hops, chocolate and a little bit of dark dried fruit.  Very malty fo sho.  A bit thick and overall one of the best of its style.
A fantastic beer. A creamy taste with a  spicy feel in your throat. This is the beer that will leave you wanting more. It has definitely jumped into my top 10.
While a bit sweet for me, it is a very good beverage.   I will add to this later.

12 oz bottle. Nice brownish/port color-filtered. Small, thick white head. Nose is chocolates, a bit of coffee, sweet. Like #14. Taste is chocolately, very malty, a bit chewy. Seems simple but comes off well. Very warming but not overwhelming. Drinks almost too easy for an 8% beer. Nice.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 29, 2009 Poured an attractive mahogany color with an off-white head that was fairly dense and gave up some decent lacing.  The aroma was heavy on the roasted malt with light chocolate and thin hops.  The flavor was roasty, malty, chocolaty and pretty good.  Decent mouthfeel, slightly dry.  I enjoyed that it did not taste like a standard winter warmer which more often than not ends up tasting like a pale ale with some clove, nutmeg and cinnamon added.  This one is pretty nice.

Draft at the tap room.  Pours a reddish brown with a bit of dirty brown head.  Sugary malt caramel and toffee nose, adn just the slightest bit of herbal hop noes.  Flavor is just kind of one note burnt toasted malt.  I must be missing something.  Medium body with lots of harsh carbonation and a dry finish.  This one seems bland to me.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 Poured deep amber with a tan head. Aroma of malted milk balls candy. Creamy mouthfeel. Taste of sweet malt, caramel and milk chocolate. Like the description says - no spices. Just a big sweet chocolate malt of a winter warmer. Loved it.

pours a ruby brown with a thick off white head. Strong chocolate and lighter fruit aroma. Flavour was very sweet malt, honey, some oatmeal tones? 
I dont think my comments do it justice. Very drinkable and very tasty.

Style and Glass: Strong English Ale, Pint
ABV, Volume & Calories: 8% in 12 fl oz. estimated at 200 C
Purchased at: Issac Newtons, Newtown, PA for $5.00

Aroma: tannins, grapes, malty, sweet, honey, fruity

Visuals: beautiful label, summer sunset, deep, ruby, nice tan head, hazy, long lasting lace.

Taste: well balanced, heavy barley malt, cherry, peach, some hops, good strength.

Palate: high quality, sticky texture, long burnt finish.

Overall: Wonderful, delicious, great flavor & finish. Id love to repeat. Its a favorite. High value. High craft. I paired it with vegetarian chili and a blackened chicken wrap  absolutely delicious, and a very good pairing.

2007, aged it a year.  Great chocolate flavor.  Dry, and a bit thin, but ok.  Hints of cherry shine though.  Soapy lacing.  It feels like it is trying to be a bigger beer than it comes off as.  No flaws, but could have been bigger and better.
Very nice winter beer. Spicy with a hop note  at the end which makes for a great finish. For the most part malty, but kudos to the avery for their malt blend that makes this very enjoyable.

Pours a deep dark brown with a big, thick, tan head. The head is huge and blossoms out of the glass. Aroma is hoppy and sweet. Flavor is very complex. Sweet malts, dark fruits, Rum-soaked fruits, a bit of hops. Rich, creamy mouthfeel with a good amount of carbonation. I picked this up in a mix-6 because I didnt want a full 6-pack of this, but having tried it I realize how wrong I was.

Poured a cola color with orange highlights. The head was tall, creamy and tan in color. There was nice lacing. The aroma was mild. A bit of sweetness, a hint of chocolate and other subtle fragrances. There was a strong flavor of anise initially and a good bit of chocolate too. The taste built to a mild bitterness with a slight sweetness underneath. There was a good complex flavor to this beer. Very enjoyable!!!!

Bottle.  Pours clear, deep brown, with a thin biege head, some lacing.  Big sweet aroma of raisins, figs, molasses, and pine.  Thick, velvety body.  Lots of sweet malt, fruity and toffee flavors, and a dry, slightly bitter edge to the finish.  Has a nice, balanced English character, but a more American hop sensibility.

Probably one of the better "non-spiced" winter beers I’ve had. Solid malt flavor....some nuttiness and under-tones of coffee and toffee. Aroma mainly malty...not much beyond that. Alcohol is decent...can’t really taste it.
Dark red amber, balanced, roasted malts, hoppy, brown sugar, little bready, little nutty, little coffee.

Subtle aromas of the malt - with a sweetness peaking through. Not fruity, not spicy.  Pours a deep red-amber, fluffy head.  There isn’t one flavor that overpowers another. Mostly malty, slightly bitter (hoppy) at the finish but leave a tingly feel on the tip of the tongue from the carbonation.  Full bodied and very drinkable - an English style ale with a hint of a Belgian.

Pours a black/dark brown with an Belgian-esque head.  Aroma of brown sugar and yeast.  A nice combination of sweet and smoked malt flavors with a slight bitterness.  This has a slight Belgian flair to it.  Extremely drinkable.

Pours a nice black/extremely dark mahogany with two fingers of head. Excellent lacing for quite a while.

Smells actually rather fruity with a bit of dark roasted coffee cutting through.

Tastes of a dark fruity almost prune-like flavor with a very hoppy finish. Hoppy and spicier than I expected from a winter warmer. Many complex flavors, too much for my novice taste buds to pick up.

Overall an excellent brew, and was a great way to warm up after coming inside in an Ithaca blizzard. Warms me right up. Probably could be a little less hoppy, but that’s just my taste.


Reviewed on: 02-14-2007
Bottle. Pours amber with off white head. Aroma is nutty and mild hops. Flavor is malty with a hop finish. Flavors of nuts, toffee, small amount of coffee.

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark amber color with a small frothy off white head. The aroma is a sweet hop and nuts. Decent lacing on the glass. The taste is  a sweet fruit, apple with a dry finish. Very drinkable and hides the alcohol well. A very good English Strong Ale from Avery.

Pours the color of maple syrup from the bottle with a silky reddish/tan head.  Brimming with the aroma of blueberries, raspberries, molasses, and hops.  Starts out malty, with a medium body, but builds into a piney alcohol finish that almost sets your mouth on fire.  Very impressive.

Let the doors of Christmas open up, wow. Pours a dark amber with a nice head that recedes quickly. It smells of Christmas spices and caramel. On first taste it is also quick spicy. The spices never quick leave your lips or palate. It is also quite easy to pick up both the aroma and flavor of nuts and toffee. As I said the spice sticks on your palate for a nice warming feel. A very good seasonal.

A deep, dark, red/orange with a dense, long lasting foam.  Minerally/metallic aroma with no hops and low malt.  A very viscous and full bodied mouthfeel.  The flavor is very malty with a subdued hop presence.  A typical winter warmer and not a whole lot of personality

Burnt caramel and molasses nose.  Brown orange color with soapy head.  Chewy sweet malt with just the right amount of bitterness providing  great balance.  Full carbonation, full body, dark caramel finish with a slow warming alcohol burn.  Really one of the better winter style beers out...just a great brew!
Bottle. Poured deep mahogany with a thick lasting white head.  Rich nutty aroma, with a malty bone. Full flavour with some nut and toffee.  Coffee and caramel in the finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Wonderfullly sweet aroma of caramel.  Medium sized white head.  Mohogany appearance which in itself was mouthwatering.  Flavor was sweet with caramel.  Medium bodied.  Wonderfully aromatic and splendid tasting beer. Definately will drink again.

Bottle. Poured reddish dark brown with a creamy beige head. Malty aroma with spicy and nutty notes. Medium bodied. Caramel and dark fruits in flavour and leaves a long malty caramel like finish. Very rich and tastefull ale.

bottle thanks to cocks liquour in witchita falls, tx.  poured a dark brown/ruby with a rocky beige head that stayed leaving some nice lacing behind.  aroma of spice, malt, and liqourice.  flavor was alcohol spice and some nuttiness, chocolate, and caramel.  med body with a dryness at the end.  not bad just not what i was expecting.

bottle.  Pours a deep mahogany, with traces of intense magenta.  Head dissipates surprisingly fast.  Aroma features cherry, wood, plum, caramel malt, and brown sugar.  Carbonation is initially prickly, but palate calms to a smooth, almost syrupy, full-bodied feel that coats the mouth.  Flavor is fruity sweet at first, with a touch of malty undertones.  Mid-palate forwards some cough medicine, more fruit, and some roasts.  Finishes similar, with warming alcohol touch.  Overall, I am impressed by the fullness of this beer, but not sure I really enjoy all the flavor notes present (cherry, sweet roasts, cough medicine, etc).
355 ml bottle at home. Clear mahogany color, nice beige head. Aroma is sweet, spicy, fruity and hoppy. Flavor is sweet, malty, fruit and spices, hints of alcohol, hoppy dry finish. Very nice.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.
Pours a deep amber with great, rocky beige head that left lacing all over the glass. Sweet aroma of malt, fruit, with some alcohol spice. Flavor is nice, sweet, some spice,very slight baking chocolate, caramel, nutty, alcohol spice. Mouthfeel is medium body with medium-high carbonation. Over all, tasty warming ale.

Bottle @ EBF. Amber with an off white head. Sweet malts and caramel, hints of nuts, chocolate and fruits with a little hop character shining through. Not bad but not outstanding either, I’m starting to get the hump with Avery now.
Bottle at EBF08. Good caramelly hop aroma. Clear dark chestnut colour. Small head. The flavour is caramelly, OK spicy hoppiness.

This is a deep rich red colored ale, very little head. The aroma is a wonderful sweet malty scent with a hint of fresh hops, if it taste as good as it smells it will be a very good beer. As for the taste, its fresh with rich maltiness that finishes with a mild hop bitterness. This is a good Winter brew, its rich flavor and mild bitterness is perfectly matched for a cold winter day.

Bottle of the 2006.  Hazy dark brown pour, a very little tan head.  Nice malty aroma.  Some roast and sweet malts, caramel, some roast or smoked nut.  A little earthy/oily.  Kind of a lingering sweet finish, not much hop prescence to speak of.  Reminded me a bit more of a scotch ale than an English strong ale.  I had a Three Floyds Robert the Bruce scotch ale before this one and I thought this was slightly better.  Since I prefer the heavier, less spiced winter ale, I thought this was excellent.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: roasty, burnt toast, coffee, non-hop bitterness kills this beer.  very astringent. head dissipates quickly leaving nice lacing.  With no spices, buttery mouthfeel, this beer was not a fun experience.  Based on the reviews, maybe my bottle was bad, but I won’t rush out to get another one any time soon.
Amber with a thick tan head. Fruity and sour notes. Citrus, bitterness and a touch of stable. High carbonation. Medium to full body with a bittersweet finish.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2013 12oz from Whole Foods, Durham. Funny, but there was a surprising amount of carbonation on the pour and I somehow flashed on root beer. Only in the look, of course, as the caramelly, malty nose immediately jars your senses and prepares you for a solid, flavorful winter warmer. I actually prefer it when these brews have a bit more bite, either from spices or from hops, and found this one just a bit too slick and sweet to rank highly. But its still enjoyable and would not turn it away.
Very nice beer. Had a vertical tasting of this beer at the 15th anniversary. Hay impressed by those: the 2007 version, 2006 and 2004 version on bottle.  I loved it

Amber-brown in colour, creamy and rich beige coloured head, excellent lacing.  The aroma is malty, chalky, some chocolate, plums, high sweetness.  The aroma is malty, rich, sweet with lots of fruit and some chocolate.  Sweet but still some bitterness in the mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes sweet, fruity and malty.
This dries out at the end but it still lacks a bit of what the Fullers Vintage Ales bring.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan.
Opened on February 24, 2008
No date.
Pours a brilliant mahogany with a creamy ecru head.  Aroma of brazil nuts, light spice, and black tea.  Nice flavor; rich but light enough to be quite drinkable.  Very nice.
Like Fullers 1845, this is a seasonal. But like that beer, it is not a traditional spiced holiday ale. It is a well brewed strong ale. Aromas and flavors of toffee, brown sugar, and roasted malts.
Pours a great head, the colour of the beer is dark red. The aroma is malty, with hops and roasted barley. Flavor is very good with roasted barley and hops.
Pours with a MASSIVE head that fluffs like whip cream. Dark brown. Smells of cinnamon, brown sugar, and spices. Warming and sweet with a dry finish.
Pours ruby with a fruitty, sweet malty aroma.  Flavor is chocolate, nuttiness, and smoky bitterness

From the bottle. Pours a beautiful rich ruby brown with a lovely tan head. Aromas of currants and raisins. Nice malty sweetness in the flavor profile with chocolatey,  toffee and nutty characteristics. Nice dry finish with a bit of warming alcohol, great example.
Bottle.  Pours Mahogany brown.  Aroma is malt, chocolate malt. toffee, and dark fruit.  Finish is a bit to bitter and dry for my taste.

Nice dark reddish color. Aroma if fruity and nutty. Mostly sweet malt. Dark fruits, toffee, nuts make up the flavor profile. Perhaps some peppery hops in the finish with a good amount of noticeable alcohol for the percentage. Decent stuff.

They claim no spices but that is hard to believe. Peppery and a not sweet but a candy liccorice aspect that I cant fathom. Woody yet they claim no barrel aging. Very bitter I just wish it had a hint of fruit.

12-ounce bottle. Pours a dark, near-opaque orange-brown with a 3/8-inch head. Nutty, creamy, malty. Pleasant. I was expecting a little more alcohol taste.  This is a good and satisfying beer, but theres something slightly amiss here. I cant quite put my finger on it. Unbalanced, I guess you could say. The different flavors dont synergize like they would from a "great" beer. It seems that Avery gets so close to that world-class level without actually breaking through to it. They made very good beers, not "great" beers, in my humble opinion. As is the case here.
Flaske. Mørk ravfarvet øl. Diskret duft af humle og en del malt. Ikke sød men maltdomineret med en skarp eftersmag af humle. Bitter metalisk. Udmærket velkomponeret bryg.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear dark amber with a thin off-white head that disappeared after the first two sips and left very little lace.  Light malty aroma with not much else detected.  The flavor is sweet malt up front, but is also fairly timid.  A moderate alcohol burn kicks in towards the finish.  Peppery at the swallow, which lingers for a bit afterwards.  Not a bad beer, just not something Id go back to.

I really enjoyed this beer, and it used to be something that I did not really enjoy, just to show how your palate can change over the years.  I like the nuttiness that melts into the malt profile, this is the kind of Christmas ale that I like to drink, this is what I think of, not something overly spiced, this is just right for the winter.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 Beautiful deep brown/amber color.  2 finger head. Sweet caramel malt with a little pear nose.  Heavier and more complex then I would have expected.  Malty taste, sweet, more creamy mouthfeel then a brown ale but similar initial taste.  Flavor turns roasted chocolate at finish with very little bitterness.  you can tell a lot of thought went into the choice of malts.  Very good beer.  I would drink again.

Pours a dark brown with a thin head.  Nice sweet malt flavor and some caramel.  A very tasty beer.  Well balanced with minimal carbonation.  Actually a lot better beer then I thought it was going to be.

Pours very dark clear brown with a frothy tan head. Aromas of burnt malts and coffee. Sweet flavor to start with a bitter finish. Full body with minimal carbonation and a silky mouthfeel and a slight alcohol taste. Very smooth drinking.

Foamy head and an odd malty aroma with a hint of herbs.  Nice winter scene on the label.  Tastes something like a sweet porter - nice hops plus hints of nuts, herbs, lemon, and maybe some coriander?  I was surprised to see from the brewers description that there are no spices added.  I am beginning to develop a healthy respect for Avery Brewing.

Poured a deep copper with a creamy beige head that lingered for several minutes. Big hops on the nose with undertones of caramel or choclolate.  Hops almost overpower the malt in the mouth, but the slightly sweet malty finish saved it for me.... Later.... the malts seem to be asserting themselves more against the hops as the beer warms in the glass.
Brown with medium off white head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, chocolate and ripe fruits. Sweet flavor that holds roasted malt, dark bitter chocolate and prunes.
Good color,small head, nice nose, pleasant lingering bitterness, a good winter type, which I think tastes better from the keg rather than the bottle. I like it.

12 fl oz. Pours slight hazy deep amber with a tan head. Light woody and fruity aroma. Flavour is sweet, hoppy with a liqourice note. Light woody note and a light hops bitterness and dryness into the finish. Light woody note in the far finish.

Pours brown with an almost white head. Flavor is full of leathery malts, with a very smoky finish. This is a very good beer. Not much lingering on the aftertaste, but it makes its statement in full flavor - very refined, like a single malt scotch.

Served cold from a bottle, pours a dark reddish brown with a nice tan-colored head. The aroma includes malts, but anything other than that i cant quite discern. the flavor is wonderful upon first taste, but the aftertaste is a little dry and bitter. Its a fine beer, but not exemplary.
12 ounce bottle purchased at The Corner Store West Palm Beach, FL for $3.50 Very good.

2006 bottle courtesy of drewbeerme.  Pours a clear deep mahogany color with a nice 2 finger chunky beige head.  Nose is caramel, and at first, a slight sour vegetable smell (like V8 juice  I know, thats crazy talk!)  Nose opens to malt as it warms.  Palate is caramel, nuts, and malt.  Medium mouth feel with great lacing.  I liked this more than I thought I would  not too bad.
Reddish in color, almost brown with a decent tan head.  Slight nuttiness in the aroma.  Medium body.  Slight alcohol.  Dry finish.  Some bitterness.
Dark amber with a solid head. Fruity  and spicy aroma, with flavours of toffee, caramel, coffee and chocolate. Some bitterness towards the ending makes this a fine strong ale!

Bottle. Huge thick creamy beige head that mostly lasted. Clear sparkling body with a pale nut-brown color. Good display of lacework. Aroma of toasted malt, bread, caramel, fruit, dried fruit, grain and mild hoppy feel. Over the palate came floral and light pin notes with a hint of alcoholic sharpness. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and light dry texture. Light to moderated bitter flavor with light counter sweetness. Dry and bitter hoppy finish.

Light brown, small compact head with some laces, carbonation is rather low. Sugar-candy, vanilla, rhum soaked fruit cake, caramel, ruby-red grapefruit and a bit spicy (nutmeg?). Well balanced, starts candy sweet then the hops deploy their presence with grace and elegance; never is it too sweet nor too bitter, yet the bitterness lasts for quite a long time. The body is round enough to be satisfying but the beer never feels heavy. Surprisingly refreshing, still credible as a digestive. Very enjoyable!

Bottle poured into a chalice produced fingers of tan head that goes to a sparse lace on top of a dark mahogany  

Aromas of malts, candy sugar and spices filled my nose

This beer is rather hot (alcohol) and bitter which is a surprise to me because of its nose 

The mouthfeel is not as rich as I would like on this one but it is smooth on the palette 

Its an ok warmer but one at a time is enough
dark brown with reddish highlights, thick tan head.  malty fruit in the nose.  fruit in the flavor mixed with chocolate and a bit of evergreen bitterness.  finishes bitter.  a likeable brew.

Handsomely dark pour with slight beige head.  No winter spices, but something still wintery about it.  I feel like theres still a faint hint of coriander, but maybe its just phantom because I expect it to be there.  This is a favorite winter brew for me.  Toasty, malty, sweet, slightly smoky aroma... almost porter-like on the nose.  Nice and malty taste with caramel and toffee notes, with still enough hops to stay balanced.  Gets better as it warms up slightly.  Yum.

Pours tall head, which collapses normally. Not too fast. Not too slow. Seems very carbonated. Dark brown, with hints of dark cherry color when held up to a light source. Wonderful aroma. Again, reminds me of cherries though perhaps that is what theyre calling the hint of hazelnuts. More than a hint to me. VERY nice flavor. Not overly hoppy and on the malty side for sure. Definately taste the hazelnut flavor they talk about. Not cloyingly sweet. Lightly roasted malts hang around on the pallate. Hides the 8% alc. well in its body, though as the beer warms up it does come out a little more pronounced. Overall, Id definately put this on the buy again list. Wish Id had this earlier in the season so I couldve known to buy a whole six-pack!

Bottle. Clear dark copper/brown. Thick tan head, leaving striped lacing. Sweet and rich malty aroma, somewhere between caramel and molasses. Sweet but not cloying dark malt flavors, slightly roasty/toasty coffee/chocolate with a bit of a plummy dried fruit tang in the background. Some darkly toasted nut bitteness in the finish. Alcohol clandestine. Nice straightforward X-mas ale which is not unnecessarily gussied up with the traditional spices.

pleasant dark red coloring with a little lacing on the glass. Nutty, malty and spicy taste with a rounded, almost oily mouth feel. A nice winter beer. Would go good with beef tips or a nutty cheese, or maybe nuts.

In short: A good caramel/toffee malt backbone but overly spicy.  Quickly gets sickening.
How: Bottle, 3+ months old.  From dmac621, thanks Dave.
The look: Dark ruby body with a medium beige head leaving very good lacing
In long: Rich malted body with caramel and toffee.  But the spices man, they just went overboard with the spices.  Cinnamon, nutmeg, basil and whole bunch more.  Just too much of it.  It took over everything.  Felt as if my bottle was filled with the end of a keg with all the spices deposit.  Bad bottle?  I dont know but one thing for sure this bottle didnt suit me at all.  Not enough shoulder room and my feet were all squeezed.

pours a rich reddish brown (some say mahogany) with a tan head that leaves lots of lacing. aroma is a combination of light fruity sweetness, caramel, grain, wood, spice and a mild sourness. the flavor is really malty along with toffee, cinnamon/spice, chocolate, raisins and some herbal woodiness. lightly bitter yeasty finish as alcohol peeks its head in. medium body that is not sticky and develops creaminess when its sloshed around...

12oz bottle.  Very deep brown-black color, with a deep amber shade when held to light.   This one is full bodied and complex.  Brown sugar and alcohol aroma.   Sweet and a little hoppy like a Barleywine, but more drinkable.  Deep and malty like a Dopplebock, but toffee flavors and ale yeast characteristics come through making it certainly not classifiable as such.  All in all a great original winter beer.
Pours a  medium brown with a nice bubbly head. Smells like malt, hops and some caramel. Flavor of hops, citrus, chocolate, coffee, malt. My taste buds are confused, but I like it.

bottle poured a cola like in color with a one finger head that settled to a thick light tan layer on the surface. aroma has plenty of malt, caramel, toffee, and some wonderful flowery hops. mouth feel is medium light with some thickness and coats the tongue. the flavor has some sweetness and a nice combination of malts, plenty of toffee and light peppery spice. nice flavor for a winter ale finishing with bitterness on the sides of the tongue and some sweet malted thickness. a very easy drinking brew that hides the 8% very well. really enjoyed this one.
Pretty good beer! Pours a amber brown color with a light head. Smells of winter time with the hints of hazelnut in the nose. Taste of  mocha and and carmel. Delicious beer!
12 oz bottle.  Poures a huge head.  Aroma of caramel and toffee.  Good mouthfeel and aftertaste.  Hops are present.  very delecious beer.  Would drink again.
Pours a dark amber with a thick tan head and some nice lacing.  Aromas of nuts, coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is the same, with dark fruit and a great palate.  Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2008 pours a clear ruby-amber with a tannish head.  aroma is hoppy, lightly nutty, some toffee and some toasty malt and a bit of straw.  taste is toffee, light caramel, some hops, toasty notes, some nuts.  mid-full bodied with a creamy/sudsy mouthfeel.  leaves a layer of bitter on the palate.  nice bitter finish.  alcohol is nicely blended, and there’s some nice lacing.  quite nice, very drinkable.  not uber-complex or overpowering, but has a nice taste.  would fit great into a session.

Jan. 2007 - Dark brown pour, two finger head and really nice lacing.  Flavor dominated by dark roasted malts with some nuttiness...very little sweetness or alcohol noticeable.  Very simple in character...I must have had a muted version of this, because all the goodies other people are commenting on just werent there for me.  Nonetheless, it was a solid sipping brew that I enjoyed.

Tasted 2/11/08.  12oz bottle.  Either a 2005 0r 2006.  Filtered with a deep dark ruby brown hue.  Spiraling taupe head.  Aromas of alcohol, plums and raisins.  Bready and dark berries.  Resinous grassy hop undertone.  Full bodied with a sweet sticky palate.  Tart fruit flavors.  Good alcohol with a wonderfullly rolling palate.  Cellar temperature.  Dark fruit and dark chocolate.  Bready and a touch citrus fruit.  Nutty and tangy.  Peppery resinous hop finish.  Nice alcohol warming sensation.  Mild effervescence.  Caramel flavor with a touch too heavy on the burn, but still a very nice seasonal!

Bottled, pours deep brown with a copper hue. A thin hint of vanilla colored head and lacing for the first few minutes. Subtle aroma of peppery caramel, raisin and almond with some wet hop notes. Sweet toffee and chocolate malt flavors are prominent, with a good bitter punch towards the end. Some orange citrus is noticeable in the palate, including some French vanilla latte. I get a bit of a metallic sting with the carbonation. Easy to drink for 8%. Not bad.

Pours a clear dark brown with a creme head that rises and falls just about as fast. Nice caramel laiden sweet nose. Flavor profile is nice. Nice smooth sweet tones with woody after edges to it. Smooth liquid feel and a biting carbonation. Very easy to drink. A nice winter warmer.
12 oz. bottle, pours a large tan head that falls to a 1/2" of heavy lacing, pruny fruit nose with slight bitter taste and some nocello liquer flavor

dark mahogany color, small tn head, good lacing. Aroma is very nutty, notes of hazelnuts, plums, freash baked raisin bread. Wow, i could smell this all day, such a beautiful aroma. Flavour is malty, with again, a good amount of nutty flavours. Lots of hazelnut, and some almond. NIce bready notes in the finish with some ripe fruit. Wow, this is an incredible beeer! I love this!

Tobacco spit brown with pillowy, frothy eggnog head. Nutty aroma, slightly sour and a little hint of something Im not altogether fond of. Light coffee roast, dates, raisins. Smooth nutty flavor, again with some medium roast coffee. Quite a bit of malt complexity in this one. Slightly salty too, with a bit of a metallic edge. Dryingly roasty finish with some dark chocolate mixed in, warming. Pretty unique and good.

Pours an amber color with a frothy tannish head and lacing. Aroma is floral, roasted malt, chocolate, nuts and prunes. Plethora of flavors including toasted malts, toffee, nuts, fruit and some coffee. A bit of a warming sensation in the finish. Short nutty dry finish. Very smooth texture.

Bottle. Bright, rich maroonish/red color. A midsized white head. The nose is just a touch of malt, but very thin. Sweet malty flavor, honey, nuts, and maybe a bit of candy. It finishes with more alcohol burn than Id wanted from a beer this thin. A fizzier than normal mouthfeel. I expected more from this one.

Not a unique style of ale this time of year - nice to find one as well executed as this. Rich bready malt base that is just slightly sweet with a plethora of winter notes from toffee to roasty chocolate. I like the fact that there are no spices added, does not shock ones palate and just contiunes to smooth as it warms.  Alcohol almost undetectable.

Pours a rich mahogany with a substantial head and great lacing. Pleasant aroma of toffee with a hint of burnt caramel. Taste is a complexity of molasses and apricots. The hazelnut flavor surfaces at the very end. Nice, silky mouthfeel. Finish is a little too bitter, and the alcohol raises its ugly head right at the end.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2008 Dark brown with ruby.  Head is big and airy; dissipating expediently.  Dark fruit aroma of prunes and rum raisin with molasses and some roastiness.  Some alcohol in nose as well.  Taste is similar but with "cough syrup" (as one reviewer astutely opined) towards the end.  Finish is a nasty combination of alcohol and cough syrup.  Hibernation Ale is much better.

Pours an elegant mahogany color with creamy off white head.  Nice lacing.  Sweet brown sugar aroma with hints of toffee, brewers grain, vanilla, chocolate malt, and hazelnut.  Flavor contains vanilla, hazelnut, cola, toffee, and slight floral hop bitterness.  Im pleasantly surprised.

12 oz. bottle from Gregis.  Pour is ruby brown with a nice off white head.  Aroma of sweet dried fruit, biscuit malt and some nuttiness.  Taste has all of the elements of the nose, sweet, malty and nutty.  The taste and the finish are extremely dry.  Over the taste seems a bit disjointed.  The palate felt a bit thin for the size of the beer.  Despite this, I really could not detect any heat.  Overall, decent but nothing to get terribly excited about.  Thanks Greg!

Special thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Smells sweet and fruity with cookie malts, cherries and hazlenut. Beautiful dark red-brown color with some small particles floating around. There is a small creamy head with excellent lacing. Taste is of chocolate malts and is somewhat bitter at the end. Taste reminds me of a Porter a bit. Medium to full body with a dry mouthfeel and a bit too fizzy carbonation. Overall very good!
Dark ruby brown, very nutty pistachio, malty aroma. Malty nutty, candied fruit flavor. Very well balanced.
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2008 I wasnt hugely impressed by this one. Not bad by any means but probably wouldnt buy again.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: 12 ounce bottle.  Deep amber color and pour with an off-white head.  Very flavorful beer- I taste molasses, candy sugar, plum? notes, with some woody taste.  Very interesting beer.  One of the best Christmas beers I have had so far.

12oz bottle from ucusty. Nearly opaque mahogany pour with a large and quite rocky white head. Fruitcake, nuts, candy sugar and bready yeast on the nose. Plenty of oddly put together malt. Quite dry on the tongue. Plenty of crusty and bready malt. Wood, almonds cough syrup and alcohol. Interesting but not integrated all that well and all over the map.

Bottle.  Dark red-brown pour with a fine off-white head.  Aroma is spicy and bready, caramel, toffee, smoked meat?  Flavor is alright - hops and malts balance each other well.  Bitter almonds, dark fruit.  Slightly tinny right before the finish.  Not bad, but not exceptional.

12 oz bottle-Pours a mohogany red color w/almost no head but decent lacing. Faint malt aroma. This one was a disappointment, just didnt wow me or live up to the hype. Had some malt flavor to it, traces of caramel & toffee, but I just felt it was a little lacking. Not bad, just kind of bland. Averys always seem to be kind of hit or miss to me & Id have to call this one more of a miss. Id drink it if offered, but I wouldnt buy it again.

Pours a deep color like a cola.  Some red hues.  Aroma is amazing.  Smells like the condensed liquid malt home brewers sometimes use.  Deep rich and syrupy malt aroma.  Flavor is exactly the same.  Rich, malty and bursting with flavor...mocha, molasses and maybe carmel.  I dont even get a hint of hops.  Just wonderful malts.  I like this one alot.

Bottle. Pours rich mahogany with red highlights. Poured into a Trappist so barely any head formed but a white ring is left to collect around the rim. Aromas of toffee, roasted malts, over ripened fruits, a hint of coffee beans, mocha, and alcohol. Flavor is so malty and absolutely perfect for the season. Rich with toffee, molasses, more mocha, prunes, and roasted malt fading to a nutty malt backbone. Hops appear towards the finish with some hints of brown sugar and caramel malt. Alcohol is present throughout its entirety but never once attempts to overpower the rich malt characteristics of this brew. Medium-Full bodied with a slight twinge of carbonation. Smooth and easy drinking, but rather filling.

12 oz. bottle from 2004. Pours a clear light brown hue with a two finger head; Nice lacing. Smells of sweet malts and alcohol. Medium bodied with a rich, full mouthfeel. Very fine flavor of roasted malts, spices and caramel. Slight bitter hop/alcohol taste to finish. Jan 2005
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours a dark red with off white head. THe Aroma is sweet and nutty. The flavor has a mild bitterness and hints of fruit. Really enjoyable.

pours brownish with fairly good, but fading head.  Dusty malts and chewy caramel, vanilla and fruit (berry, cherry, figs)notes come off and move into a drynig tart flavor that is typical of the style.  A light woody dryness echoes in the back of the palate.  Enjoyable.  A nice winter brew and a good fireplace beer.
Bottle.  Amber pour with small lacing.  Nice molasses aroma upon opening, very nice.  Big fan of Holiday beers, this is a nice offering.

Pours reddish brown, small head. Caramel malt, roasted malt, coffee aroma. Thick malt taste, chocolate, spices, hint of dark fruit, and caramel malt . Finish very nice, well balanced. A good winter warmer.

12 oz. glass bottle- color of brownish red, with a tan colored head - nose of hops, dried vegetation, and red cherries  taste of hops, sweet, lime zest, alcohol, and syrup- body is medium, and robust , and with low carbonation  aftertaste of red fruit, citrus zest, and hops
Red- brown color, with a medium sized tan head. Nose is malty with molasses. Malty, caramel, cookie taste.  Very nice.
Deep copper red pour with creamy white lace. Deep malt aroma and an almost mollasses. Deep fruitiness with abv and dried fruit. Creamy rich mouthfeel. Full flavored full bodied solid all round.

12 oz bottle. Deep red color. Clean perfumed aroma with caramel, vanilla and fruity yesters. Thick and viscous palate with sweet caramelly flavor, dark sugar and toffee. Warming and slightly roasty finish, nice finish. Not excatly my cup of beer, but well made.

(Bottle) Pours a dark brown color with some beige head. Aroma of dark malts and caramel. Taste includes dark fruits, hazelnut, and hops. Not very bitter. Distinct alcoholic aroma and taste. Good palate, and low carbonation. It was all right.

Poured from a bottle.  Poured a deep brown color with a moderate off-white head that left decent lacing.  Aroma of caramel and spices.  Strong malt entry with hints of caramel, toffee, nuts, and spices that lead into a soft, bitter finish.  Nice and smooth on the palate.  Alcohol is not noticeable.  Enjoyed it more than I thought I would.

Pours a deep brown with a touch of red. Thin, tan, quickly dissapearing head. Nose is quite nice with dried fruit and sweet malt. Flavor is malt-rich with hints of toffee, caramel and molasses. A touch of earthiness peaks through as well. Very subtle bitterness finishes it off.

Pours a dark red/brown with a one-finger head that stuck around for a while.  Aroma of fruit and malt.  Strong malt flavor with a semi-dry, caramel finish.  Nice creamy palate.  Overall one of my favorite seasonals.  Excellent winter brew!

Hell, yeah!!!  Loved this stuff!

Nice brown color with a lingering head.  Looks really good.

Smells fruity as all get out with a nice malty background to it.  Now this is what I want out of a winter beer.

Wonderful sweet dark fruity taste with just a hint of malts to it and a finish that bites a little.  

Man, this is good stuff.  This is the best winter beer Ive tried in a while.  Still like the Celebration Ale from SN better but hey, Im a hophead.  Still a solid-ass beer from a brewer that seems to be coming on.

A little hoppy, but malts balance out well.  Poured well and had a light aroma that was pleasing.  Caramel is definitely present; Not bad for an aftertaste; a little alcohol taste after half a botlle.  Will drink again!

Pours a nice mahogany with a creamy beige head that stays around a while before it diminishes, leaving only a thin cap at the surface and creamy lace marking its retreat. The nose is a round malty front with a backing of earthy and lightly spicy hops. Medium-bodied with creamy, soft carbonation, the palate segues to a tight bitter finish and a touch of alcohol on the exhale. A solid, toasty malt front transitions to a well balanced, moderately hoppy finish. (Behind the big, malty body, I cant distinguish any specific hop variety, but their unmistakably bitter presence is a nice component of the finish.) This is a fairly tasty holiday ale. Ill have to hide a few bottles away to see how well it cellars.
Pours a dark chocolate maple syrup.  Smoked aroma with malt.  Very smooth, small hint of alcohol. Great taste of smoked caramel.

12oz bottle.  Has a woodise toffee nose.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Sweet carmel malt with a slight bitter balance.  Medium lasting dryness.  A smooth beer.  Almost tastes like it has spices.  Easy to drink.

Draft at Taco Mac. Pours dark brown with garnet highlights and an off-white head. (bar served it with virtually no head). The aroma is rich with chocolate, maple, and alcohol. The flavor starts rich, malty, and complex: maple, toffee, chocolate, and roasted grains. A mild hop bitterness begins to balance the maltiness around mid-palate. The finish is dry and roasty - and very bittersweet. The mouthfeel is full-bodied and very creamy. Overall, a pleasant beer, but I prefer some of their others...

Draft at Beer Engine ... Dark, almost mahogany, pour with an off white head.  No spice, which is not always my idea of a Winter Ale, except for the Celebration Ale.  Nutty and sweet, enjoyable but not something I would have more than one of.

Draft @BSP. Pours a nice light ruby with faint beige highlights and a decent, receding off-white head.  Nose is perfumy, like marzipan or oxidized wine.  Pretty light on the palate, strong toffee/hazelnut alcohol warms the palate and leaves a slight hop tingle in the finish. Pleasant.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of cereal and roasted, light notes of resin and dough, with raisin, brown sugar and cola in the background. Head is small white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is a clear dark reddish brown. Flavor starts heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and bitter and lightly acidic. Palate is medium bodied, between creamy and syrupy in texture and has a lively carbonation. A very nice malt dominant beer with no hint of the 8% alcohol. Wintery indeed.
This is a beautiful deep golden red ale. Frothy head that remains till the last. Strong spice flavors that do not linger very long. Very nice blend of malt, beer goodness and spices..

12 oz in a winter seasonals 12pk.  Pours a dark amber/light brown with  tannish head and good lacing.  Aroma is hops, malt, bread.  Taste is malty, earthy, nutty, and a surprising hoppy bite.   Alcohol is well hidden, this is nice  and unique beer - its unique because its simple, no spices. Very nice.

Pours with a tan head and a mahogany body (yeah I know that is what they officially say, but it is true). Malty and doughy aroma. The taste is pretty strong with a thick body. Heavy on the malts, almost a salty sort of finish. Little bit of hops do that I think. Heavy alcohol content completely unnoticeable. Little nutty with roasted flavors on the side.
Ruby brown color crowned by thick white foam. Sweet malty yeasty aroma. Taste is piney with noticable ginger. Palate is crisp. Sharp hoppy bite. Nice blend of maltiness and spiciness.

2007 version - brilliantine Mahogay with thin creamy tan head...and nice long legs
Aroma: Some treacle/toffee like notes with sherry like leaning towards tart notes
Flavor: medium-rich Malt complexity leaning towards dark malts with nutty and dark fruits (dates and dark raisins) with nice balance of spicy hop flavor.
Finish: Creamy, cocoa power and long with sizeable alcoholic warmth 
Overall: I think this is a very well made beer... I know Strong Ales should have some alcoholic warmth... in this sample I am picking up some higher alcohols and the sherry notes dont seem balanced with the age of sample. If this is usual, maybe wait a while before trying it.

Pours clear brown with a medium head.  Aroma is caramel, nuts and some grassy hops.  Palette is lively with a good amount of carbonation. Flavor is a nice blend of sweet malt and bitter hops.  Some roasted flavors are present, but there is no signs of the hazelnut mentioned in the description.  Nonetheless, this is a very good beer and goes down far to easy considering its abv.
Pours nicely a deep amber brown color, with little carbonation and not much foam. The aroma is of hops and bitter. The taste is nutty and bitter. Not my favorite.

Bottle, pours dark brown with a nicely lasting head that has a tan color. Brown malts, slight roast, Nice taste of roasts, just slightly bitter not too sweet. Pretty solid, quite enjoyable and really 8%  I couldnt taste any alcohol.

Poured a dark ruby with a nice little head on top.  Malty dark fruit in the nose.  Tastes similar,  a bit of hops.  Luckily I couldnt find any hazelnut in this,  not my thing.  Finished a tad watery but the alcohol wasnt anywhere to be found.  Should have bought a six pack.

Nice malty English strong ale. Malty and richer than most English beers Ive had. Bit of coffee and nut taste. But I did expect the typical spiced winter warmer. None of that is here. Im a bit sorry I only had one sent to me.
Bottle. Delicious strong beer with the alcohol hidden well. A solid no thrills beer, and thats why I love it.

Pours a dark mahogany color with a white fizzy head. Smells of nuts and a bit of roasted coffee. Taste is sweet but smokey. Actually pretty good beer but the finish is short and the taste is a bit unbalanced.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Wonderfull dark amber-red 
colour. Moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Light chocolate notes. Fantastic powerfull heavy bitter flavor. Nice complex notes of hopps and chocolate. Creamy palate. Really great beer.

A good strong ale. You can really taste the difference between the hop heavy American strong and the more balanced English strong in this one. The malts are very pleasant here, sort of creamy and amber tasting.

12 oz bottle poured into trappist glass- poured semi transparent, very dark amber color, decent lacing head.  Aroma of nuts, malt, and toffee.  Hits the mouth with a full medium body, malt, slight hop finish with milky overtones.  Very enjoyable and warming.

12 oz bottle purchased at Spirits RB. Pours a deep dark cocoa brown  with some burgundy hues on the edges and a small off white head. Aroma of cocoa powder, cola, tea and cooked vegtables. Medium bodied with average carbonation and a slight milky feel. Flavor of chocolate and cooked vegtables, not a good combination. I found this beer to be a huge let down from one of my favorite brewers. Bah hum bug.

Pours brown with a decent off white/tan head.  Smells of earth, some tea, dark fruit.  Tastes of spice, caramel, raisins, boozy, some tea.  Mouthfeel is full bodied.  Finish yields some alcohol that interferes with an otherwise enjoyable experience.

12 oz. bottle. Clear, dark, coppery brown producing a substantial sand colored head with excellent durability and a fine, sticky, lace. Aromas of roasted malts, burnt caramel, pine, and spice. Medium body and light carbonations with some sharpness, but a clean palate, nicely dry. Spicy, peppery bitterness is up front over a background of burnt sugar. Not an overly sweet winter seasonal like many, this has a nice bite to it.

Bottle. This one is an 06. Pours a deep mahogany. Aroma is of roasty malts. Flavor comes in very malty and roasty with some caramel and toffee like sugar and a hint of nut. Pretty heavy on the alcohol in flavor and feel. Creamy and a little syrupy but mouthfeel isnt bad. Not a bad seasonal at all.
Pours brown with tan fluffy head.  Smells of caramel and spice.  Flavor of roasted nuts(filberts?), spice, and prune.  Very balanced and not overly spiced like many winter ales.

11-20-07 bottle 
Watery thin brown color.  Strange smell of funky malt.  Gross taste and mouthfeel.  Metallic and has a strong alcohol flavor. It has a sweet alcohol aftertaste that somewhat stings the tongue.  Difficult to swallow this weak bodied, strong alcohol flavored brew.

Aroma hints are somewhat od and fruity, like old fashioned candy. Dark color, like cola or dark cream soda. Strong big ale flavors. Alky and offensive. Be prepared to jubilate after a few of these. In your face annoyng manners. Cannot get thru the flavors to check out the mild carbonation. Too strong for my lager lovin girlie taste buds. Mildl~medium lingering bitter malt intimidating finish.  Sorry, Im not good enough for this brew, save it for the imlerialistics.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: very dark amber with ruby colors and a small head.  nice scent of malts and a slight bit of hops.  very nice thickness and very well balanced between the malts and hops.
Like the commercial discrimption, a mahogany color, aroma mocha/ coffee.  A very nice beer to drink on a cold night.  Had a slight cold so could not fully apprciate.

This was a very good ESA compared to probably every other one Ive had lately. I associate this style with the gold imperial pilsener style beers and this was not that. Pour was a nice medium brown/red with a 1 finger white head. Aroma of roasted malt with little chocolate undertones. Taste was nice and rich. Dark and caramel malt with good carbonation. Nutty and almost toffee flavor in the aftertaste. A good beer, and one of the best (if not the best) ESA Ive had. Makes me realize there is more to this style than Santas bad helpers.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This dark ruby colored brew has a coffee / mocha flavor with a weird tasting finish which is partly due to the alcohol, which isnt hidden real well in this beer.  I like its warming qualities which a winter beer should have, however I dont like the finish which is....VERY STRANGE.

Clear dark ruby colored pour.  Smell is slightly chocolately malt but not a rich roasty chocolate smell.  Taste is the same, except with an unpleasant alcohol taste to finish.  No need for this to taste as alcoholic as it does, and it really detracts from the decent flavor.  Still, overall its thin, boring and the alcohol doesnt fit well.  Unimpressed.
The smell is floral and toasted malt. The color is light copper hue. The taste is full body malty hoppy beer. With a clean and easy finish. Enjoyed this spicy christmas ale.

(bottle): Pours a reddish-brown color, fizzy. Huge tan head, okay lacing, foamy. Not too strong an aroma. Some grapefruit & hops, but very weak. Malt, coffee flavor, watery, smoky. Some spices. English alcoholy taste. Coffee aftertaste, almost porter-like.

Bottle:  Dark brown pour consisting of a wispy tan head.  Candied sugar, dark roasted english malt and some earthiness in the aroma.  Sweet, dark malt-bomb with some chocolate and spiced fruit accents.  Medium bodied.  Good stuff.

bottle.  A good ale from Avery (one of my favorite breweries)... a little disappointed in this one... I dont know what I was expecting really but was very surprised at what I tasted.... a ton of plums.  They could call this plum ale because the plum aroma and taste took over this beer - but it was good, just very different.  Other aromas and flavors of malts shined through.  It was a bit weak on the palate and in the finish.  Would not buy again, but glad I had one.

Its refreshing to find a winter wamer that isnt burdened by obligatory spices.  The right combination of different malts.  Well made strong ale that doesnt remind the taste buds that its 8%.  Well done.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2007 I love it when the holidays roll in and we get to buy this beer!  A deep amber color and a darker lacy head.  It has a very nutty, alcohol flavor that makes you want to move on to the next bottle.  Happy Holidays.
Deep red/brown pour. Very tasty, enjoyable rich maltyness balance well with some hops.  Want to try cellaring this and see how it tastes in a couple of years.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass. Deep reddish with lasting flat head and lace.  Malty, earthy, winey, sugary aroma.  Fruity sugary winey flavor with mild bitterness.  Medium-full body and medium carb.  Somewhat like a mild english barleywine.  Pretty good.
06 Version courtesy of jimbowood.  Flavor of toffee and caramel.  Warming alcohol aftertaste.  Wish there was more punch to this one.
When cold the thick caramel sweetness is in discord with the bitter hop but as it warms it starts to make more sense...but not a whole lot.

Aroma of toffee and nut. Beautiful garnet color with an off-white head that laced while collapsing. Thin to medium body with mild carbonation. The flavor is dark caramel with bread and citrus. The flavor is fairly dry considering the maltiness, with mild bitter and hints of coffee. Very tasty.

This beer has an odd yet familiar aroma. The chestnut, molasses, and granola notes combine to create a bouquet that is very much like the cereal Grapenuts. Brown color, thin tan head. Roasted chestnut and toffee flavor with a weak raisin finish.

Pours a burnished red amber with a thin to medium light tan head. The aroma is sweet candied fruit, molasses, caramel, citrusy hops . The flavor is sweet, caramel, grapefruit peel hops, nice waxy aftertaste, dry alcohol, a very nice winter warmer.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 Pours a monstrous sustaining 1.5 inch tan head over a very dark amber/brown body. Strong nose of coffee, roasted nuts, and chocolate malts.  Flavors continue with more coffee, malts, candy sugar, cocoa, caramel, oak, and toffee. Mild hops in the palate. Medium/hard carbonation and full body. A pleasing and warming mouthfeel combined with robust flavors aid in alcohol concealment. A very nice ale for snowy nights that are the things of fantasy down here.

Bottle. Pours with a brown and slightly red color. Great flavors of malts and spiciness. It is amazing that Adam got this flavor without using any spices.
This explians that the spices are not overpowering, there is still a very comforting cartamel and toffee backbone. ALcohol is not noticeable,this beer sneaks up on you.
Pour is a reddish copper with off-white slightly fizzy head.  Sweet malt, dark fruit, bread, metallic hops, and caramel.  Pretty good, but not really my style (to much harsh metallic flavor).

Nice purplish-ruby pour with some light pink in the head.  Aroma has some dark fruit, candy, honey, and baking bread.  Flavor has a nice dark fruit/bread sweetness to it that is sugary, but not medicinal.  Light but pleasant mouthfeel.  Kind of like a "light" barleywine - nice!
12 oz. Dark chestnut with ruby highlights. Aroma is peanut butter fudge and dry grass. Flavor is earthy, woody, and nutty. Great balance. Palate is nearly medium, and dryish.
Brown with lasting beige head.Deep earthy nose. Earty malt profile with a light fresh hop finish

12-oz. Black with a thin, moussy and dense tan head and plenty of lace. Smells like mold, sweat, must. Very much like a basket of dirty gym clothes. With a pile of soggy burnt nuts in the middle of it. Big body, high side of medium for sure, grainy and well carbonated. Roast and toast and char hit you up front, followed by ash and chalk and sour milk. Not a whole lot of fun to drink.

Bottle from City Beer Store in SF.  Great dark red mahogany color, poured aggressively but failed to get much head.  Very clean aroma with chocolate malt, nuts.  Taste of grape, cherry, caramel malt, a veritable bouquet of carbonation.  Thinnish on the front but slightly chewy at the finish.  I am going to stock up on this!!

12 oz bottle.  pours deep ruby.  slight head, nothing of a jubilee though.  aromas are not of hazelnut, but of something nutty. also, red grape aroma.  taste is malty, slight coffee, and shining through with an almond finish.  interesting...
pours a lovely shade of mahogany. with light airy head. Lots of carbination.  Very malty especially on the finish.  Hints of toffee and filburt nuts.

Poured from a 12oz bottle, and served in an English pint glass.  This brew poured a dark ruby/brown with a thick, foamy, tan head that lasted.  Some light lacing was left behind.  The aroma included very rich caramel malts, toffee, light pine, and also some faint coffee notes.  The flavor was made up of hazelnuts, caramel, toffee, chocolate, along with a light underlying citrus hop note.  The mouthfeel was slightly creamy and medium to full-bodied with a strong dose of carbonation.  This was a very enjoyable brew.  Give it a shot if your a fan of the malts.
12oz bottle-A deep amber body with a very minimal head and an aroma of malts, toffee, and caramel. Taste of the same with some hosp thrown in. A nice tasting brew for a cold winter night.

Had this beer on 12/19/1997.  This is a deep rich red colored ale, very little head.  The aroma is a wonderful sweet malty scent with a hint of fresh hops,  if it taste as good as it smells it will be a very good beer.  As for the taste, its fresh with rich maltiness that finishes with a mild hop bitterness. This is a good Winter brew, its rich flavor and mild bitterness is perfectly matched for a cold winter day.

I have had this beer in many different vintages, though it is great after and 2-3 year cellaring Im reviewing the one I tried a day of the bottling line. It pours a dark brown/amber with a small tan head.  Aromas of light floral and chocolate, toffee, roasty burnt caramel and coffee.  A full palate of dark fruits, chocolate malt, caramel, espresso, and some roasted nuttiness.  Slightly dry finish, one of the best winter warmers.  Aging brings out more bourbon, alcohol, and port flavors.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2007 Date: 12/11/2003
Mode: Bottle
Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta

slightly alcoholic sweet malt aroma with rich hops, rich malt flavor well balanced with good earthy hops, like a light barleywine,

clear dark amber, sweet spicy rich malt aroma, rich malt flavor, dry and hoppy, light bitter finish

clear very dark amber, frothy beige head, solid lace, slightly fruity light malt aroma, rich malt flavor well balanced by lots of earthy hops, good bitterness, picks up a bit of fruity character, stays rich malty fruity and hoppy to the end

sweet malt aroma with a winey character, 
lots of oak and wine flavor, rich malt is offset by the oak, nice fruity esters,

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2008 Dark mahogany with big, creamy tan head / Big nose of toffee and raisins / Full, moderately syrupy body with a spritz on the strong finish / Flavors of toffee, raisins, nuts, coffee, wine, and chocolate / Great balance and finish.  A stunner from these masters of monster ales.

Sampled 12-oz bottle shared by joebrew. Pours an old penny copper amber brew with a creamy off-white head that has good retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel roasted malt, trpical fruits, some citrus zest and roasted nuts. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with flavors of sweet caramel malt, dried raisined fruits, some alcohol and sweet brown sugar. Finish is semi-sweet, smooth, creamy with a caramel malt aftertaste, more malt than any hops character.
Rich malt aroma, some spice, auburn, pours a small toffee head. Huge malt taste, some hops and almonds.Medium bodied,bitter, really well balanced, great mouthfeel. Terrific!
sampled at the blind tiger ale house in nyc. oak, berries, bitterness! good combo! Obvious nuts and some fruits. Sweetness is ok. Good beer
A bit thin in the flavor dept.  Nice solid ale, glad its not trying to be overly something....  Very drinkable!  and thats good!

Pours a clear dark brown color with ruby highlights and a thin light brown head. Aroma and flavor of molasses, nuts and alcohol, it feels quite ordinary, almost boring. The body is light with a liquorous texture and soft carbonation.

Bottle at home.
Dark red-brown with a samll head. Aroma heavy malty (chocolate, prunes, caramel, coffee, roasted). Flavor (almost) heavy sweet. Full body, the alcohol is felt.

Pours a cola brown color with a 2 finger pillowy head that thinned out fairly quick.Aromas of malt, nuts and a slight hint of alcohol.Flavor was malts, nuts, hops and caramel.Flavor at the end clinged to the back of my throat for a bit.

Pours brown, clear, with a moderate head. Aroma is hoppy with a mild roasted malt quality beneath. Solid mouth feel with a roasted malt flavor. Light hops drape around flavors of coffee, nuts, and caramel. An alcoholic warmth pervades the flavor. Very well balanced, good beer.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Lovely winter brew. But enjoyable even in Florida in July. Dark and rich, theres a spiciness that exists despite the lack of spices. Caramel, chocolate, a slight bit of toffee thrown in...Finishes well.

Bottle, from Lyager Vine, Fredericia. A dark red pour with a small off-white film head. Aroma has distant nuts, a good dose of caramel, some sherry and a touch of oak. Quite low carbonation, sort of oily. Flavour is very powerful, with an alcoholic edge to it. There are tones of chocolate, roasted caramel, oak and a good hoppy finish.
Decent nut aroma with chocolate finish.  Dark brown color with minimal head.  Roasted malt and chocolate body.

Poured from bottle...very nice color maroon with a decent tannish head.  Very dense aroma....oak....thick burnt flavors...mouth feel is nice as hints of chocolate and toffee abound.  Can clearly tell the alcohol content....finish is very nice....Avery you have done another great job!

Pours a dark thin reddish brown with a thin tan head. Has no lacing, and has hints of hops, nuts, vanilla, roasted malts, and some caramel. This is your typical english ale. Finished with a caramel hop taste.

Colour is a dark reddish brown with a tan head. The aroma is of oak and vanilla with caramel and some plum and raisin.  The taste is hoppy with some burned notes and maltyness mixed in with an oaky/earthy notes. The body is full and the carbonation is just right.

350 mL bottle.  Dark brown with white head.  Great aroma of caramel, nuts, some spice, and chocolate notes.  The taste is just as good as the aroma with a nice hoppy bitterness to balance out the sweetness.

Rated 7/9/07.  OK, look up the word "underrated" in the dictionary and the definition is "Old Jubilation".  This is an absolutely fantastic beer!  The pour is a very unique, dark brownish-purple color with a 1" frothy off-white head.  Lacing was very good all the way down the glass.  The aroma was complex, with notes of dark malts, oak, candied pecans, dark rum, and mocha.  The flavor was less complex, but equally impressive.  Chocolate, coffee, brown sugar, hazelnuts, and a nice hop bitterness were all present.  This beer reminds me of a porter mixed with an English Ale.  Nice mocha and candied nut flavors mixed with just enough hops to balance everything out.  Very smooth.  Right up my alley.  I will be buying more tomorrow to cellar for a while.  What an unexpected treat!
Good. The malt part tastes a bit like Fullers ESB. Delicious malty nose. Lots of toffee. Balanced with hops. Not very complex, but well-crafted. Recommended.

Pours a ruby brown color with a thin light tan head.  Light spice, toffee, licorice root and malt on the nose.  A bit of spice begins the taste and the maltiness is more apparent in the middle.  The finish is quite a bit roasty and spicy as well.  Alcohol is quite apparent for 8%.  I remember this being more enjoyable the first time I had it - Ill try another bottle soon.
12oz. bottle pours a dark reddish brown with a small amount of head. Another strong brew from Avery.
Licorise, sweet aroma.  Red with lasting head.  Roasted, sweet malts.  Smooth roast finish.

dark red/brown poury with thick white head that disapears quickly. It had a tangy/bitter aroma to it, but also a hint of sweet/caramel in there.  The taste is mild hops, more mocha and bitter in my opinion, with a medium bitter finish.  not really my favorite type of ale, but for a winter/spice ale it is one of the better ones.

probably got the bottle from the same place as flna80. and i agree 100% with your rating. i just liked it slightly better. touch of alcohol and a toffee straw note (in taste and in aroma) that manages to dissappear quickly enough. chaingang guy i can understand youre apprehension perhaps you havent had winter in awhile. and i did spend three good years at fort benning ga. particularly at kelly hill and harmony church. but if given the chance may i say  that there are quite a few wonderful winterbrews that i would feel privilaged to bring to youre attention.

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. A dark ruby color with fluffy, off-white head. Sweet, aroma of malt, fruits, caramel, and light hops.  Medium bodied, creamy texture.  Flavor is sweet toffee, then light hoppy bitterness. A good, malty brew.

Im somewhat shy about this whole Winter Warmer category; a category filled with beers flavored with spices, bush berries, and twigs. Yet, as Ive enjoyed the other Avery products Ive tasted, I thought Id give this one a try. Here we go!

Appearance: Pours a rich garnet hue with a modest, yet persistent tan head.

Aroma: Sniff! Gobs of sweet malty goodness upfront teamed with hints of caramel and mystery dark fruitiness. Also: a playful, leafy hop bouquet once you get past the malts.

Taste: Alright, lets jubilate! I get a Malt Mouth with light cocoa powder, caramel, and with a dash of light coffee thrown in. The hops lazily file in at the back of the line, allowing the beer to finish with a pleasant, albeit lingering hop flavor. Theres also a tiny bit of smokiness to be found. The 8% alcohol goes undetected, and was well hidden within this brew. Delish! Just the right amount of sweetness for me.

Mouthfeel: I would say medium for the mouthfeel with this one, and theres a decent amount of carbonation, too. Smooth! Which leads us to...

Drinkability: Oh, its drinkable alright! Especially for the 8% alcohol. Absolutely a joy to drink, even without the spices, bush berries, and twigs present in so many of these seasonal offerings. A hefty brew, and certainly a tasty one, I am pleased to have given this Avery offering a try and look forward to the remainder of the six-pack. Way to go, Avery!

Pours a dark deep red brown to mahogany with a healthy light tan head.  Dark malt abounds not necessarily sweet or roasty though.  Distinctively nutty.  Some dry dark bitter chocolate and a god hint of alcohol.  A light though creamy mouthfeel.  Perhaps a bit soapy, low carbonation.  The flavors are a bit more confusing than the nose.  For starters, the roast is much more noticeable. A good bit of chocolate and nuttiness also in the flavor.  Maybe some chicory or even light coffee?  Rather dry, the alcohol is well hidden too though.  Perhaps a bit of cinnamon and nutmeg, but only a hint.  Something woody and maybe even a touch oaky, minus the cherry hints.  Dry tannins linger on the tongue.  Dry roasty finish, with a bit of charcoal.  Lingers like a stout.  Almost like a big in your face dry porter.  This got better as I drank more of it.  I could get used to this.

Rated 12/2/06:  Burnt amber color poured with a towering light tan head that remained 1/2" thick for the entire time (surprising considering the strong alcohol content). Powerful carbonation inside the glass. Drinkable and lightly warming. Only wish it were fuller, but its still a hearty brew. Aroma has a thick malt scent with some grassy yeast. Taste is oh so slightly bitter at first soon mellowed by the thick malts with a tinge of alcohol burn. A touch of nuttiness. This one really gets bitter after a while, different but nice.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2015 Bottle.  Sweet, soft chocolate and roast malt aroma, porterish with wood, sweet ripe fruit in the bg, prunes.  Good deal of malt with some caramel.  Ruby body with a spoonable, lacing, creamy tanned head.  Sweet malty taste with a wave of medium bitterness, warm ending.  Dry, somewhat alcoholic aftertaste.  Toffee and roast sweep in and out, wood lingers with the saltiness.  Raisins and prunes and faint brown sugar behind dark, ripe fruit.  Caramel and medium, late-arriving hops.  Some earth and spice.  Thick, almost syrupy full body, rich and smooth feel.  Very robust flavor, a malt lovers dream.  Complex and delightful! [2007.05.22: 4.0]The Munich is really nice here, getting great grape character (at a Doppelbock level) and medium, persistent sweetness (much sweeter than I remember, but a great dessert quality).  Great malt depth, bread crusts through the finish, some raisins and plums, very lightly tangy.[2015.11.23: 4.2]

This was awesome, the black licorice flavors really shined and gave this thing a great complexity to the malts. Im a big black licorice fan, so that helps. Dry and spicy with a warm toasty nutty malt start. Reading the description im amazed to see no anise or black licorice in there, I need to find that malt for when I brew that gives that strong flavor. Overall one of my favorite winter seasonals.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2017 OK, I may have had a few beers at EBF2008, but by 11pm I actually quite enjoyed this, so notched it up a few points.
Rerate of (5-4-7-2-11=2.9)
355ml bottle (Black Door, Helsinki)
Sweet and beerlike. Malty with vegetable tinge. Sticky malt/hop combo, not very sophisticated.
Rerate of (5-4-7-2-11=2.9):
355ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki , American Week 2007).
Looks great, dark creamy head on dark red body. Smells sweet and sticky, some dried fruits maybe. I was unprepared for the taste - its huge. Very unsophisticated, and unbalanced. Even the unsubtle explosion of malt and hop tastes fails to cover the strong alcohol taste. Yet another US charicature of a UK style not done very well. Didnt leave any though, so not that bad.
355ml can - thanks martjoobolut (6:3:5:3:10=2.7)
Eww, sweet. Almost lagery malty taste. sweet, and alcoholic, pretty faily.

pours deep red with a beige foamy head that ligners for quite a while and leaves generous amounts of lacing.  smell is of molasses, and for a fleeting moment I smelled chocolate and some dried fruits as well. taste is kind of flat compared to what I would hoped it would be.  Has that sort of averys molasses brown sugar taste. dry hoppy finish with earthy taste.  I get lots of spices as well, although not quite as spiced as anchors christmas brew I think this works in its subtlety.  Love the discount price at beers of the world.

Bottle. Dark amber with thin beige head. Aroma of nuts, riped fruits, chocolate and alcohol. Malt, chocolate and some hops in the flavour, but not bitter. Low carbonation compared to other US microbrews. Nice winterwarmer, but not outstanding.

Dark fruits and some sweet malts stand out in the aroma.Pours a deep mahogany with a medium off white head.Caramel malt,dark fruits and a hint of alcohol makes up the flavor.Medium to full mouthfeel with a sweet,slight chocolate finish.
(Bottle) Courtesy of gracious trader BeerandBlues2. Dissipated white head with deep brown body. Nose of fig, raisin pulp. Flavour is overly malted for my weak tastebuds.

12oz bottle.  Pours a brown cola color with a bubbly beige head.  Lots of lace down the glass.  Very interesting aroma.  Very sweet, sharp, fruity, winey, vinegar, chocolate. Sweet, malty taste.  Some dark fruits in there too and maybe a hint of alcohol.  Interesting, unique beer.  Pretty complex.
Dark brown-amber colour.  Toffee & dark fruits on the nose with hints of alcohol.  Toasty, breadcrusty earthy strong ale with an overriding hop character.

Bottle.  Pleasant surprise, as I randomly chose this one.  Poured dark with a slowly receding tan head.  Coffee, caramel, and fruit on the nose.  The alcohol is completely masked by the complex, malty flavor.  Smooth, warm, and one I would definately order again.

Avery does not seem into the "we have more hops than you" mentality of brewing.  Their products are very well made and eminently drinkable.  This is from last years batch, excellent body, great balance, a truly tasty strong ale.  Well made and highly recommended.

bottle - Pours dark amber with a moderate head that fades to a thin, sustained head.  The aroma is of caramel malt and dark fruit and the flavor is along the same line with some mild hops for balance and maybe a hint of chocolate.  Its warming and very drinkable.

Solid medium brown pour with yellow/brown head. Head held at about 3/4 inch until dissolving to a thin lacing on surface of beer and around glass. Smells barleywine-sweetish, notes of fruit (strawberry?) and some generic licorice. First sip impressions: bitter! strong, full mouthfeel. Toffee flavor, more berry. Wow, is this stuff good. Very rich, amazing feel on the palate. I just got some old school bubblegum, you know the rock hard sticks of bubblegum that came in Topps baseball card packs in the late 80s? That is the prevailing aftertaste right now.  A nice, almost spicy bitter cocoa comes through quite soon in the pint. This is a fantastic English Strong Ale.

A clear but deep garnet body shows light traces of carbonation and holds a thick, khaki head for a long while until it falls to a fat cap and laces like a frickin doily. Spicy, fruity, malted aroma with enough citrus-atop-caramel to make me think theres a barleywine in my glass. Somewhat dry and fairly thick in the mouth. Cocoa dominates the flavor with a wash of raisin and a finish of chocolate and coffee. A llight spicy lift in the finish disperses an otherwise bitter, dirty linger. I can use this "winter warmer" today as we lost 40°F since yesterday...
<font size=-4>A trade thanks to <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/View-User-4111.htm&gt at the <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve />

Bottle: Dark mahogany, huge foamy light beige head, quite nice lacing. &nbsp Unsweetened Cocoa aroma, slight biscuit, otherwise dominiated by soft bakers chocolate (unsweetened). &nbsp Forwardly malty, soft hop presense, a touch of dark pitted fruit, hint of sourness, otherwise a Carob or artificial chocolate like flavor. &nbsp Noticing a bit of charred wood or campfire as it warms. &nbsp Moderate to full bodied and mouthfeel. &nbsp Finish leaves me wishing it was a bit sweeter. &nbsp Tiz okay, but just not fancy enough for a Winter Warmer. &nbsp Its missing something... or perhaps its that it is the "bakers chocolate" oriented profile that has me unsatisfied. &nbsp Slight dryness after the finish.

Bottle 12oz

Neat citric nose, grapefruit, lime, red apple and solid dose of brown malts.

Appearance: brown, clear, creamy tanned top.3+

Medium full bodied, light roast below with potent and clean hop character. Smooth balanced work.

Bottled. Floral aroma mixed with madeira and raisins. Brown color, beige head, good lace. Very floral and herbal hoppy start. Then it becomes sweet and finishes hopbitter again. I love it when a beer evolves during the drinking. Well balanced, sticky and dry in the finish.

Aroma has madeira, lot of raisin and hops. Clear, brown coloured with an off-white, medium head. Taste is sweet, madeira/port like with a hopbitter finish. Alcohol is noticeable and belly-warming. Nice brew I must say.
