The aroma was nutty and toasty with a sherry character, chocolate and coffee thrown in for good measure. The chocolate and fruity esters dominated the aroma was dark fruits of raisin and prune. The beer was brown with an amber hue and some particulate matter. The head was off-white and barely there, yet lasting enough to lace at the glass. The flavor was malty with dark fruits, once again raisin and prune, and chocolate, dark and milky. The beer had a strong caramel malt flavor coupled with chocolate and a smidge of coffee. The  body was medium full or just a bit less and with a low carbonation level was still a bit creamy in the mouthfeel. A nice beer, kinda a porter IMO. I believe this one has been in the stash for awhile, but it certainly does not seem the worse for wear - I had written 2003 on the label. 12 ounce bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle.  Poured dark burgundy; large tan head.  Aroma caramel, dark fruit, toffee, alcohol, and floral hops.  Medium-to-full bodied, with a dry finish.  Diverse malt taste; caramel, toffee, smoke/coffee.  A slight hit of citrus hops and pepper. Lingered on the back of the throat.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2007 Pours dark mahogany with a mostly receding thin light tan head. Aroma of alefruits, caramelized wort, toffee, and plums. Taste is malty, reminiscient of Marris Otter, with plenty of citric hops. This is spot-on with the classic barleywine taste, English varieties may add that extra something, but this is gettng close. Mouthfeel is heavy and resinous with lively carbonation. This is a nice barleywine.

Bottle: Pours a nice burgundy/ rusty amber with a sustained 1-finger tan head. Thick and malty aroma. Earthy, hearty, and full of grains, with a light undertone of peaty and dirty hops. The flavor is pretty robust. Medium to full bodied, and loaded with layers of malts. Ryebread chewyness, slightly nutty, wood notes are also there. Subtle toffee notes which are subdued by darker and grainy flavors from the various malts. Theres an abrupt dry bite in the finish. Thoroughly well made English Strong Ale. Since its classified as a Winter I wouldve liked if it were spiced, but its still good stuff.
For a winter seasonal I think this could be brewed all year round. Seasonal gives you something to look foward to, but this is not the first on my mind. Okay, but I would have to try again.

Bottle.  Light tan creamy head that leads into brownish-black color.  Good lacing.  Aroma is of roasted malts with a touch of mocha.  Flavor of caramel and coffee with a hit of hops at the end (mild though).  Al;so noticed slightest touch of alcohol.  Not bad.

pours black with a one finger tan fluffy head. aroma is grain, malt, and hops. has a medium body with good lacing. flavor is the same as aroma. little grain aroma and flavor gets stronger as it warms. has some nice carbonation and a little bite at the end. not bad a little oily feeling on the palate also. as it warms there is a little roastiness flavor to it, and a little coffee flavor also both in the aroma. has a small dry hop aftertaste at the end. the hops comes thru a little more at room temp. not bad.

12oz no date.  Pours a clear dark brown with a big 3 1/2 finger staying creamy beige head.  Aromas of pine, wood, and spicy hops, some vinous raisins and alcohol, toffee, peanuts, toasted malts, and a bit of misc fruit.  Nice.  Flavor is toffee and raisins up front, some earthy spices and hops followed by some vinous notes and alcohol, and an earthy roast dry finish.  I dont mind beers with high alcohol at all, but with some of these Avery brews it seems a bit forced and a separate entity from the rest of the beer.  Medium bodied with creamy moderate carbonation.  A pleasant surprise overall.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Very English style winter warmer.  Big, warm aroma.  Malty and rich on the palate.  Alchohol is weel integrated.  Excellent, especially through this brutal Florida winter....

12 oz. bottle. Appetizing, subtle aroma that is both malty and hoppy; dry and musty, but in a good way; chocolate-covered raisin or even pretzel notes. Poors a translucent, almost maroon dark brown with a bronze hue; small amount of beige/tan head (I would prefer a bit more); long legs. The flavor is smoky and tart. The hops are clearly of an English variety, and they are stronger in the mix than I expected. Tasteful prune malt sweetness. There may be no spices added, but pepper and pine tastes are present. Complex but manageable. All the flavors remain in the aftertaste. Heavy body; lively in the palate; very drinkable despite the high alcohol content. This beer is a perfect mitigator during the viciously cold February evening in Minnesota through which I am suffering. It is strong across the board. An excellent and underrated treat.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is ruby amber. Aroma is rich and complex. Taste is sweet with spices and fruit. Alcohol in finish.
Bottle. Hazy dark amber colour with a small off whjte mostly lasting head. Sweet aroma and taste of roasted malts with notes of licorice. Bit alcoholic finish.

bottle. dark mahogany pour with thick frothy off white head.  hoppy, very fruity, roast malts and mild spice in aroma.  smooth and creamy.  nice roasted malts but the other flavors in the aroma pale in comparison.  good none the less.

(Bottle) Pours beautiful deep red to brown. Roasted, fruity, fairly sweet aroma with nuts, plums and prunes. Undertones of roses, coffee, earthy liquorice and toffee. Soft and smooth mouthfeel. Crisp bread and fruity sweet flavour with some chocolate, coffee and nuts. Medium bitter and midium bodied. A nice english treat from the US.

On tap at the BSP.  Reminds me of every "house" beer in any pub in Portland, OR.    Dark mahogany thin white head.  nice lacing.    heavy malt makes this beer  Creamy, chewy, and very floral and sweet.

This beer pours a deep mahogany with a large tan head that dissapates leaving some good lacing down the sides.  On the nose I amgetting odors of hazelnut and sweet malt.  The flavors are quite good...  Lots of sweetness that lingers past the drink!  Very dark flavors strong with malt.  This is a well crafted beer and one I will have again!  Cheers!

Thanks to bditty187 for the bottle.

Pours a dark walnut brown with a thick two finger head. The foam settles slowly to a very thick cap that leaves behind a solid sheet of lace.

Smell; piney hops are the first to hit me, with little bit of citrus mixed in. Theres dark roasted malts that come off as a bit burnt, but also with some chocolate and caramel.

Taste; the dark chocolate, caramel and roasted malts come to the fore in the flavor. The pine and citric hops are there, they just take mare of a complimentary role instead of a dominant one as they did in the aroma. The hops and roasted flavors mix very well with a bit of a spicy alcohol presence in the finish, making for a very tasty beer.

Mouthfeel/Drinkability; mouthfeel is medium bodied, and very smooth, with a bit of alcohol in the finish giving it a bit of a drying character. Drinkability is really good, especially if you like lots of roasted malt flavors.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text:
Pours an average to large sized, creamy, off-white head that is mostly lasting.  The clarity of the ale is muddy with no chance of light getting through.  The hue is black.  It is medium bodied and creamy with a slight roasted malt aftertaste.  Carbonation is average.  I detect a presence of fruit in the aroma, perhaps raisin.  The initial flavor is sour and finishes with sweet malt flavor.
	Overall this beer is baffling me.  I love the texture, the aroma, the palate, but I cannot pinpoint what is in the beer to give it these characteristics.  This is a unique beer; I have not experienced a beer quite like this before.  I am very impressed.

Bottle courtesy of Blankboy (thanks!).  Deep ruby red, thick foamy off-white head.  Rich malt, dark fruit, wood in aroma.  Deep rich malt, dark fruit again in taste, along with a lot  of hops and lots of alcohol.  Crisp mouthfeel.  Lingering sweetness and some spiciness.  Hint of smoke.  A lovely winter warmer.

bottle: pours a deep brown colour with a small off white head that stays around. aroma is sweet and nuttywith some hops.
starts off sweet with a nice roasted flavour ends with a nice clean bitter finish.

Pours deep mahogany into a Trappist glass.   Stale sweet cardboard aromas.  Offwhite congolmerate head has good retention and leaves sheet lacing as it slowly recedes.  Sweet, full toffee with lasting bitter licorice finish. Flavor is better than aroma.

Bottle. The scent is subtle with light notes of oak.  Clear and dark with deep red hue.Very light flavor of alcohol. Almost, but not quite soy after taste. Tingles the tongue, but leaves the mouth feeling refreshed. Not bad.

Near black colored with sligth red hints. Big beige head. Sweetness, caramel, licorice, some vinous tones, mild alcohol and hoppy flowers in rich aroma. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is more hopped with bitter flowerness and caramel, also some licorice with some burned sugar and roastiness there. Aftertaste is hopped with mild alcohol. Excellent beer, reminds me of some barley wines.
Poured a deep chocolate brown color with a very large tan head.  Nose of spiced malts, dark fruits.....some chocolate as well.

12 oz bottle thanks to BeerandBlues2.  Cola colored pour with a bigger-than-cola head.  Actually overpoured cuz I thoguht it was going to act like a cola.  Dark fruit and caramel aroma.  Flavors were roasty and caramel too with a touch of spice.  Not too bad at all.

Nice auburn color with medium head when poured.  Smells malty but pleasant.  Smooth, slightly sweet, creamy taste that leaves you with a tart spicy aftertaste.  Reminds me of nutmeg or ginger.  I really enjoyed this and IMHO it was just as good as some beers costing 2-3 tmes the price.

Bottle (12oz).  Beautiful deep ruby, refractive, with an average frothy/rocky beige lasting head.  Almost barleywine aroma, fresh cereal grains, solid but not overpowering herbal hops, slightly tart apricot toasted malt, alcohol, maybe a bit of cream - very nice indeed. Taste is very peaty with a tang of iron to it, roast malt, peach pit and herbal/funky hop bitterness - surprisingly bitter finish.  Average body, very astringent, almost burnt sugar character on the palate, where it lingers quite a while, alcohol dryness to it.  Very good beer, nice take on the style.
Looks great, flows nicely. Has a smoky aroma to me, a little funky. Taste has some smokiness too. Not very complex or spicy or thick but okay. They have better stuff. The head retention is fantastic.

Bottle: Poured a deep burgundy color ale with a nice medium foamy head with good retention and lacing. Aroma of deep malt with some sweet dry fruits is really enjoyable. Taste is also dominated by the sweet malt with some presence of dry fruits and a hoppy slightly bitter finish. Body is above average with a nice level of carbonation and no alcohol is discernable.

Dark red with lots of fluffy off-white head.  Aroma is nice, it has some chocolate and caramel hints, as well as strong hops.  The taste starts off sweet and chocolatey, then it turns slightly alcoholic, and then bitter.  The aftertaste is clinging, just a little bit bitter.  Not a great aftertaste.  It feels a little too thick for my liking.  It has more of a stout feel than an ale, but not bad.  Pretty impressive beer.

(bottle)poured into a pint.  poured a dark amber with full frothy head.  has a sweet bitter hoppy aroma.  gives a slight bitter front with sweet middle and an acidic finish.  it is slightly loose(watery) on the palate.  there are definitly spices evident within this seasonal.  good for the occasion or in a tasting line up, but I prefer a few other seasonals.
Dark brown colour, thick spongy off-white head. Flowers (roses) in the aroma. Very sweet and spicy, with christmas flavours. Nice palate, roasted taste. Good! Finishes with a strong bitterness.

One of the beers in my New Years Eve line-up and man, this was perfect. A great beer to end a great year. An aroma of sweet malts, raisins, toffee, caramel, hops, spices (thought I was picking up cinnamon too). Appearance is a deep burgundy/purplish color, excellent lacing and a nice head with near perfect retention. Flavors were a near match to the aroma, which was a good thing. Simply outstanding!
Pours a very dark amber with a BIG frothy head. Nice roasted malt aroma. Nutty spiced flavor with a touch of bitter hops and some chocolate.

Bottle rating from the Happy Gnome.  Dark red in color.  Very hard to get a read on the aroma here.  Roasted maple nut flavor with winterish spices.  Alcohol is well hidden.  I wouldnt have guessed this was 8% when drinking.  Sweet flavor with a hint of hops.  Interesting that in the commericial description they mention that there are no spices used.  Could have fooled me.  Would have scored higher with a more detectable aroma.  Still good, but the full experience just isnt the same when you cant smell the beer.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 I held on to this bottle for about a year because I got it from a six pack of identically themed winter themed beers, all promising to warm me up on a cold, snowy night.  That line had become so trite and cliché that I just pushed the rest aside and let the biting winter cold finally take me.  Somehow I survived until morning despite not having another winter warmer from the six pack, and I vowed that as much carping and captious tom-foolery as I might throw it I should give this ale the same chance that I had given the others.  A little more than 365 days later I did, and I was treated to something familiar in its regularity.  This whole genre of beers is what fiber does to the digestive track  it becomes predictable to a letter.  I dont even want to go into the same old, same old character and quality.  It has no head, its ruby red, it smells like pine long dead, the smell is lead, with resin bled, and licorice for street cred.  There, I feel a little bit better now.  Its all true, mind you.  Old Jubilation is sugar on a rampage, adhesive with sugar molecules and nigh organic with its gargantuan pine resin presence.  The only other flavor here is chemicals from a carpet cleaner, which needless to say is not a pleasing thing to have on the tongue.  Im still bent on the idea that drinking medium to low quality brews is helpful for my abilities as a Ratebeerian, but this style clearly has come cookie-cutter issues that need to be resolved, or better yet, absolved.  Just cut down on the quantity of beer that tastes almost exactly the same.  I appreciate all the wonderful and diverse label art, but it seems like it ends up being the same suds in every one.  And as for the whole winter warming idea?  When theres a centurion legion of beers out there that can do it and do it with style Im likely to go stand by them in the presence of a fireplace then make the best of it with a beer that tastes like everything else that it shared its shelf with.  Again, its not the flavor Im upset with.  Only the repetition of the same flavor.
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Bottle. Very dark brown color.  Very good - rich and strong. Roasty flavor.

Pours a redish-brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of sweet malts, nuts, and a hint of floral hops.  Flavor starts off with the sweet malts and give way tho the hops.  Finishes with a lingering hop bitterness and some slight alcohol warming.
Tap - PDX - Rose and Raindrop. In a tasting with other seasonals. Just what the dr. ordered for a cold damp winters day. satifsying and filling!

Bottle. Pours brown with a tan head. The aroma is sweet with fruits and toasted malts. The flavor seems spicy, with a nice mix of malts and a hint of hops. Light to medium body with a light bitterness throughout.

pours clear and dark amber with a creamy light brown head.  Aroma is lightly malty of cookies, heavly hoppy of grapefruit and hints of grape.  Flavor is lightly sweet and heavily hoppy with an average finish.  Medium bodied creamy and lively.

Dark amber/brown with fine creamy off white head. Aroma and taste has Caramel & chocolate -roasted malty sweetness. Alcohol and dark fruits (prunes/plum) - warmth. Filling body. Light Hoppy lasting finish! Another great product from Avery!

This one is very dark brown, almost black. and the head is nice. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, cough medicine and cheese. The mouth feel is oily. The flavour has nice notes of aroma hops, roasted malt, caramel, licorice, cough medicine and a dry, delicious bitter finish. Yet another nice beer from Avery.

Bottle. Nice red-brown colour with a small head. Aroma is sweet and malty, hints of dark fruits, caramel and nuts. Flavour is sweet, bit spiced, lovely fruitiness, nuts, some schocolate and caramel. Tasty tasty tasty!

This ale pours a beautiful dark, ruby red with about an inch and a half of foam on top!  The aroma is a bit sweet, with hints of dried fruit and malt.  The taste is also initially sweet, but that quickly changes to malt, spices, and hops.  The finish is a little bitter, and that bitterness lingers throughout the warming, alcohol finish.  I like this brew, as I do everything Ive tried from Avery, but is isnt anything really special, just another adequate winter ale.

A deep red beer with a fluffy brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of fruit, prunes, caramel, nuts, and alcohol. The flavor is very sweet and very powerful with notes of fruits, both fresh and over ripe, as well as chocolate, nuts, caramel, prunes, alcohol, coffee, and roasted malt. The end is sweet with a slight bitterness
12 oz bottle. Dark cloudy copper color with minimal brown head. Aroma sweet malt. Taste of coffee with a strong bitter after taste.

Bottle. Pours a very dark and deep ruby with a large lasting rocky off-white head. Nice lacing. Very nice aroma of sweet malt, chocolate, toffee, dark fruit and spices (I know the description says no spices but it smelt like there were some to me). Pleasant flavour of sweet malt, chocolate, dark fruit, spices, hops and a light bitter and smoky finish. Alcohol completely hidden. Medium to full bodied. Wow, I dont know what i was expecting with this beer but it wasnt this, this is really good stuff -- glad I have more!

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a cloudy brown color with amber highlights and a very thin layer of tan bubbles.  Rich malts, alcohol, cherries, smoke and chocolate.  Medium bodied, smooth and moderately carbonated. Ending is malty with notes of earthy hops, coffee and chocolate.

Sweet beer!
Dark mahogony body with no head.  Aroma of roasted malts, nuts, and some hops.  Tastes of roasted malts, some nuts, fruit, and a light touch of hops and alcohol.  Great beer!

Draft @ Blind Pig.  Dark body with amber tint. little head with some lacing.  Malty, nutty aroma with pine mixed in.  Strong hop and alcohol presence, but lacked the malt sweetness that I really lock for in this style.  Enjoyable, but just a little off too...
Bottled. Pours a clear dark amber with a lacy off-white head. Sweet toffee-malt nose. Medium body with light carbonation. Lightly sweet taste of fruit and nuts. Well rounded.
A very solid ale.  Toffee and dry malt on the nose -- a bit of chocolate on the tongue.  Classy beer.  A nice winter offering.

..as i watch myself in the reflection of the tv...i drink this drink as it were my last....this beer has something to it, like when you get sand in your eye and you get the sand out of your eye and the relief sets in....pure goodness touches my lips as a bear would grapple with a strawberry in a basket of cloves...the aroma and smell that emanates from my mug makes me think, "what if pigs could fly?"...would they smell like this gem?...ill tell you this..ive never smelt a pig like this...the lamb is great....Jubilation makes me smile....it has flavours that make the mind race and the fingers walk, sweet embraces tangled up in a web of magical goodness...one day i will have the answer, but for now the overall has to be this...awaiting a brew that makes me write like a drunk poet on acid: means that the world is ready for a pint of jubilation...thanks mom!............."thank you jesus"-Hank Hill..

Awesome nosefeel for a hophead that didt expect it, great color with a nice yeasty head that ended up lacing nicely. Lots of malt + hops that balance beautifuliy. Hints of coffee and the ABV is hidden niclely. Worth saving a bottle or two for next year.

Tap at Capital Ale House - Innsbrook.  A great dark ruby/mahogony body with a light ivory head.  Aroma was excellent, fruity and malty with a nice hop complexity.  Taste was very nice, malts come through very strongly along with some hops and light fruits.  A very tasty ber.

mahogany body with massive head...aroma huge in dark fruit, chocolate roasted malts, and light citrus hops...excellent flavor profile of caramel and toffee, dark fruit, wood-like characteristics...finishes slightly hoppy and bitter...very nice

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 12oz 06 bottle. pours a dark mahogony with thick fluffy head. aroma has PNW hops?, huge malt presence with undertones of  cocoa and burnt coffee. smells great. flavor leaves something to desire. big malt presence but wheres the hop bitterness and flavor? sure its drinkable but why? flavors of  toffee, hints of chocolate and caramel. cant taste the alcohol. ive had this at  one year old and it didnt improve much maybe a little more balanced but not enough to save this beer..3. 12oz 05 bottle aged 2 years. this really isnt aging well. drinkable yes, but even more alcoholy. 2.7

On tap at Barleys in Asheville.  Deep reddish brown body with a medium tan head.  Nice citrusy hoppiness balanced well with the malts in this brew.  Nothing grating on the palate... slightly alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 I didnt detect much of an aroma upon pouring this beer.  The beer itself is a dark red, with a nice head and good lacing.  Can detect the alcohol slightly in the finish, but it balances nicely with the malt flavors.  This is one that I have cellered some, and will re-rate when I open them up.  (Re-rate)  There is now a slightly sweet aroma to the beer.  Coloration and carbonation appear to be about the same.  The beer has seemed to gain more of a roasted flavor.  Not bad at all.

Not too shabby. Poured a little cheesy, but settled in with a chocolatey fruity note, with dancing spicy, almost citric hops. A woody resiny note is apparent, almost reminds me of the cedar in Kiuchis IPA, but not quite. Easy finish with a lingering hot palate. Fair.

12 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquor - Pours a clear deep amber color with a one finger off white head.  Light lacing.  Has a light spicey malt aroma.  Has a smooth toasted malt and light spice flavor with some very light esters.  Slight bitter finish.  Medium body.  A good beer.
verk dark. but clear. sweet fig aroma.  a little empty on flavor. off-tastes everywhere. metallic. palate a bit thin too.

Pours a deep mahogany brown w/ a medium sized semi creamy froth. Froth is spattered and recedes slowly to reveal a fine canopy surounded by a complete wall of lace. Aromas of thick malted caramel and cocoa. Full nectar w/ soft residual effers. If there ever was a seductive brew, this is it. Full yet soft and lucious mouthfeel w/ bold yet refined flavors. The hop profile is intricately weaved throughout holding it all together like only a good woman can. Malty w/ ample caramel, cocoa, slight roasted coffee and vanilla bean. Theres a slight nutty flavor that reveals itself as she warms. The finish is juicy and hangs around for a while w/ a perfect bittering of the asprin sort. Overall: a well balanced brew of a sensuous nature. Theres nothing about this brew thats short of true classic. Connoisseurs Choice! Highly Recommended.

Pours clear mahogany with a big head. Left medium lacing. Aroma of dark fruit and roasted malt. Medium to full body. Sticky texture. Pretty complex, with tastes of prunes, brown sugar, toffee and wood. A little bit of alcohol to finish.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2010 [rated 12.14.06, one of my first ratings hehe] did not know this was 8%...  after a couple i got unexpectedly silly... will rerate after another go... but was very delectable 7.4.7.3.16. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . [rerated 1.5.10]  Pours a clear glowing dark amber with a nice frothy creamy beige head with some lacing.  Aroma is fruity and lightly spicy, malt flour, very fruity/ fruitcake-like, smells like this might be at least a year old.  Flavor follows, glassy malt feeling, tastes like bitter fruitcake, malt flour, hint of cocoa, sweet , fruity and spicy, slightly similar to Great Divide Hibernation, a bit more earthy, has to be some rye in this.  Medium bodied, glassy but thinner, nice sizzling fluffy carbonation.   7.4.7.4.15.
Bottle. Dark red colour with a nice tan head. Aroma and flavour of toffee, malt, fruit and hops.
Nice dark cherry red with a perfect medium head. Light sweet aroma of caramel/maple. A little juniper in the aroma and taste. Taste starts with moderate sweetness and finishes with spicy hops.

Another gift from the bartender at Barcade I love this place.  Dark amber beer with a thick off-white head.  Aroma is a bit salty and herbal with intense oaky character throughout.  Herbal dill-like character that reminds me of the barrel-aged Leviathan.  Flavour shows saltiness and sweet caramelly malt.  Strong alcoholic flavour and a bit of tartness on the back.  A bit of vanilla and caramel along with some herbal hoppiness.  Strong and sweet but not terribly malty.  Not really a fan.

a very nice strong beer.  Great for the cold winter months.  Rich and malty and smooth as silk this is a creamy, thick beer.  Sweet but not overpowering so.  It drinks more like a porter than a English ale

(Bottled) Dark nutty brown with a smallish, tight head. Toffee-caramely-malty aroma of berries, blackcurrant leaves and birch. Smooth, lightly roasty, very caramely-malty and fruity flavor with flowery hops. Slicky, medium to full-bodied, warming palate with slightly foamy carbonation and well-hidden alcohol. A nice, sweetish and warming winter brew with a strong scotch/old ale feel.

Pours a deep brown with reddish hues and anice light tan head.  The aroma is malty with some dark fruit and spice.  Flaovr is rich with spice, dark fruit, roasted malt, and nuts, with a nice snappy hoppy bitterness.

Bottled from Whole Foods Market. Pours a dark ruby color. Sweet woody aroma. Some hops are noticable, but just a touch. Some vinousness and bourbon. Dark malty character. Lots of wood and dark fruit. Hoppy bitter finish. Well balanced brew. The 8% is very well hidden.

Malty aroma with a slight smokey scent.  The apperance is dark brown with red highlights.  Palate is extremely full.  Very complex flavor.  Wood, malt, smoke--lots of flavor.  Some hops come out as it warms.  Very nice.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2007 Pours to a garnet shade with a creamy head, with a nose of maple, caramel, different woods, and alcohol.  Rich flavors of raisins, bourbon, and fruitcake, finishing with a bit of burn reminiscent of Robitussin.  Flavorful, but it began to strike me as strangely overcomplicated, as if someone poured a bit of cough medicine on chocolate cake.  Might even be a bit young.

Chestnut brown color with a full chocolate cream crown. Mildy hoppy aroma wafts easily away. Woodiness in flavor with ambiguous nuttiness and spiciness and finish of wood and alcohol. Decent brown ale/APA with woody character. Alcohol is well integrated. Enjoyable mouthfeel. More hoppy that I prefer for a winter beer, but well crafted.
Reddish brown, medium sized beige head. Clean, crisp aroma - spicy, and even a bit grapey. Flavor is piney at first, then a fruity, grapey note. Earthy, woodsy finish.

12oz Bottle Pours out a dark brown topped with a small tan head. Aroma of fruit and caramel. Great tast. A very nice beer to drink AFTER A BUCKEYE WIN OVER MICHIGAN.
GO BUCKS

Brand new bottle, fresh from the shelves.  Pours a dark brown, with red highlights, clear.  Therea nice fluffy head that maintains itself wonderfully, but theres little lacing.  Aroma is really interesting: Definitely some dried fruit, perhaps plums and pears, maybe some grapes.  Whoever previously said leather, is surprisingly right!  Whatever it is, its a malty backbone to the fruit.  Not like any other beer Ive smelled.  Taste is tangy and toffee some toast elements to it.  A bit of fruitiness as well as bitter roast going down.  Finish doesnt let up.  Very good, but slightly thinner than I would hope.  This would be even better with a thicker texture.
Rich copper.  Nose is fruity, chocolat,e some rye, caramel.  Flavor is quite fruity, caramel, alclhol, some lemon.  Quite bitter finish w. some alcohol.  Not bad.
Fantastic beer, one of the best ESAs around. Avery is a great brewer and this one is perfect for cold winter nights

Bottle. Pours brown with red highlights and a nice tan head. The aroma is dried fruit and a bit of leather, some citric hops. The hops come through stronger the flavor and the fruits take a back seat, some slightly burnt aftertastes mingling withe the strong hops. I might have called this one closer to 6.5% or 7%, so the alcohol is well hidden. This is a reasonable beer, though not a standout in my book.

Bottle. Clear, moderately dark brown with a decent cream head that drops quickly. Aroma seemed muted with little to distinguish it. Packs a quick hop bite that fades quickly on the back of the tongue, leaving a tingly, citrusy carbonated taste. The alcohol presence is very hidden. I might try to cellar this to see if it improves. Its good, but not my favorite winter seasonal.

Bottle.  Clear dark copper/brown.  Thick tan head, leaving striped lacing.  Sweet and rich malty aroma, somewhere between caramel and molasses.  Sweet but not cloying dark malt flavors, slightly roasty/toasty coffee/chocolate with a bit of a plummy dried fruit tang in the background.  Some darkly toasted nut bitteness in the finish. Alcohol clandestine. Nice straightforward X-mas ale which is not unnecessarily gussied up with the traditional spices.

Draught. Beer is clear, medium-to-dark borwn with a small, creamy, off-white, frothy, mostly and quickly diminishing head.

The aroma was moderately malty with notes of toasted grain and caramelslighly husky; Hoppy with moderate notes of resin/pine, grapefruit, light note of dried apricot; Yeasty with light notes of dish rag, sweet soap and dough; Light miscellaneous notes of alcohol, moderate peach, trace of candy sugar.

The flavor was moderately sweet, moderately-to-heavily bitter with a long, moderately-to-heavily bitter/grippy, lightly sweet, trace salty finish.

The body was moderate, the texture was velvety and the carbonation was lively.

Pours dark brown with a reddish hue and moderate sized off-white head.  The aroma has dark sweet malts and dark fruit.  Medium / full body with some sharp carbonation.  Thte taste has lots of hops I didnt detect on the aroma.  It is woody mainly, but there is some pine and spice in there as well.  There is some sweet malt hiding in the background.  The finish is spicy, woody and fairly dry.  Further down more malty roastiness starts coming out.  Very well done beer.

The aroma has roasted malt, molasses, chocolate, vanilla, and fruit. The appearance is red/brown with am medium head. The flavor is like the aroma with more bitterness than I was expecting. The palate is soft and smooth. The aftertaste is toasted malt and nuts. Overall I like it.

From a 12 oz. long neck bottle, 2005 release.

Poured a milk chocolate brown with a small foamy off-white head that settled into a thin bubbly lacing.

Aromas of mocha and nuts, a soft dark ripe fruitiness, a light vanilla and a bit woody alcohol.

Moderate carbonation and a softly crisp, smooth light-medium bodied mouthfeel.

Tastes of a plum fruitiness, nuts and a powdery mocha, vanilla with a touch of toffee in the middle, earthy, the alcohol is slightly noticeable, a bit solvent like, and a nutty, powdery finish.

Not a bad winter seasonal from Avery, but I think I will try a fresh bottle this December, I thought the flavors were a kind of muted.

Fruity cherries oranges and hops in the aroma.  deep mahogany cherry wood with a few big center bubbles.  malt bread solid with lots of hops and fruits, woods, vanilla.  big flavor yet very drinkable.  quite enjoyable.

pours a bark brown with red highlights large camel head.aroma is chocolate carmel and nuts.tadte is sweet choco. with a clean hop finsh.over all would be a great winter warmer but by defintion too hoppy but dont let that turn you off cuz Im defintlatey getting this christmas eve

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2006 12 oz bottle into an English Pint glass.  Pours a beautiful deep brown toned mahogany color with a dense and pillowed tan head that has great retention.  The aroma has a very Earthed nutty smell, while being back by hints of toffee and coffee.  The brew brings a smooth drinking and somewhat carbonated feel to the palate.  Much of what is going on in the nose is represented.  First bringing sweet hints of toffee and hazlenuts backed by dark fruits (mainly plums), then slowly moving into a nicelym bitter hopped coffeed out finish that lingers on the tongue with a bit of an alcohol singe.  An excellent winter beer, this one would definitely warm on a cold day!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 Exceptional pour.  Deep, very dark mahogany and with a bit of clarity; great full, great lasting ability, khaki-colored, pillowy/creamy head with some tight lacing.  Nose is great, like a hazelnut, mocha coffee with some toffee and definate earthy hops.  Flavor is similar, hazlenut mocha roastiness, a little anise, some toffee and slight raisin as the flavor progresses.  The hop bitterness seems to be light but gains strength into the finish where it is bittersweet with bitterness taking over almost taking over in a pleasant way.  Palate is medium, moderate carbonation, and creamy with only a slight alcohol warming near the end.  Being from Colorado, this is an excellent winter warmer for the cold late fall, early winter nights with friends or family.  Not spectacular, but simple, original, and fully satisfying.  After over a year in the cellar...  Appearance is still great,  Nose is similar but now picks up some dried fruits, cellar notes, and the hops have become somewhat resinous.  Flavor remains similar but hops are less dominant towards the finish.  Body is better with a medium-full body and a more round mouthfeel.  I like the palate and the new intricacies of the aged bottle but the hops are great in the fresh version.  Its a very good winter warmer frsh and aged.

a mahogony pour w/ more hints of reds when helled to light w/ a dense light tan head that laces well but dissapates pretty quickly.  Aroma is sweet and malty lots of brown sugars and toffees some raisens and soem other dark fruits.  pretty avg pal smooth some nice carbonation.  Flavor is a nice full roast malt and roast grain aroma over some toffees, plum, raisens.  Very nice beer.

12 oz bottle. Deep mahogany with a decent tan head. Sweet malty nose, some prune and raisin, caramel and some roastiness. Full body. Sweet flavor, prune, dark caramel, roasty - bittersweet. Lovely on a slightly chilly night.

Bottle.   

Nice brownroasty and malty thing. Welcoming flavor, sweet and round. Tasty and makes one drinks more. Lovely and nice beer.
Dark, reddish amber with nice white head. Malty, dark fruit and hazelnut. A smooth mouthfeel with medium body and a slightly sweet finish.

12 oz botle pours a dark reddish brown with a thin head.  Aroma is malty and a little bready with some spices coming through.  The flavor is much of licorice, (if they were going for this they definitely over did it) and malts, nutty undertones that finish bitter, cloying, and unbalanced.  Not one i want to drink again.

Pours from the bottle to a dark brown, with hints of ruby redwith good carbonation, and a medium tan head that lingers and then reduces to good lacing. The nose is a mild aroma of malty dark fruit, and the taste is a nice mixture of this malty sweetness and hop bitterness. The 8% alcohol creeps into both the aroma and taste at mid-glass, and leads to a sweet, warming finish. This bottle depicts a winter scene, and thgis may be better as a winter warmer, but I was not disappointed having it on a warm, early Fal evening.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2008 1/29/08: Re-rate. Draft at Town Hall brewery in Minneapolis. Despite the fact that my previous rating was very favorable, my recollection of Old Jubilation is that it was less than memorable. My ratings this time around all plummeted: Ar 6, Ap 3, Fl 7, Pal 4, Ov 15. Overall impression is that its alcohol and malt with nothing overly distinctive about it. A nice beer, but not worth the extra dough I spent when I could have had an Avery the Reverend on tap or better yet, another Town Hall brew.

9/22/06: Malty aroma with a slight hop aspect. Also sweet in the nose with some black cherries. Dark reddish brown. Thin light tan head. Some lace, smallish head. Rich, strong, sweet. Really good. Caramel, faint molasses. Very well balanced. Maybe needs a little more carbonation. Excellent brew.
Bottle. Clear deep reddish/brown - offwhite head. Malty, roasted, sweet, ryebread, nuts, caramel, hoppy, complex.
darkish red, clear, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, lively middle, moderately bitter finish

I picked this one up thinking it was a barleywine... First wiff and taste and I had to look it up because... well its not a barleywine. Pours a clear dark mahogany with a small head that does leave some lacing. Aroma is all malt with nuts, toffee and caramel. flavor is the same without being excessivly sweet. If the alcohol wasnt so high this would make a great session beer. Plesant, easy to drink and very enjoyable. Alcohol presance is quite masked for an Avery beer.
Bottle. Jubii what a beer, just like a small version of The Maharaja, but a bit more in harmoni, nice nice beer.
Bottle. Mahogany color with a small tan head. Very sweet aroma. Flavors of spicy malts with burnt toffee, wood and some chocolate coming through in the finish.

Bottle, pours medium reddish color, with noticable lightness around the edges. and a medium sized tan head. Aroma is a complex blend of malts, molasses, and spice. The flavor has a nice malty almost caramel cookie-like turn to it, with some fruits. great drinking for an August evening, would even be better in December or January.
Pours a nice ruby red with a huge head. Smells of sweet cramel and toffee. Taste is caramelly good with light roasted nuts and an assertive bitterness in the finish.
bottle. dark amber color. large head. sweet hoppy aroma. round and pleasant hoppy and spicy. very good.

Very unique mahogany color with a small tan head.  Very sweet aroma of toffee, molasses and raisins.  Flavors of spicy malts and cherries at first with burnt toffee, wood and some chocolate coming through in the finish.  Texture is just a little thin but the complex flavor more than makes up for it.

(on bottle) Rubyred with a beige head. Vinorous, yet light sweet nose. Somewhat mashy and fruity. A small kick of the alcohol, get´s rounded of huge amouts of malts later. The finish is really complex. First it´s all light and malty, but it soon returns with a hefty mix of esters, tobacco, dry fruits and wood.

Some dark cherry flavor along with a bit of burnt toffee,comes in as a bitter flavor. Not bad for 8% at all. Gets a little hotter as it warms but the flavor becomes a bit more of Port. Thanks to Moejuck for this one.

Dark transparent ruby-mahogany, minimal white head. Aroma has nice balance of carmel-toffee malt and spice. Apparently there s no spice used though, oh well. Flavor again nice caramel-toffee character, faint dark fruits with roasted nuts and grains. Even get hints of smoke. With the huge malt bill, doesnt seem too unbalanced. Well done.

Pours reddish-brown with ruby highlights. Thin tan head, Not much lacing. Smells of malty molasses and caramel.

Fruity and richly malty. Plum and caramel. some decent hops in the finish. Sticky with hints of the alcohol. Not overly complex but a good winter warmer.

Aroma:toffe,nutty....
Appearance:Dark brown,good head..
Flavor:Good bitterness,nutty......

Pours dark opaque brown. Aroma carries hazelnut and sweet carmel. Flavor has a carmel toffee and herbal begining works into a dry hoppy finish watery no lingering flavor after the first few sips I got bored. Sorry but I did not dig.
Dark brown, almost black.  Lots of caramel and toffee in the flavor.  Followed by a dry, bitter finish.  Hides the alcohol well.
This was great stuff.  Toffee and candied nuts, along with some roasted caramel and chocolate, followed by some sweet sugar coated fruitiness.  Finishes with just enough roastiness, nicely balanced.
Very mild aroma and flavor. Very slight hops and some sweet malt, maybe a little cocolate. Not much else, kind of watery but not bad.

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a thin off white head.  The aroma is enticing with a nice fruity aroma, with some interesting spices and plenty of malts.  The flavor is really smooth. Caramel, malts, light chocolate and coffee.  Excellent winter brew.

18-Jun-06 (12 oz bottle: Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA Im not quite sure why I thought this was a barleywine two years ago, maybe having "Old" in the name threw me off, but it clearly doesnt fit that style.  This particular bottle has been aging in my cellar for well over a year, and its showing positive signs of that maturation.  Its very earthy and roasty, toasty, sweet, chocolaty, smoky in the finish, and moderately bitter throughout.  The beers earthiness is fairly prominent in the nose too, where a pleasant toastiness takes hold as well.  Toast and chocolate definitely take a back seat in this area.  Full bodied but not syrupy in any way, and the bitterness balances the sugars, preventing the palate from cloying.  Medium ruddy-brown in color with good clarity.  A good inch of beige-colored head forms on the pour, taking many minutes to settle to a thin, persistent layer.  The significant amount of lacing covers the glass in a doily pattern that will likely persist until I wash it off the glass.  Clearly this beer is capable of a year or two of aging, though Im not sure there is too much change to the overall flavor profile.  A great beer when fresh, and equally great when aged, so buy a sixer and dont worry if it takes you a year or more to drink it.02-Mar-04 (12 oz bottle: OBriens in San Diego, CA) A very malty and earthy barleywine that goes easier on the heavy, syrupy sweetness and results in more balance that is typical of the style.  Moderate bitterness right from the start, but the hoppy bitterness gains prominence in the mildly smoky finish.  The beer has a nice, thick palate initially, but the hoppiness at the end cuts in dramatically.  Aroma is light but mostly that of sweet malts.  The color is a gorgeous ruddy mahogany, clear and sediment free.  Head is very light-tan in color, smallish, but has fairly good retention.  Very intricate lacing pattern resembles the window pattern of a high rise building. (6, 4, 8, 4, 17 = 3.9)

Dark amber color with a wisp of an off white head. Multiple malt notes in the aroma along with a Barleywine style smell (yum). Big malt flavor combining crystal malts to give the caramel flavor, cherry like sweetness and highly roasted malts (such as black patent) for a porter like taste component near the end of the swill. Starting to notice burnt and coffee flavors too. Very good.
Dark copper with a creamy off-white head. Some lacing Rich, fruity aroma, with some cherry, malt and alcohol. Nutty sweet flavour with a port-like alcohol-dominated finish.

Bottled. Deep copper in color, with a dense, beige head. It has a sweet aroma with some alcohol, malt and a good dash of hops. The flavor is malty and sweet, with lots of piny and fruity hops in it, some alcohol too. Fullbodied, very bitter, hoppy beer, with a lightly roasted note and some alcohol in the finish. Hop-heaven in a bottle. (060513)

A very nice surprise. This one poured a nice brown ale-ish color with a very very nice head, that yielded excellent lacing. A very interesting aroma and flavor profile. The aroma was harder to pick up, although they served this at almost cask temperatures (nice). The flavor was somewhat of a brown ale (nutty) with nice hopping that was balanced by rich lightly roasted (coffee?) maltiness. There were spices mixed in with light floral hopping. A great beer. Alcohol was very well hidden.

A perfect winter ale brewed by Avery. I get this one every year, and for good reason... its one of the better winter seasonals that you can find. Pours a nice full bodied brown hue with ruby highlights. Bakers chocolate, caramel, spices flavors come through, as well as some nutty flavors. This one has a nice bit of hops that even out the malt well. This beer is nice and sticky, a little chewy, too. This one is definitely worth picking up in the season.
Bottle . Dark brown colour with a beige head. Hoppy aroma. Sweet caramel and hoppy flavour. Light roasted caramel and bitter finish.
Bottle. Off-white lasting head. Clear dark red body. Barley aroma.  Hazelnut cocoa flavor ending with a pleasant bitterness.
Very mild aroma and flavor. Very slight hops and some sweet malt, maybe a little cocolate. Not much else, kind of watery but not bad.
Ruby pour. A sweet malty brew, but it had a hint of hoppiness, quite drinkable, alcohol is quite mild. Hint of spiciness, overall, a pretty good brew!

05/06. Very dark ruby/brown. Small, frothy, off white head. Aroma of piney, resinous hops and underlying toasty malt, thats all. Flavor has chocolate, caramel, the same piney hops, nuts, some generic winterness, and just a touch of alcohol. Medium/full, balanced palate. Very well balanced brew, very drinkable.

Dark pour and off white head.  Aroma is malty and spicy.   Flavor is strong with caramel malt, hops, and a lasting bitter finish.  Heavy on the English ale  character.  The flavor is a little too heavy for my taste.  A good alcohol bite buried in the heavy flavors.  Very roasty taste as well as some sweetness.  Full body, rich with flavor, and well made.. just a flavor I did not particularly care for.  $9.99 for a six pack at Broudys, Orange park FL.

My first from Avery: enjoyable, but not overwhelming.  Dark in color (deep mahogany, maybe) with matching dark flavors: hops, sweet malt, a little spice on the back of your tongue.  It has a distinctly English vibe to it.  Definitely deceptive with the alcohol, I wouldnt have put this a hair above 5%.  An enjoyable evening beer.
UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark bronze with an  off-white head, aroma of hops,  citrus, spices. flavor is  bitter, alcohol, sweet finish, fruity, i liked this.

(bottle - 12 oz) Clear ruby red color with a very thin tan head with nice glass lacing. Roasty and sweet aroma with hints of almonds, hazelnuts, and caramel. There seems to be some hops underneath all of the malts. Flavor is malty and sweet at the front. Begins with a roasty and nutty flavor, goes to a bitter and malty middle and a slightly hoppy and bitter finish with a lingering malt taste. Thank you Dan for another good quality beer.

Roasty almond, mocha, hazelnut aroma really opens up as this beer warms. Soft and pleasing and very nice. The taste is slightly harsh up front, with a dank, meaty mouthfeel. Roasty scotch flavors lead to a bitter finish without any noticable hop flavors. I couldve used a little more earthy hops in this one to go along with the english style.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2006 En brun øl (33 cl) købt på arbejdet.

Duften erfrugtagtig og humlet. og kan duftes langt væk.

Skummet er cremefarvet.

Smag: bitter, peanut, kaffe og brændt. Kraftig i smagen.

Eftersmag er tør og bitter. - nærmest grape.

Íkke volsomt meget kulsyre.

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 target=blank>beeryum, thanks Dave!) Pours a reddish tea-colored brown with a tight 3/4 inch biscuit head. Aroma is caramel, toffee and hops. Some sloppy, weepy lacing. Mouthfeel smooth, kind of prickly. Flavor is malt-candy sweetness, kind of like brown sugar and smooth whisky with a mild hoppy bitter bite. A nice one.

Certainly pours a deep mahoganywith a medium frothy light tan head that slowly dissapears. A nutty yet soapy aroma with some caramel malt and a bit of smoke. Similar in flavor thre is some hazelnut, some caramel malt, coffee, maple, dark fruit, and some soap elements. Its malty over the tounge with a nutty, bittersweet, somewhat dry finish. Its really too bad Im having this one now, it feels like a great winter holiday beer.
Pours a dark amber.  Aromas of malt, caramel, fruit. Flavor is kinda sweet, fruity, mildly spicy, with a nice hop background.

Pours a dark mahogany with a lasting and creamy tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, raisin, cherry and some chocolate.  Medium bodied and creamy.  Malty, alcohol up front.  I think the alcohol does detract from the overall flavor, but also brings out the coffee and its bitterness.  Hops evident into the finish.  Its very good, just a bit too obviously boozy for me... perfect for a winter seasonal though.

Draft, Baja Bean, Staunton VA. Deep brown color with slight beige head. Aromas of dark caramel/toffee, raisins, slightly sour malt, chalk, toffee, coffee, and chocolate malt. Flavors of all of the above, with a very smooth and full palate and a nice chalky-grain focus on the sweet malt, though with enough bitterness and alcohol warmth to be completely balanced. Though theres no mention of hops in the commercial description, the bitterness throughout this beer was very nice, and I assume it is coming from some substantial hops. The slightest bit of a plasticy sweet note in the finish, which I enjoyed. Very nice indeed.

Pours a lot like a cola, quite dark with a slight, late forming head.  A nice looking beer.  Aroma is fruity and malty.  It is fairly sweet.  First taste is an interesting mix of malt and bitter.  It is a beer that grabs you and holds on.  It also gives a pleasant warming sensation.  Just saw the alcohol percentabe is 8% and am not surprised to find it is high.  It is interesting that the middle of the tongue is stimulated by this beer.  The finish was brought the malts to prominence.  The bitter was still there but more in the background.

An impressive ale, but it lacks something that other Avery Brews and other English strong have. Anyway, its a beautiful bouquet of Caramel, raison and spices. Taste of spices, and mild Coffee, a after-taste Bitterness that sticks with you

Not too impressed...poured a light wood honey woodstain with little head.  Aroma is heavy with malt, honey, and nut.  Flavor is similar but too restrained...could be great...but just not enough omph.  Mouthfeel is dry from some bitterness.

Rich, sweet and malty aroma with some sour notes and hints of caramel. Dark amber colour with off-white head. Nice lacings. Sweet, rich taste with some hops bitterness. Disguises the alcohol totally. Medium to full body with a creamy mouth feel. Overall a very good winter ale.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2006 12 oz bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar:   Dark ruby amber color with a modest off white head. Aroma is light sweet caramel with a wiff of alcohol. Flavor starts caramel sweet with a little fruit finishing with a long dry citrus rind  bitterness. Medium body and creamy with moderate carbonation.

Bottle.  I feel really fortunate to get this beer considering I thought I was buying a 6 pack of another Avery product.

Pours a dark brown with a light tan head.  No aroma that I can detect right away.  

A very rich taste, I can taste the toffee and mocha.  Reminds me of a sweet stout as opposed to a English Strong Ale.

Nonetheless, a good beer that I will look for next year when it is available.

(Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Colour is dark brown/mahogany with hints of ruby. Nose is malty, fruity with lots of dark cherries and chocolate. Taste is malty with an alcohol sweetness,  toffe and chocolate. Quite bitter and hoppy finish. Very nice and wintery. Probably cellarable for a lot more than 2 years.

Clean dark brown color; thin creamy head. Aroma of malt, caramel, roses, Full mouthfeel, malty, with toffee and a lot of caramel, ending with a good hopping (strong and partially resinous), and light roasted malt and roasted nuts. Original. Solid. Dangerous.

I expected a rich and sweet beer.  This beer is neither but still good.  Aroma is surprisingly coffee and oatmeal.  Dark brown with a thick white head.  Very dry flavor, very much like a bitter or malty brown ale.  Dry in the finish as well.  Alcohol is hidden.
So Good I bought a sixer and forgot to save any.  Watch the alcohol content, very unnoticable may kick you in the arse.
Dark brown color with a creamy light brown head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Flavor of malt with hints of caramel and hazelnuts.
Bottle. Dark brown and reddish color. A bit of caramel and nuts and lots of malt. All in all a good beer.

bright and clear reddish-brown colour with a little foam; aroma of caramel and hazelnut, notes of fir needles, slightly roasted; sweet and full-bodied, very tasty, late but robust bitterness before a dry caramelish, woody and malty finish - a big very impressive beer; big thanks to fiulijn

Cinnamon colored with white cremy head.  Smells like carmel and hops.  Some piney notes and roasted nuts.  Borwn sugar as well.  Flavor is slightly astringent with some brown sugar, hops, lots of malt, and some light roasted almonds and walnuts.
pours dark bronze with a thin off-white head, aroma of pine hops, some citrus, spices. flavor is hoppy bitter upfront, alcohol is present, sweet finish, slightly fruity, good body, good brew.

nice dark brown pour with a pillow shaped off white head.  nose of spices and nuts.  malty roastedness.  first sip dispersed cocoa bean roasted malt characters.  after the beer settled and warmed evolved into more of a rock candy sweetness of raisins and figs.  slight alcohol feel.  like a mellow barley wine. good and solid.

What a great looking brew! When put to the light, it is that deep hue of ruby, that I associate with most barleywines or a nice piece of furniture . Sweetness hits at first and then the lingering effects of the hops take hold. An excellent seasonal that will be eagerly anticapated year after year.

bottle 2005. pours deep ruby red with a little off white head aroma is sweet caramel malt  plum nutmeg taste is alcohol caramel  malts  hop bitterness in there as well. a smooth drinker though a little strong on the alcohol.

Dark amber, nice offwhite head. Aroma brings some hops but most of all malts, buttery, some x-mas spices, chocolate, coffee, figs, vanilla and toffee. Gtreat malty flavor, some toffee, vinous and with a great body, hoppy, pleasant finish with some pepper. Dry palate.
35,5 cl bottle. Dark amber colour with a fizzy white head. Hoppy aroma with notes of caraeml. Malty and very hoppy flavour with a touch of toffee.
Poured a dark brown with a very good off-white head. Aroma was malty with nutmeg and a bit of fruit. Flavor was malty with toffee and a bit of chocolate.
Dark ruby red to brown poured with a thin white head. Aroma was rich with chocolate and fruits. Alcohol was intense in the flavor as was fruit sweetness and light chocolate malt flavor.

Dark reddish brown body with a moderate head. Aroma is English ingrediants with notes of dark malts and fruits. Alcohol was always dominating though, moreso in flavor unfortunately. In short I thought this was an OK English Ale with too much alcohol. Bleh

Bottled. Dark amber/ruby red colour, mediumsized beige head. Strong malty nose with some fruitish notes. Flavour is ryeish, maltish and a bit bitterish. Also some coffee is found. Quite pleasant and wellbalanced.

Bottle @ Oliver Twist, StockholmBig head. Very flowery and hoppy aroma with a hint of cheese. Rich body and complex. Filling. Lots of hops and chocolate malts in this one. Perhaps even some rye?. Quite good.

Bottled
Dark ruby red, small expresso head. Coffee nose, a bit rye and barley in it. Medium-bodied, roasted, a bit ryeish flavor with some cold coffee in it. Hides alcohol perfectly.

12oz bottle.Pours a deep dark amber, medium fluffy white head with satisfactory retention & lacing. Big aroma of piney, floral, citrusy Northwest hops, molasses, rich malt, toffee, and a whiff of chocolate. Flavor is roast grain followed by astringent hop bitterness, some malt, toffee and a hint of chocolate. Rich, slightly oily palate. As is their custom, Avery sabotages what could have been a great beer with their tiresome over-astringent hop bitterness.

In the bottle. Picked this up in Peoria IL.  This pours very dark brown to almost a porter color. Head is fluffy and off-white. Aroma is very earthy, almost peaty in fact. Has a strong bitterness, but mainly a tremendous burnt , roasted taste. A very fine ale for sipping outdoors in the hot tub on an atypically warm Nebraska January. If you are looking for a heavy dose of spices, this is not your beer. The spices are quite masked by the roasted malt. A thick mouthfull of a beer.

Chestnut colour with creamy, lasting head - drew a bit of lace as well.
Fairly agressive hops in both aroma and flavour, almost perfectly balanced by sweet, fruity malts and just a hint of alchohol.
Nice full body and quite sharp aftertaste - good to keep warm during the winter :)
Beautiful mahogany color with a large tan head.  Great lacing.  Aroma of roasted  malt and fruit.  Roaste malt/coffee flavor.  Alcohol fairly well hidden.  Nice winter warmer.

Bottle, pretty dark brown pour, with just a touch of orange, and a substantial head.  Malty caramel aroma, with some dark fruit and a sweet molasses undertone.  Medium to big body, with more caramel malty flavors, and some spicy hoppy notes
(Bottle 35,5 cl) Dark ruby red with a small, off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt and prunes. Good, solid body with notes of dried fruits and roasted malt. Fairly dry, bitter finish. 160106
Bottled at The Map Room.  A dark, dark amber with a thin head.  Caramel malts with  traces of mocha and molasses.  Finishes with good hop kick and a small alcohol burn.
this was pretty good stuff, id like to get some more of it.  had a bit of a chocolate flavour, smooth body.  nice brew.

Mahogany color with a small off-white head.   Really sweet malty aroma with hints of caramel and toffee.  Flavor is roasty,nutty, malty, and a little chocolatey.  Complex.  Palate is smooth and round, low carbonation.  Finish is long and fairly bitter.  Overall very good winter beer.  Definitely would drink this again.

Awesome woody, fruity, malty aroma.  Beige head on a dark amberbody.  Taste was very sweet, with hints of dark fruit, toasty malts, and a spicy bitter hop finish.  Nice balance in this, and an awesome beer to sip and chill with.
Has a delicious dark flavor. I am really enjoying this. A perfect blend of hops and rich malts that makes for a tasy beer.

Bottle.  Pours to a deep mahogany body with a thick rocky tan head.  Leaves some pretty nice lacing.  The aroma is what I would call nutty with a light cardboardy toffee scent.  Not all that appealing.  The flavor is chocolate coffee and toffee.  Some undiscernable nuts.  The palate is earthy and medium bodied.  Not really a fan of this beer overall.

Translucent mahogany pour with light tan head. Malty aroma of nuts and toffee. The flavor is multi-layered starting with sweet malts of caramel and brown sugar and then hints of citrusy orange and raisins. The flavor gives way to resiny hop bitterness that sticks with a long finish. The ale is medium bodied and soft on the palate. The alcohol is somewhat subdued, but still noticable. Very drinkable - and enjoyable - winter ale.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2008 Pours dark brown with thin, fading, off-white head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, and chocolate. Flavor is initially of caramel and toffee beforepicking up citrusy bitterness at the end. Finish is bitter, dry and soapy. Medium body, texture is smooth.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2006 Poured from a 12oz. bottlle into a pint glass. High hopes just after the pour as the colour is certainly another success for the Avery palette offering a lovely cherry-tinged burnt sienna. The nose was the first disappointment offering only a little bit of caramel dominated by overbaked bread. I found the flavor in line with the aroma offering a nice enough malt profile reminiscent of a classic English Winter Warmer and an all too ephemeral touch of toffee. An ok brew but not a standout for the brewery.
Bottle: Sweet molassas, nut and light spicey hops; burnt nutty caramel notes, roasty and slightly dry finish; some alcoholic burn and astringency; OK

(bottle at Oliver Twsi, Stockholm) Dark, clear brown colour with a small bubbly tan head. Complex aroma of raisin, caramel, nuts, spices and alcohol.  Well.balnced flavour of nuts, clean caramel malts, marzipan, floral hops earthy spices, mint and alcohol. Chocolate, raisin, nougat and floral hops in the long, warming, delicous aftertaste. The one is a keeper during the cold swedish winter storms.

Bottle. Pours a murky ruby-shaded brown. Nose is nutty and chocolaty. Bit of toffee and dried fruits. Says no spice but its aroma  makes you think differently. Taste is bittersweet, with flowery hops, cocoa, hint of cinnamon, toffee, dried fruits, hazelnut coffee, and a hint of brown sugar. Theres too much lingering hoppiness in this and normally its never a detractor. In this, though, its not working for me. Body is medium with a mild carbonation feel. Theres more lingering hoppiness throughout this one. Finishes with cocoa, light alcohol coming through, melon, light citrus, toffee, and hazelnut coffee. Not as good as Id have hoped, but still very drinkable.
malty nose with opaque brown hue topped w/ brownish head.  floral aroma thats apparently dry hopped, although the hop presence is less felt in the body.
12 0z bottle. Deep brown with smell of roasted malt and chocolate. The taste is primarily the same as the smell -- minimal hop presence to balance the malt. Not a bad beer, but needs more hops.

12oz. bottle.  Deep brown with yellow and orange highlights.  Small light tan head.  Woody and earthen malt aroma, grassy hop accents.  Muddled clash of spicy malt flavors, biscuit, raisin, bitter nutshell, and burnt toffee.  Residual bitterness and hop herbal grassiness in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium, slightly sticky.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2005 This was a good beer, I am looking and seeing that this is 8% and I never would have guessed.  It pours a mahogany color with a tan head that has really good lacing.  The flavor is of malts, not too sweet, with a nice balance of hops.  This is a very well balanced beer and very drinkable.

Bottle from a Holiday pack-The aroma just overwhems you, its loaded with a cherry fruit smell, even before you finish the pour.  Solid copper to deep red color with a medium to large head.  Medium amount of lacing.  Full malt flavor with an alcohol kick.  Some hop taste and aroma appear from time to time.
poured a crimson red with a light brown head that left lacing.raosted malts,brown sugar,and nuts make up the aroma.flavor was much of the same with an alcohol bite.  medium mouthfeel.
Draught: I thought this was gross, it had a nasty spiciness to it that made me wish I never tried it. I really did not like this.

Clear, reddish amber with a fluffy, tan head.  Whole grains, raisin, maple, light smoke, apples, caramel and some nuts.  A mild hoppy perfume comes out from time to time.  A moderate body with low to moderate carbonation, but with a lasting flavor.  The malt is layered and exciting because it has a nice balance of flavors and a nice balance of sweet and savory.  The hoppy bitterness exists, but is subtle and just enough to keep the malt in check.  This is one of the more enjoyable winter beers in my eyes at this point.  Its warm, hearty, flavorful and, more importantly, well balanced.  Well done.

Sampled at a 2005 Christmas and Winter beer tasting at Delilahs, Chicago, IL.  2001 vintage.  Clear dark brown ale having a small diminishing tan head. No discernable carbonation. Spicy candy malt aroma.  Medium bodied that starts with light sweet malt, sour cherries, and toffee flavors.  Finishes with light sourness. Though cellarable for only 2 years, this old vintage brew was pretty decent.

Luscious malty aroma, whiff of earthy hops.  It smells soft.  Medium-full bodied, luscious dark malts, some dark crystal malts, toffee with hint of chocolate.  Light bitterness, whiff of earthy hops late.  This is good stuff.

Someone spilled their Scotch Ale in my English Strong Ale.  Pours dark mahogany with a tiny tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is nutty and full of roasted malts.  But, this tastes a lot like a stronger black and tan or Scotch Ale.  Very malty, very nutty, and a big finish of toffee and roasted malts.  Almost too flavor without the alcohol you would expect.  In the end, its still a good beer
Amber colour with a tan head. Malty and nutty aroma with hints of dark fruits. Warming malty flavor with caramel, bread, toffee and some dark fruits too. Very nice warming malty aftertaste.

Crystal clear medium brown body and perfectly nice, appealing-looking frothy head.  Figs and caramel, honey and nutty aroma compliment the nutty and malty flavor quite well.  Well-balanced, mild hops, and very true to this style of beer.  A nice lighter winter beer.  The 8% alcohol is barely noticeable.

Deep ruby/chestnut brown color under a thin light tan head. Nose is a bit faint, but pleasantly dominated by aromas of roasted malts, dark wheat bread and nuts. Mouthfeel was full and chewy with a slightly smooth, oily texture. Somewhat restrained, but delicious flavors of toffee, roasted malt, bread, walnuts and smoke are noted blending into a somewhat assertive crisp hoppy finish; a bit more than would be expected for this style. Overall just a tad on the light side for a winter warmer, but still well balanced and classy.

Ah the Old Jub. Amber with a tan head. Aroma is malty and breaklike with some nuttiness. Malty brew that tastes spiced regardless of the ingredients. Smooth with the hops coming through at the end. I liked the description of soft for this one. Just felt "soft". Again hops define themselves in the finish.

Probably my favorite at the Holiday Festival at Delilahs this year.   Some great smoky/peaty aromas.  Very syrupy toffee like palate with a pleasant alcohol (not overwhelming) burn.  Good afterdinner brew.

Pretty reddish brown, with pretty nice beige head.  Aromas are a little weak... of scotch ale-type malt with lightly detectable hops.  Flavor is pleasant, but not outstanding.  Very nice balance and mouthfeel which are the two strongest aspects.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: yummers, didnt really expect this to be that great. definitely full bodied, but a damn fine body!!
Bottled. Amber appearance. Quite soft, malty and sweet. Quite bitter finish. A well-balanced brew in terms of the sweet body and the bitter finish.
Bottle. Clear reddish-mahogony beer with a small tan head. Roasty/caramel malt aroma. Rich caramel flavor with roasty/coffee notes. Some hop bitterness at end. Fuller bodied.

Bottled.  Poured a clear, deep ruby/orange with a very nice tall beige head (receded after a minute, but left nice intricate lacing).  Full aroma of English bittering hops, caramel, hazlenut, and some wintery spiciness.  There was a lot of spicy maltage in the flavor... working well with the English hops and caramel.  Smooth across the tongue with bitterness around the edges.  Long, spicy, and warming finish.  This is a great fireside treat!

UPDATED: APR 12, 2006 Starts out with a mild aroma of caramel/toffee. A smooth pour with very little head.  The flavor is a sweet, malty blend with just enough hops thrown in to keep it from tasting syrupy.  Palate is very creamy smooth, but goes down clean - no tongue coating.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2006 12oz - 2005 - Aroma is hoppy, carmel malt, and christmas cheer.  Pours a deep brown with red accents.  A small head and great lacing.   Flavor is carmel, hops and  toffee.   Palate is smooth and creamy.  A nice easy drinking brew to sit by the fire with.
Tastes like a watered-down version of GD Hibernation.  Call it Hibernation Light,  Great appearnace, but too watered down for my taste.

Draught.  Brown appearance, with a lasting off-white head.  Hoppy nose, with citrus and some malt.  Flavor is very hoppy, and a little roasty in finish.  Grass in aftertaste.  Could be a nice beer, but the hopwreck kind of kills all of the other flavors that are supposed to be there.

Bottled: Dark amber coloured. Clear. Light brown small dense head. Berries, caramel and spices in the nose Flavour of chocolate, hops, light fruit, sweetness. Has a full maltbase and a light alcoholtouch. Is nicely bitter in the end, and has a long impact on the palate. Nice one.

Poured with a dark ruby and brown body. The head is thin with a slightly yellowish tint. The aroma is nutty with some light toffee and coffee. The taste is a little spicy with some ginger and light cinnamon. There is also some toffee and a little note of bourbon. A nice winter warmer that is definitely a sipper. A very creamy and thick mouthfeel. I imagine this would smooth out nicely with some age.

Poured dark mahogany with a semi-frothy off-white head.  Aroma is dark fruit, cinnamon, cookie dough, and a bit of alcohol.  Taste is slightly sweet molasses, dark fruit and floral hops with a dry alcohol finish.  Fairly full body with assertive carbonation.  Nice, if somewhat generic, strong ale.

Bottled.
Clear red coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Sweet aroma with notes of fruits and spices with flowery notes.
Sweet fruity flavour with notes of mlats and caramel.
Hoppy finish.

This starts with a large tan head over a sparkling clear, deep garnet body. 
doughy chocolate covered cherry aroma.
Well balanced flavor, moderately sweet with a nice bitterness at the finish.
No alcohol in the flavor. Not too bad overall, Id have another one.

There is a kind of smoky coffee, nutty, and alcohol flavor in this beer.  Aroma of the better of the lame European hops.  Every sip tastes different. not sure what i think about it.  this bottle even tastes different than the last one i had.  I think my rating is as high as it is mostly because i know im drinking a high gravity beer.

Very malty aroma, with some nice notes of toffee, caramel and a light hop note. Sloght hazy deep amber body wti ha small but dense off-white head. Sweet and mlaty flavor, notes of dates, nuts, toffee and a light dry hint in the end. Alcohol is noticeable and it feels quite warming.

Deep reddish colour with a dense tan head. Sweet malty aroma with a solid hoppyness and a faint alcohol note. Malty flavor with a dark fruit and caramel sweetness. Nice balanced hoppy bitterness. Good one!

Fairly dark ruby brown with a nice, creamy, pock-marked head that lasts for a while. The aroma is thickly malty, with a slightly aggressive hoppiness in the background. The flavor is again dominated by malts, toffee, hazlenuts and a slight dustiness. Slight hint of dried fruits like dates. Not bad at all.

Aroma has some fruits, roast, and malts.  The off white head is farily thick.  taste has sweet and spiced malts that sit in the throat.  Nice Christmas/wintery ale.  The malts really come out as it warms.
malty aroma.  dark red with medium  off white head.  a very good blend of malts.  a sweet fruity flavor.

Med Brown, cola-like color.  Tan head...  ...Malty, hints of chocolate, Bitter with sweet finish.... ....Med Body.  Light carbonation. ...  ...   ...A solid Strong ale.  Delightfully on the hoppy end of the spectrum.  Good balance between the hops and malt

Bottle. Red brown colour with a medium baige head. Light roasted malty, Dark fruits aroma and a sweet caramel malty, dark fruits, , licurise, light alcoholic taste. Medium to full body and a sweet anis, light alcoholic finish.

Almost like an English barleywine, this cola colored ale.  Nice creamy tan head with good lacing.  The aroma is a bitter, roasted malt, a touch of chocolate, nuts, and dark, dried fruit.  Very smooth.  Besides the toasty malts, theres some soft toffee in the flavor.  Nuts, fruit, white peppers, and some coffee, too.  The alcohol mainly comes out in the dry finish.  Nice.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a deep ruby- brownish color with a nice thick head.  Aroma of malty nuts, fruit,chocolate,  and alcohol.  Smooth body with hints of carbonation.  This is a great winter brew.  Smooth enough, tasy enough, and very warming.

Deep, lucrative brown with a safire kiss and a creamy, dense, blanketing quarter-inch head, leaving perfect lacing all the way down the tulip.  Promising aroma of brown sugar, caramelized pecans, black cherries, concord grapes, prune juice and a hint of nutmeg.  Flavor smacks with discernable alcohol amidst festive spicing.  Plum skin, toasted rye, and mulled, diluted port sprinkled with a dose of pepper to keep with the holiday spice tradition.  Some accents of crème liqueur drizzled over singed walnut casings.  Stinging, resoundingly bitter-sweet.  Medium-bodied and numerous elemental palate forces butting heads with each other, simply not in agreement.  Effervescence exceeds its tolerable limits, finishing with a pessimistic alcohol sting.

12 oz bottle via trade w/ Sprinkle.  Pours a dark ruby with a thin foamy 1" head.  Mainly malty nose with supporting notes of spice, yeast, and alcohol.  Flavor is malty with minimal hop presence.  No hint of spices that the nose indicated (after reading comm. desc. I guess I was right).  There is some oxidation here as well.  Lighter bodied with soft carbonation.  Not a bad Winter Warmer, but rather thin and bland to my tastes.  Im wandering if maybe this was from last years release.  I might question their "cellarable for 2 years" claim.  This just didnt seem big enough to stand up to any significant aging.

This bottled brew poured a head of foamy frothy topped tan colored mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a carbonated transparent deep caramel rel brown colored body and a good lacing.  It had a malt hop dough caramel  aroma.  The  mouth feel was tingly from start to finish, mildly vinous with a strong caramel malt flavor.  There was a very noticeable hoppy content to it along with a yummy caramel flavor.  Delicious!  Another fine brew by Avery!

Drunk in 2 bottles not bad. Rich flavor. From my home state of Colorado. Beats Coors, which isnt tough.  You guys like this real rich taste, Huh???  Like I said, I give it some points because I like a beer with a kick and this has it. I am kind of getting interested in these Breckinridge/ Boulder Brauries. This is a Boulder Braurie. I kind of like the Breckinridge Braurie better, but is OK.  It is some business for Colorado that is all I know hope  you guys find something in it you like.  I like what some Brauries are doing with beers here it is worth exploring for you beer Conniseurs. 

Rich beer but not skunky, I dont think beer should be skunky. 

Licorice head via hazlenuts. 

Some people say the beer is warming, I agree I dont know why, but it is a relaxing brew to drink that is  reminiscint of holiday times as the picture shows on the bottle.  It would be great enjoyed with some holiday hores dourves and watching a winter footaball game.  Enjoy  men.

Deep reddish brown color with a decent off-white head. Caramel and toffee aroma with a hint of plum and chocolate. Toffee is big in the flavor but there are also notes of dark fruits like raisin and prune along with a slight coffee flavor. Good stuff.

Im heading into this with negative expectations. My battle with Strong Ales wages on, yet Im merely an abecedarian to those examples which fall into this category. Plus, Ive heard not so great things about this specific specimen. It pours a clear ruddy, brown, with a deep tanned ivory head of cream. I can already taste the caramel and toffee. To the nose, a light, brisk whiff of sugar and hops, mingled with the though of an aged cheddar, no wait thats my french bread pizza in the microwave, the perfect bachelors companion. An expected strong dose of caramel malt, with a lack of hop balance. Two phased, this beer begins with a bright, chipper vanilled brown sugar malt, morphing into a mellow, christmas cookie and marshmallow run.  I was mistaken at first, thinking this an American SA, but its indeed an English. And as the beer warms, its yielding some crisp, green euro hop notes on the back and smack. It actually doesnt fare poorly compared to other examples Ive run with.

Pours dark brown with a foamy light brown head. Malt, raisin and a warming note of alcohol in the aroma. Sweet malt and liquorice flavor with plenty of spices and a bite of alcohol. A bit sharp with a not so pleasant note of medicine, but still quite enjoyable. Warming.

Bottle. Pours a formidable deep, dark red with foamy off-white head and pretty good lacing. Nose of malts and alcohol. Very soft, spiceless flavors of pure, lightly roasted malts. Sweetness with hints of dark fruits and raisin from the alcohol. Incredibly smooth texture, rich and warming body, and very hidden alcohol. An excellent warmer.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2013 on draught. This is a super deep opaque mahogany with a solid head. The nose is a forest of piny hops, rich caramel, some toasty brown sugar, and smoke. This has, surprisingly, a mocha coffee, porter-like body which is highlighted by some smoked wood and a bright, spicy hop onslaught. The flavor is huge and provides a welcome overtaking of the palate.

[November 28, 2013]

6 pack from Liquor Galaxy. I always wondered why I had such an affinity for this beer so I decided to revisit it. The answer, Im not sure. I guess my taste has changed over the past few years, but this is just okay and Im ready to move on after one bottle. I do like that it is a little unique compared to all the other winter specials on the shelves this time of year. The malty nose is very nutty with hints at vanilla, mocha and alcohol. Full malty body with flavors that could possibly lead the drinker to believe spices were used, but nothing quite on the level of an adjunct. Yeah, its a pretty good beer and Ill probably have it again in the future. But Im not nutso about it.

[Bottle, Oct 13, 2007] Im not exactly sure why, but  I do have a soft spot for this stuff.  There is a bit less hops than I remember, but many interesting, subtle spiced notes. Im impressed that no spices are used, because I get definite hints at nutmeg and cardamom. A thin, juicy berry-like flavor is noted along with a pleasant chocolate-esque finish. Its a nice change from the usual winter warmers, but very appropriate for the season.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2006 Bottle.  Pours transparent dark amber, beautiful color.  Medium off white head.  Aroma is rather nice.  Toasted caramel malts, resinous hops, slightly nutty.
